Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Thu)

--

By perseverance and fortitude we have the prospect of a glorious
issue; by cowardice and submission, the sad choice of a variety of
evils- a ravaged country- a depopulated city- habitations without
safety, and slavery without hope- our homes turned into barracks and
bawdy-houses for Hessians, and a future race to provide for, whose
fathers we shall doubt of. Look on this picture and weep over it! and
if there yet remains one thoughtless wretch who believes it not, let
him suffer it unlamented.

- Thomas Paine, "American Crisis"

Well, who can criticize Thomas Paine perhaps our least famous, but most imp=
ortant founding father?=0A=0ACertainly not me.  You just can't go wrong wit=
h a Thomas Paine quotation.=0A=0AOf course it is worth mentioning that at t=
he time the Hessians (German mercenaries employed by the British) were actu=
ally being quartered in people's private homes.  And an armed revolution wa=
s under way when Paine wrote American Crisis.  The Battle of Trenton was ab=
out a week later.  Look it up.=0A=0AAnyone out there have foreign soldiers =
quartered in your house?  I guess you wouldn't be able to post here if you =
did.=0A=0AFrom the same pamphlet:=0A=0A"Tis surprising to see how rapidly a=
 panic will sometimes=0A             run through a country. All nations and=
 ages have been=0A             subject to them. Britain has trembled like a=
n ague at the=0A             report of a French fleet of flat-bottomed boat=
s; and in the=0A             fourteenth [fifteenth] century the whole Engli=
sh army, after=0A             ravaging the kingdom of France, was driven ba=
ck like men=0A             petrified with fear; and this brave exploit was =
performed by=0A             a few broken forces collected and headed by a w=
oman, Joan of=0A             Arc. Would that heaven might inspire some Jers=
ey maid to=0A             spirit up her countrymen, and save her fair fello=
w sufferers=0A             from ravage and ravishment! Yet panics, in some =
cases, have=0A             their uses; they produce as much good as hurt. T=
heir=0A             duration is always short; the mind soon grows through t=
hem,=0A             and acquires a firmer habit than before. But their pecu=
liar=0A             advantage is, that they are the touchstones of sincerit=
y and=0A             hypocrisy, and bring things and men to light, which mi=
ght=0A             otherwise have lain forever undiscovered. In fact, they =
have=0A             the same effect on secret traitors, which an imaginary=
=0A             apparition would have upon a private murderer. They sift ou=
t=0A             the hidden thoughts of man, and hold them up in public to=
=0A             the world."=0A=0Ahttp://www.urbanophile.com/arenn/americana=

ndex.htm=0Ahttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Paine=0Ahttp://en.wikipedia.=

Subject: Re: [sfraves] The 1 day job in Campbell Re: [sfraves] NRR: job opportunities

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Wow that was some adventure! Things work out in strange ways

Osby Oi Oi Jamz <osby@viberation.com> wrote:  OK... so like the day after Chirstmas, I talk to Matt Downer on the
phone... he told me that he needed help like with his business yada yada
yada 'cause he "can't do eveything myself"... so I offered to work w/ him
& get his shit organized & stuff 'cause at the time, we were reeaaly good
friends & stuff! So we ended up talking that night for like 3 hours on
the phone, literally. Then he told me all the things, all the benifits i
woiuld get by working with him & all this money i would make working for
him & yada yada la la la! His promises even included him giving me my own
lap top & a condo for to stay at for free that he owned so i could finish
my Adult School Education & still work for him in SJ! Dope!

So the next morning, he picks me up in Hercules & brings me all the way to
Campbell to his "office" which is basically his garage. He had me change
in grubby clothes to start work. He told me to organize his garage while
he attended meetings all day. OK.. now you gotta understand, by organize,
he meant file like 20 boxes of reciepts, documents, papers, jounral
thingies, accounting books, & mislleaneous papers... then there were
products he stocked from all the companies he owned that needed to be put
somewhere, this messy ass desk, a computer that needed t be put together,
phones answered, and general housekeeping (dust, wash, windex, vacum, etc)
that needed to be done! So i slaved away that day and did what needed to
be done. He came home like around 8PM & he was impressed with my work! 
We then spent the next 2 hours putting things in storage in the backyard!

Oh yeah.. it was my 1st night of well.. an online class that I was suppose
to like get online & do whatever, but I forgot my sylabus for the class @
home or something & didn't have the proper log in info i needed to do that
class thing online that night.

He dropped me off @ the Cal Train station by his house & well.. after 2
hours of waiting & seeing like 3 Cal Trains zoom by, i was stuck! I
mean... it was still like holliday hours from xmas, & the trains stopped
running early. I mean, i seriously thought he picked me up from Hercules
that morning & it was just curtious on his part to bring me home after i
was done working for the day, then I'd do the commute thing starting the
next day. I mean... Matt didn't tell me he wasn't going to & it was
probably my bad just to assume. BUt i dunno... I mean... we he got back
from his like 10 hour Meeting whatever & kept saying "I'm sooo tired", i
guess he was planning on it, but well... I wouldn't even ask a tired
person to do a 200 mile back & forth drive just to bring me home. BUt
still.. ya know?

So funny enough, i didn't remember Matt's phone ### by heart & the paper i
had it written on was in Hercules & 411 didn't have it either! I also
didn't know anyone elses phone ### i could call in the South Bay cause
well... i just didn't have my list with me. So after a long while, i went
across the street to the Safeway Plaza & i dunno... i just figured it it
was more well lighted than the Cal Train Station & i could figure out what
i needed to do to be safe if i was gonna spend the next many hours by
myself.

So as soon as i got to Safeway, i just like stood there by the phone booth
& man, i was like heeeeeeella confuzed 'cause I was in this mondo pickle. 
But atleast I felt kinda safe. Then this dude like came up to me and like
asked me for change to make a phone call & I lied & said i only had enough
money for me to take the train in the morning when Cal Train opened up & i
was pretty stuck. Then he gave me this whole sob story about going to his
Sister's house in Redingin the morning, his Mom is the Hospital, his
grandmother, & calling his ex girlfriend's cousin who lived around the
corner. So after he was done venting, then i vented to him about my whole
day & how I was stuck & why i was where i was @ the moment. We kinda
talked for a while longer before he said that he'd like help me out & just
stay with me 'til Cal Train opened up since he was in the same predicament
as well!

Oh yeah.. this guy's name was Jack. I actaully called him Crack Head Jack
'cause well.. he told me how he was spun for 3 days & he was like coming
down hard which is why he was soooooo emotional. I mean.. i have a thing
about trusting strangers way to quick, but I dunno.. something about Jack
was sincere. So i ended up giving him money to make that call & actually
a few minutes later, we were hangin' out at his ex girlfirends's cousin's
pad. We were probably there for like an hour & 1/2 'til her parents got
home & we left!

While we were walking back to Safeway, he told me that it would probably
be better if we head downtown & kick it at some of the empty houses over
there. Well... it was his hood, so i figured he knew what he was talking
about! Anywaze, the next few hours we spent in downtown like going to
tacobell, walkin' around campus, & we actually hung out & slepton this
porch of this 1 abandoned house.

When daylight hit, we went to a donut shop & had coffee & donuts & had
like this loooooong ass goodbye.. I mean... we were reeeeeally close by
that point & practically knew almost everything about each other from
talkin' the whole night. It was Awesome, sad, but hella touching! He
told me that as soon he made it up to Redding, he was gonna call me! We
even planned on hangin' out again, i'd like do a day trip up to Redding &
stuff. But yeah, it took 3 hours, but i finally made it home.. Needless
to say, I didn't bother going back to work for Matt Downer, CEO again! Oh
yeah.. he called me that night & we kinda had a mondo bitch session at
each other.. lol.. Hello 2day.. we ain't spoken since then :) Hello 2day
-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] [NRR]Pandora's Trunk February 3rd

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="Windows-1252"

All, this is a trunk sale hosted by a friend of mine in SF. Please take the=
 time to check it out and spread the word if you like it. Make sure to tell=
 them where you heard about it. I get no kickbacks or anything just want to=
 see what forms of promo are working.=20
=20
=20
Brigadoon is a mythical (ok, mythical since it was invented
for a 1947 musical) Scottish town that only appears once
every hundred years... we're a little bit more dependable
than that. Don't let us pass like ships in the night; there
is too much in store for this weekend to miss out! Sail
yourself down to SoMa from 1-7 on Saturday for a chance to
see sculpture inspired by the sea, from three local artists
working in reclaimed materials. Hang out on the foredeck,
cocktail in hand, and soak in a little sitar-viola tag team
music. We are throwing caution to the wind and letting them
use an amplifier so please don't splash or we'll all go down
in flames. Let our masseuse swab *your* decks before you
unfurl your sails in style - we're of course bringing you
the best in recycled and reclaimed fashion and accessories.
When you are far out at sea you have to work with what
you've got, and while we don't have any clothes made of
rimey sailcloth (it chaps our bum) we've got damn near
everything else that used to be something else.
=20
=20
Featured at this event is our DIY clothing modification
station, bringing you free and at-cost clothing, patches,
and trims so that you can make the finest pirate pants your
little heart desires - but are too tongue-tied to articulate
to anyone else.
Pandora's Trunk
A bi-monthly eclectic arts showcase & designer sample sale
February 3rd - featuring works from recycled and reclaimed
materials
http://pandorastrunk.com
Saturday Feb. 3rd 1-7pm
free admission - live music - free drinks
916 Natoma st SoMa SF
(between Mission & Howard, 10th & 11th)
http://pandorastrunk.com/pandorastrunkfeb3rd.jpg
Fashion & Accessories designers, working in reclaimed textiles:
Miranda Caroligne - http://www.mirandacaroligne.com
Medium Reality - http://mediumreality.com
Bad Unkl Sista - http://badunklsista.com
Miss Velvet Cream - http://missvelvetcream.com/
Homey Grown - http://www.homeygrown.org/
Siya Nara Clothing - http://www.myspace.com/siya_nara
Doctor Popular - (maybe if we are lucky he will yo-yo like
he does on his website. All he has agreed to do is sell his
hats made of recycled ties. Bring your puppydog eyes and
we=92ll see what we can get=85) http://doctorpopular.com/
Shannon Riley - armlets and other brightly colored body warmers.
Other creations in the key of re-thought:
19 Moons - jewelry made with old typewriter keys and other
reclaimed bits - http://www.19moons.com
Recover your thoughts - blank books made of reclaimed books
and publishing scraps - http://www.recoveryourthoughts.com/
Joan R. Rogers - a venerated east coast printmaker has
mailed us a little west coast exclusive - art notebooks from
the scraps of a whole career=92s worth of art prints.
Bike parts revisited - there will be too many people working
in this medium to list them all. Rest assured that the
sheer number of innovative uses for old bike parts that we
will find and display for you will boggle your mind, and
stir even the hatin=92est heart.
Indie artists:
Alicia Bainbridge Escott
http://www.boombox.org/alicia
Working in expressive monochromatics recalling the kinetic
landscapes of Northwestern painter James Lavadour, Alicia=92s
pocket-sized paintings are made on polystyrene, or #6
plastic. This plastic is very common but not recyclable;
the work seeks to educate people about which plastics can
and cannot be recycled.
Rachel Lyra Hospodar
http://mediumreality.com
Bringing you a 1-6 punch, Rachel is showing a pair of
diptychs made just in time for Anon Salon's NYE Sea of
Dreams, as well as a sparkling fresh pair of undersea animal
sculptures made from reclaimed objects and an unhealthy
amount of glue.
Katie Sutherland
Marcus Guillard
This impressive large-scale work was also shown at the NYE
event. Take a moment out of the frenetic pace of talking
art and drinking sangria to lean your head back and
contemplate putting down roots, floating away, and taking
flight, all at once.
=20
Edible Love - decadent microbusiness chocolate truffles from
our resident chocolatier are good for you on all levels.
Don=92t eat a whole box, though you=92ll be tempted. The
overdose will make it hard for you to enjoy our licensed
masseuse or live musicians.
Enjoyed the show last time but not sure if you can make it
this time around? Word of mouth is the most valuable
promotions we can get. Help us and your friends out by
hooking us up with each other! Please take a moment to
forward this email to any friends you think may be
interested in the show. You can also show them (or print
out for yourself) our flyer which contains a tiny map:
http://pandorastrunk.com/pandorastrunkfeb3rd.jpg

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Mac Video Capture...



it's called "Snapz Pro"

http://www.ambrosiasw.com/utilities/snapzprox/


:)

Of course, there's also the lotek method of getting
the Apple DVI to Video adapter (
http://store.apple.com/1-800-MY-APPLE/WebObjects/AppleStore.woa/61154000/wo/Vh3YLstyP9xe2P7rzcr1J1AeWGm/1.0.21.1.0.8.25.7.11.0.3
) and running your output to your DV camera, recording
it to tape, then logging the clips back into iMovie or
Final Cut via the typical method.  depending on your
needs, this might be a better option.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Mac Video Capture...

The itunes visualizer is actually an old version of the software G-force by Andy Omera. I think 55ware.com is still his website but I am sure you could google for it otherise.

You can download newer better versions of G-force that will work within iTunes or stand alone. Some of them have the ability to output to quicktime video files as well.

Finally if you like those visuals then you should certainly download the electric sheep screensaver, its not audio syncronized but the quality is amazing.

Nate

 **Alright folks, it's time once again!  Kontrol # 20!

Derek and Tim are both REALLY excited about playing for the
KONTROL 'heads and are definitely ready to throw down like
there's no tomorrow!  Even if you're not quite as familiar with
these two as some of our past guests, don't let that stop you
from coming out...both are truly outstanding DJs that know how
leave a dancefloor sweaty and smiling.

It's gonna be another raucous night of friendly faces, good vibes,
and of course plenty of amazing music.

HOPE TO SEE YOU TOMORROW!



Saturday, February 3rd

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant house
every first Saturday at the Endup


featuring New York's Twin Towers of techno!


=====>  DEREK PLASLAIKO  <=====

Spectral Sound . Ghostly Int'l . The Bunker :: NYC
This former stalwart of the Detroit party scene moved
to New York City a few years back and has made a
quick ascent to the top, recently being crowned
2006's "Best Techno DJ" by the Village Voice.


=====> TIM XAVIER <=====

LTD400 . Klikhaus . Klink . Cocoon :: Brooklyn
As an amazingly prolific producer, international DJ,
owner of 2 highly regarded minimal labels, and chief
engineer at one of the country's best  mastering studios,
Tim has become one of the US's true techno treasures.


plus special guest from across the pond:

=====>  PHILIP SHERBURNE  <=====

Raum Club . XLR8R . Pitchfork :: Barcelona
San Francisco's own minimal-loving expat and renound
music journalist returns to show off his exhaustive
knowledge of the genre and skills honed as a resident
at Barcelona's famed Raum Club.


with resident DJs:

SAMMY D  ( classic . dirtybird . utensil )
ALLAND BYALLO  ( liebe detail . floppy funk )
CRAIG KUNA  ( concept sf . esdjco )
NIKOLA BAYTALA ( robsoul . junior boys own . s.w.a.t. )

_________________________________________________

THE ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm-6am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

_________________________________________________


DEREK PLASLAIKO

Some people filter through the record bins, taking what are on the wall or
record store employee suggestions. Then there are people who dig deeper into
the dusty crates, and absorb music like a sponge; ignoring labels, bucking
trends and are forever on a quest to find the perfect record. The ones that
make the staunchest of chin stroking, note taking trainspotters lose their
shit on the dancefloor, hanging on every record from one to the next.

Derek Plaslaiko unquestionably falls into the latter category. As a teen
equally transfixed by Mojo and Wizard cassettes and Minor Threat 7"s,
Plaslaiko followed the beats from his hometown 20 miles south of Detroit to
the epicenter of Detroit techno, then enjoying its third wave of success. He
quietly paid his dues on Detroit's rave circuit, and was a crucial piece of
the puzzle for the legendary Poorboy and Syst3m parties of the mid-nineties.
He quickly earned a reputation for forward thinking DJ sets that were
clinical, sophisticated and extremely sensual. This combination resulted in
a residency for Family, the weekly party at Detroit's legendary Motor.  With
a reputation for high energy sets that were versatile and tasteful,
Plaslaiko slowly became in demand on the Midwestern club circuit; sharing
the stage with such techno luminares as John Acquaviva, Kevin Saunderson,
Richardo Villalobos, Baby Ford, and Matthew Herbert. It was also during that
time Plaslaiko was asked by Carl Craig to perform at the inaugural edition
of the Detroit Electronic Music Festival.

In 2003, Plaslaiko became part of the original team of DJs at Detroit's
Untitled parties, sharing a residency with Tadd Mullinix (aka James T.
Cotton), Matthew Dear and Mike Servito. In 2004 he made the decision to head
east and set up camp in New York City, determined to bring a slice of the
Motor City to the Big Apple.  Currently, Derek is one of the resident DJs at
the Bunker (Subtonic) in NYC, as well as an integral part of the Wolf + Lamb
monthly parties. Most recently, he was honored in the Village Voice 2006's
"Best Of" poll as New York's Best Techno DJ.


Derek Plaslaiko's website:
http://plaslaiko.net
Derek on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/plaslaiko


MIXES:

Live @ Yura Yura, Philadelphia  (2 hours - 111MB)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/AUD/Derek_Plaslaiko_-_Live_@_Yura_Yura_-_Philadelphia_07.15.06.mp3


Live @ Wolf+Lamb, New Year's Eve, New York  (3+ hours - 182MB)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/AUD/Derek_Plaslaiko_-_Live_@_Wolf+Lamb_-_NYC_12.31.05.mp3


_________________________________________________


TIM XAVIER

Tim Xavier made himself a household name for techno fans in the late 90s
with his innovative releases on Blueline, and since he has continued to push
the envelope with new sounds and ideas. His techno releases have been
consistent and solid, having signed work to major labels such as Default,
Advanced and PV. He has been featured on CD compilations by well known
techno artists such as Chris Liebing and Christian Wunsch, and his tracks
get repeated play by top names such as Luciano, Pan-Pot, Richie Hawtin,
Magda, Marco Carola, Troy Pierce and Adam Beyer.

More recently, he has expanded his talents and broadened his production
spectrum into the minimal genre, starting two new labels in 2005: LTD400 and
Klickhaus. LTD400 is his solo label featuring his own work, and the releases
have been featured on mix compilations by Ricardo Villalobos and Steve Bug.
His new project, Klickhaus, will feature his own production as well as other
artists. Tim has also collaborated with Tony Rohr as the Afternoon Coffee
Boys, their debut release on Clink selling out in days and continuously
demanding repress. Upcoming releases from them include a full EP on Cocoon
due out in February.

As if Tim isn't busy enough, he is also the owner and chief mastering
engineer at Manmade Mastering in Brooklyn, NY, where he cuts dubplates and
masters. His precise ear, attention to detail and demand for perfection have
created a devoted following with his clients. Somehow between producing,
running his labels and cutting records, he still finds time play
international gigs, sharing his sought-after sound with fans and dancefloors
alike.


Tim Xavier's website:
http://www.manmademastering.com/

Tim's discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Tim%20Xavier

Tim on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/timxavier


MIXES:

Zombie Mix  (66min6sec - 154MB)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/AUD/Tim_Xavier_-_Zombie_Mix.mp3

The Art of Happiness  (62min - 141MB)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/AUD/Tim_Xavier_-_The_Art_of_Happiness.mp3


_________________________________________________


PHILIP SHERBURNE

San Francisco critic Philip Sherburne has been heavily involved in the
electronic-music world for the past seven years, writing for publications
including the New York Times, Village Voice, Slate, XLR8R, URB, Wax Poetics,
Grooves, Nylon, RES, Neumu.net <http://neumu.net/> and many others --
including The Wire, where his "Critical Beats" column offers a monthly
roundup of experimental dance music. Philip has also written on sound art
and avant-garde practice for Frieze and Parkett, curated the companion CD
for Leonardo Music Journal's 2003 issue, and given talks at SFMOMA, PS1,
Tate Modern and the MUTEK festival. A book chapter on classical minimalism
and minimal techno is forthcoming in Christoph Cox and Daniel Warner's Audio
Culture: Readings in Modern Music (Continuum Press).  He is widely credited
as coining the name of the sub-genre "Microhouse" when writing for The Wire
in 2001.  As a DJ, Philip holds a residence at Barcelona's Raum Club,
formerly held a monthly event in San Francisco called "Soda", and has
performed in New York, Austin, Portland, Seattle, and Montreal.


Philip Sherburne's website:
http://www.philipsherburne.com/

Philip on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/194425 <http://www.myspace.com/194425+>


MIX:
Live @ Raum, Barcelona  (73min - 101MB)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/Philip_Sherburne_-_Live_@_Raum_-_Barcelona_July_2006.mp3

PERSON EVENT WAS CANCELLED BY THE COUNTY OF SANTA
CLARA, CALIFORNIA IN JULY OF 2000. MANY OF THE DETAILS
IN THE REPORT ARE FALSE: 1) WE ARE NOT COOLWORLD! THEY
ARE SLEEZE-BAGS, AND IT IS HARD TO HEAR US CALLED
THAT. 2) WE HAD NOTHING TO DO WITH THE EVENT THAT THE
NEWS REPORT STATES THERE WERE STABBINGS AT. IN FACT,
IT WAS LATER REPORTED THAT NO ONE WAS STABBED. 3)
COOLWORLD STOLE NNEARLY $100,000 FROM SILVER PEARL
RECORDS AND THE PUBLIC VIA TICKET SALES COLLECTED AND
FRAUD. THEY HAVE SINCE BEEN FOUND TO HAVE COMMITTED
CRIMINAL FRAUD AGAINST SILVER PEARL RECORDS, THE
PUBLIC AT LARGE, AND SEVERAL OTHER COMPANIES. 4) CIVIL
AND CRIMINAL CASES AGAINST COOLWORLD AND COOLWORLD'S
OWNER SASSON PARRY ARE ONGOING. 5) AFTER 6 YEARS OF
TRYING TO COLLECT THE MONEY THEY STOLE FROM SILVER
PEARL RECORDS, WE WERE FORCED TO DROP THE CASE SIMPLY
BECAUSE LEGAL FEES HAD SURPASSED ANY COLLECTABLE
ASSETS THEY HAVE/HAD.

NEVER FORGET THAT COOLWORLD'S INEPTNESS, FRAUDULENT
PRACTICES, AND BASIC TERRIBLE-NESS IS WHAT ENDED THE
GOOD-OLE-DAYS FOR RAVES IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Remember this?

There is a very technical yet fairly simple answer to
this...

1) Coolworld operated as a Corporation called CAN,
Inc.
2) CAN, inc failed to EVER pay taxes to the State of
California, and thus had their Corporate License
revoked in 1998.
3) Thhey continued to act as a Corporation. Thi in
itself in Criminal Fraud.
4) All contracts signed by CAN, Inc, including those
with the Santa Clara County Fairgrounds were null and
void, as CAN was not a Corporation, and therefore had
no right to enter into any legal or otherwise binding
agreements.
5) CAN, Inc knew they had their Corporate license
revoked, yet continued to operate under the moiker
CAN, Inc.
6) Sasson Parry, in a deposition to the County of
Santa Clara, stated that he knew the corporate license
had been revoked, and that the corporation was only
set up to disguise the fact that it was really a sole
proprietor business. Also Criminal Fraud.
7) Coolworld contracted with ticketmaster to receive
and administer all funds from ticket sales, and
distribute after their cut to the "sub-promoter." (Ask
Ron Reeser about this)
8) As crazy as this is, when we tried to rent the
Fairgrounds directly from the County, they told us we
HAD to suyb-lease through CAN, inc, as they had an
exclusive contract for any and all "all night dance
events." .... This is the craziest, because in theory,
CAN could not enter into any contracts, and thus I
should have been able to rent the Fairgrounds
directly. Unfortunately, CAN''s deceptive business
practice, and illegal behavior was not exposed un til
the discovery fase of our and other promoters
lawsuits.
9) We paid them $30000 DIRECTLY for the use of the
fairgrounds, and they never returned that money or the
money from ticket sales.

In essence, this whole affair brought so much public
attention on the Rave Scene, that no venue wanted to
get caught up in the legal BS, and thus... the end.

Thats about it... they are evil!

First of all, i'd like to thank Eric Spire for throwing my very first  party, 
Quest in late 1998, at the JJ Newberry store in Oakland (downstairs from  the 
Sweets Ballroom). The Quest parties were fantastic. Quest at Home Base was  
better than most other Home Base parties, and definitely a lot better than any  
Cool World party. Cool World sucked. When parties in general were really 
good,  sure, I had fun at some of their massives. But overall they had the big 
parties  that attracted the wrong crowd, and attracted way too many cops that 
were going  after this wrong crowd.
Cool World's later parties felt like giant sting operations. It felt like  
the raver kids were being offered up as bait to catch pill dealers. 
I've heard many times that Sasson has diplomatic immunity due to having a  
rich family from Iran. How much are people allowed to get away with if they have 
 immunity? It's not like we're buddy buddy with Iran. I feel bad seeing Quest 
 labeled a Cool World production, but I can see how the tv station would get  
confused.
Eric, I do miss your parties! 

-------------------------------1170653054--

> Cool World sucked. When parties in
> general were really 
> good,  sure, I had fun at some of their massives.
> But overall they had the big 
> parties  that attracted the wrong crowd, and
> attracted way too many cops that 
> were going  after this wrong crowd.
> Cool World's later parties felt like giant sting
> operations. 


In fact, i was offered a deal by the county to let
Quest happen, if I would do the following:
1) Pay for an extra 100 cops to be on site ($150K
upfront)
2) interact with the Santa Clara Narcotics Task Force,
teaching them what to wear and how to act (they were
going to have a "jail" setup on site, and expected to
make 1000 arrests)
3) End the party at midnight without notice (ie:
create a riot)
4) Pay for DUI checkpoints at all points of egress
(exit) from the event (another $25K)

THIS WAS UNACCEPTABLE TO ME!!!! I would never allow
our friends and family to be set up like that.

Coolworld however did make these concessions at the
Cow Palace and Fresno County Fairgrounds... thus all
the hassles....

Most people doing parties now comply with the rules
above to some degree or another... Civic Center....

I think it is disgusting to put your audience under
this type of surveillance, tactics, and monitoring...

Thus, I no longer produce large-scale events :(

E

I find it incredibly amusing that it is *you* calling *him* a "troll".

All he does is post quotes.
You on the other hand go out of your way to discredit the source of =20
these quotes for an unknown reason, and usually in an entirely =20
illogical manner just begging for a response.
I suppose in that, because I do sometimes respond to you I admit that =20=

I fall victim to your superior trolling skills.

Do you know what an ad-hominem attack is?
You might want to read this short guide to critical thinking:
http://skepdic.com/refuge/ctlessons.html

"One of the more common fallacies of relevance is the ad hominem, an =20
attack on the one making the argument rather than an attack on the =20
argument. One of the most frequent types of ad hominem attack is to =20
attack the person's motives rather than his evidence."

With that, kindly STFU.

> I find it incredibly amusing that it is *you* calling *him* a "troll".

> You on the other hand go out of your way to discredit the source of =20=

> these quotes for an unknown reason, and usually in an entirely =20
> illogical manner just begging for a response.
> I suppose in that, because I do sometimes respond to you I admit =20
> that I fall victim to your superior trolling skills.
>
> Do you know what an ad-hominem attack is?
> You might want to read this short guide to critical thinking:
> http://skepdic.com/refuge/ctlessons.html
>
> "One of the more common fallacies of relevance is the ad hominem, =20
> an attack on the one making the argument rather than an attack on =20
> the argument. One of the most frequent types of ad hominem attack =20
> is to attack the person's motives rather than his evidence."
>
> With that, kindly STFU.

On Feb 5, 2007, at 9:55 AM, Philip.X.Diaz wrote:
>
> and tony - IMHO, inspirational quotes are good.  cut it with the  
> gloom & doom gov'mint conspiracy crap.  it's old.

Yeah- "paranoid" is no way to live-
Fortunately the solution is rather simple :)
1) buy a couple guns and 20,000 rounds of ammunition
2) stop worrying
That way, whatever it is that you think is coming- foreign invasion,  
domestic riots, massive earthquakes etc- you can acknowledge the  
threat without having to live under its thumb every day.

> hi. welcome to the SF Raves mailing list!
>
> how about some on-topic discussions, people?

I can start one of those:

SFRaves' usefulness has passed, and I suggest we allow it to die a  
graceful death.

My argument?
The social and discussion constructs provided by a "mailing list"  
were surpassed back when the first "forum" was created- we're talking  
5+ years ago.
These days, with the myspace/tribe/friendster kinds of sites, forums  
have likewise now been surpassed.
Any new dynamic people with an interest in "raves" in SF is not going  
to end up here.
The only active discussion seems to be from about the 20 same people,

I vote for retiring SFR now while simply past it's prime, before it  
needs to be put on a ventilator.
The archives will live on as the fond memories they are.
Thoughts?

--
"Jupiter accepts your offer..."
AIM:IMFDUP

Subject: [sfraves] tipping for water?

ok, I have a question for everyone here.  Do you
normally tip when you get a water bottle at a club? 
What do you think?  What's the proper etiquette?  And
how much?  Sometimes I tip, and sometimes I don't, or
maybe I tip on the first one but not the second, but a
bartender got all weird with me this weekend when I
didn't.  

I've been told not to tip because the bartender's not
doing much work, they're just grabbing a bottle of
water and making change.  Also, it's not like there
was a water fountain or any free water (or way to
bring my own water in) where I was, so there's that
issue, but of course that's up to the manager, not the
bartender.  

Any thoughts?

Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?

--0-976773741-1170701588=:19321
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

T.I.P. = To Insure Promptness?

How long did you wait for the water? Were you greeted with a smile? Did they twist the cap off for you & offer ice? I think it's important to tip anybody that actually does something to earn it. Even the water if they went the extra mile for you. If not, where's their etiquette?

My grumpy-Monday .02 

Best,

Chuck

Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?

Consider this: a bartender makes the majority from
tips.  Sometimes those tips need to be split between
barbacks.

-r


On Mon, Feb 05, 2007 at 10:46:34AM -0800, Monikat wrote:

> didn't.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?

------=_Part_38915_17922144.1170702247773
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

you raise some valid points, but speaking as someone who's worked in the
service industry for a long time (not anymore thank god), the generally
accepted etiquite is simple:

tip a dollar. every time. for pretty much any drink. if you like the
bartender, the drink was particularily laborious, or you want to thank them
for hooking you up or making a stiff drink, tip more.

it's really not about how much work they're doing, it's just standard
practice.  really pouring a beer isn't much work either.  opening a bottle
of wine doesnt take much effort, but if you buy a $50 bottle, you're still
expected to tip %15 or more on it when the tab comes.

in regards to being "forced" to buy water, most places at a minimum have
good old Hetchhetchy (sp?) tap water flowing from the sinks, which is the
same water that would be coming from a water fountain.
If money is an issue, you could always refill your bottle or wash out and
refill an empty glass.  Most afterhours bars aren't ever going to put up a
water fountain.  They want to sell waters!  But that doesn't mean you're
forced to buy them all night.

as often get quoted in the service industry, "if you can't afford to tip,
maybe you just can't afford to go out."

another thing that always confuses me is when people don't tip cuz they
think the drink costs too much.  the bartenders don't set the prices, so
don't take your frustrations with pricing policy out on them.

tip a dollar. it's only a dollar, but those dollars add up to those people's
livings.  and trust me they do work hard.

there's my .02

----> Greg

Subject: RE: [sfraves] tipping for water?

Tipping for water at a place where they are serving alcohol is a "no". They 
make plenty of $$ at the bar on liquor (something like 1000 % markup) - if 
they sell liquor, water should be a courtesy for designated drivers at the 
VERY least. If they ONLY sell water, then you tip for it.

And I was a bartender for years, so this isn't coming from left field.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?

Tips are ALWAYS split between barbacks - thye tend to get a 1/3rd (or less) 
of the tip-out. But despite that, water should be a courtesy, at least a cup 
of it. A bottle of water may warrant a small tip, but no more than a $1 at 
most, and that's moreso if they do open it for you, provide you with a cup 
for it, etc.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?

On Feb 5, 2007, at 11:04 AM, Greg Bird wrote:

> another thing that always confuses me is when people don't tip cuz  
> they
> think the drink costs too much.  the bartenders don't set the  
> prices, so
> don't take your frustrations with pricing policy out on them.

Since I just posted that exact sentiment, I thought I would explain it.

There is no justification for overly-expensive simple drinks.
And simple drinks is what I drink- Gin + Tonic usually.
No special ingredients, no complicated preparation...

In my mind there is a "fair" maximum price for these simple drinks  
when I go out.
For a well drink it's about $6- for a premium drink it's about $8.
When they're cheaper I generally tip $2, but only up to those values.

It's not like food at different restaurants- a Beefeater+Tonic is the  
same no matter which bar I go to.  If some place thinks it can charge  
$9 because of its "ambience" or whatever, it can fuck off- and yep-  
it's the bartender who is going to bear the wrath of no tip.
And I don't feel bad about that at all- because it's their choice to  
work at such a place.

Living Room Lounge -> $9 Beefeater+Tonic -> No discount for doubles - 
 > $72 for 4 strong drinks = NO TIP.
Las Vegas -> 8 12oz bottles of Corona -> $56 = WTMF?!?! NO TIP!

--
"Jupiter accepts your offer..."
AIM:IMFDUP

Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?

being in the industry as well, I Think Greg put it well.  There would be one 
exception...if you are at some UG party with no ventilation, its 130 degrees 
all they have is water bottles at 5$.  I think in that scenario, the h20 is 
an absolute neccessity on the promoters behalf to ensure no body falls ill.

but, keep you peeps behind the counter be nice if they are to you, be nice, 
if they suck and they cop attitude, fuck em, but fuck em appropriately.---
if you go to a restaurant and the tab is 100$ and you feel the service is 
poor, dont be a dick and just leave 3$.  You do have to realize that as a 
waiter/bartender they have to tip out several others in that biz as well.  
At my restaurant i tip out almost 40% of my tips to hosts, bartenders, 
server assistants, food runners...appropriately so.  A lot of people dont 
realize that.
If you get a bottle of water at a party, I think it is up to you, your 
experience with that person, if you have purchased lots and tipped that 
bartender lots before, it really can go either way.

I dont think a bartender would *expect a dollar tip on a dollar bottle of 
water, but it is a very nice gesture if you can afford it.

that is my 25 percent....
Danny

>From: "Greg Bird" <bird415@gmail.com>
>To: Monikat <technoslut303@yahoo.com>
>CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?
>Date: Mon, 5 Feb 2007 11:04:07 -0800
>
>you raise some valid points, but speaking as someone who's worked in the
>service industry for a long time (not anymore thank god), the generally
>accepted etiquite is simple:
>
>tip a dollar. every time. for pretty much any drink. if you like the
>bartender, the drink was particularily laborious, or you want to thank them
>for hooking you up or making a stiff drink, tip more.
>
>it's really not about how much work they're doing, it's just standard
>practice.  really pouring a beer isn't much work either.  opening a bottle
>of wine doesnt take much effort, but if you buy a $50 bottle, you're still
>expected to tip %15 or more on it when the tab comes.
>
>in regards to being "forced" to buy water, most places at a minimum have
>good old Hetchhetchy (sp?) tap water flowing from the sinks, which is the
>same water that would be coming from a water fountain.
>If money is an issue, you could always refill your bottle or wash out and
>refill an empty glass.  Most afterhours bars aren't ever going to put up a
>water fountain.  They want to sell waters!  But that doesn't mean you're
>forced to buy them all night.
>
>as often get quoted in the service industry, "if you can't afford to tip,
>maybe you just can't afford to go out."
>
>another thing that always confuses me is when people don't tip cuz they
>think the drink costs too much.  the bartenders don't set the prices, so
>don't take your frustrations with pricing policy out on them.
>
>tip a dollar. it's only a dollar, but those dollars add up to those 
>people's
>livings.  and trust me they do work hard.
>
>there's my .02
>
>----> Greg
>
>
>
>
>

X-Originating-Email: [electrofunk138@hotmail.com]
X-Sender: electrofunk138@hotmail.com
In-Reply-To: <B2F5572B-0FCC-4C0D-ADCA-16A751FAA5ED@scosol.org>
From: "Van Mundegaarde" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
To: scosol@scosol.org, bird415@gmail.com
Cc: technoslut303@yahoo.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Mon, 05 Feb 2007 11:47:24 -0800
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 05 Feb 2007 19:47:27.0789 (UTC) FILETIME=[772315D0:01C7495E]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?

As someone who worked as a bartender, I can tell you, unless the bar-owner 
is a complete nazi, ALL bartenders have some wiggle room with drink pricing. 
A liter or Jim Beam (for example) costs the bar about $8 at most. They make 
about $5 per shot out of it. You get a SHIT TON of shots out of that liter. 
So unless the bartender is making each and every drink stiffer than 
fuck-all, they are making a shitload of money on each bottle.

Tipping should be commensurate with service. No matter how nice the place 
is, they are supposed to be providing you with a service, and most know that 
if they pour stiff, they get bigger tips. If they don't live by that credo, 
then they are money grubbing wankers. In that case, never tip more than $1 
per drink OR per round. If they are hooking you up though, always try and 
tip phat - the drinks will continue to stay stiff, and you'll most likely 
wind up with some free shots (at the least). The easiest way to insure you 
get stiff drinks from the get-go, is to tip heavy the 1st round and BE 
POLITE. Do not wave your $$ at the bartender no matter how busy they are and 
how bad you want the drink. If they ignore you completely, that's one thing 
-those people get stiffed on tips IMHO, but a bartender who takes care of 
you deserves to be taken care of. Nine times out of ten they will make sure 
you are well served if you hook them up on that crucial 1st round....




>From: Nathan Seven <scosol@scosol.org>
>To: "Greg Bird" <bird415@gmail.com>
>CC: Monikat <technoslut303@yahoo.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?
>Date: Mon, 5 Feb 2007 11:32:13 -0800

>On Feb 5, 2007, at 11:04 AM, Greg Bird wrote:
>
>>another thing that always confuses me is when people don't tip cuz  they
>>think the drink costs too much.  the bartenders don't set the  prices, so
>>don't take your frustrations with pricing policy out on them.
>
>Since I just posted that exact sentiment, I thought I would explain it.
>
>There is no justification for overly-expensive simple drinks.
>And simple drinks is what I drink- Gin + Tonic usually.
>No special ingredients, no complicated preparation...
>
>In my mind there is a "fair" maximum price for these simple drinks  when I 
>go out.
>For a well drink it's about $6- for a premium drink it's about $8.
>When they're cheaper I generally tip $2, but only up to those values.
>
>It's not like food at different restaurants- a Beefeater+Tonic is the  same 
>no matter which bar I go to.  If some place thinks it can charge  $9 
>because of its "ambience" or whatever, it can fuck off- and yep-  it's the 
>bartender who is going to bear the wrath of no tip.
>And I don't feel bad about that at all- because it's their choice to  work 
>at such a place.
>
>Living Room Lounge -> $9 Beefeater+Tonic -> No discount for doubles - > $72 
>for 4 strong drinks = NO TIP.
>Las Vegas -> 8 12oz bottles of Corona -> $56 = WTMF?!?! NO TIP!
>
>--
>"Jupiter accepts your offer..."

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Mon)

One man's troll is another man's hero I guess.=0A=0AIt is not an ad hominem=
 attack to point out the context of someone's words.  I'm merely posting th=
e context of these quotations of the day.  People say things in the context=
 of a story, or a debate, or an article.  When the words are removed from t=
he context they don't always appear to mean the same thing.=0A=0AWith repse=
ct to today's QOD, since there is absolutely no evidence presented (read th=
e whole article), it is easy to argue that any negative response to it is m=
erely ad hominem.  Where the fuck are these secret camps? Who operates them=
?  How does he know any of this?  Why should we believe him and why isn't h=
e dead?  He doesn't say.  There isn't any factual information here to argue=
 with at all.  FWIW, that's one of the most common tricks of the conspiracy=
 trade.  Anyone that attacks the author's credibility, evidence, or any asp=
ect of the theory is discounted as merely ad hominem.=0A=0ATaking today's Q=
OD as an example, out of context its hard to argue with it.  I consider mys=
elf to be a patriot, and in fact I've put my money where my mouth is in tha=
t regard.  Maybe some can argue with patriotism, but that's not my position=
.  But when you understand where this quote actually came from, a paranoid =
rant about secret detention camps, it seems to me to be a quite a bit less =
palatable.  =0A=0AAnd there is the not very subtle bit about blaming the vi=
ctims of such a system for their own situation as prisoners.  I don't accep=
t that notion at all, do you?  The quotation taken out of context doesn't i=
nclude this rather ugly idea.  =0A=0AI also linked to an article about the =
NEA being some sort of socialist homosexual conspiracy to convert our youth=
 written by the same author.  IMO this does shed additional light on his co=
re beliefs and frame of mind.  He doesn't like gay people apparently.  Why?=
  And what connects gay educational conspiracies and secret government dete=
ntion camps?  I think this is useful information about the author and his c=
redibility on both subjects.=0A=0AAs far as my motivation, personally I hav=
e just become fed up with the repetitive propagation of fear and hate on th=
is list.  These quotations, and the people behind them, have become more an=
d more outrageous from my perspective.  Maybe I just wasn't paying attentio=
n to them before.  =0A=0ASome of the people being quoted here in the QOD ha=
ve ideas and opinions that are I think are highly objectionable and I would=
 say arguably would be offensive to almost everyone on the list.  Its not j=
ust wacky conspiracy theory silliness being posted here.  I hope I've commu=
nicated that to someone out there.  Of course if I'm wrong and most of the =
people on the list support these sorts of beliefs I'd sure like to know tha=
t too.  =0A=0AIt worries me that the trully hateful ideas that lie behind s=
ome of these quotations remain hidden simply because these quotations are p=
resented out of context.  That's one of the ways people get seduced into th=
ese systems of hate and fear.  Arguably I'm blowing this out of proportion.=
  But I haven't tried to censor Deepfog or tell him to stop posting.  I hav=
e stated my opinions about his motives and I have pointed out where his quo=
tations come from.  =0A=0AApparently you don't appreciate my opinion.  You =
can't please everyone I guess.=0A=0ARegards,=0A=0APeter=0A=0A=0A----- Origi=

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Mon)

On Feb 5, 2007, at 12:53 PM, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

> It is not an ad hominem attack to point out the context of  
> someone's words.  I'm merely posting the context of these  
> quotations of the day.

No you're not- in either this instance or in general.  How quickly  
you forget your own words:
"Griffin, Devvy Kidd and Jeff Rense are deeply connected to the white  
power movement."
There is no purer example of an ad hominem attack.

> Taking today's QOD as an example, out of context its hard to argue  
> with it.

This quote was the preamble for the article, and conveys an accurate- 
as-intentioned-by-the-author idea that stands entirely on it's own.   
There is no additional context to remove it from.

> But when you understand where this quote actually came from, a  
> paranoid rant about secret detention camps, it seems to me to be a  
> quite a bit less palatable.

You read that entire article, and you thought it was mainly about  
detention camps?
It sounds like things need to be spelled out a little clearer for you:
http://www.geocities.com/anakonda_fi/

> IMO this does shed additional light on his core beliefs and frame  
> of mind.

> I think this is useful information about the author and his  
> credibility on both subjects.

> Some of the people being quoted here in the QOD have ideas and  
> opinions that are I think are highly objectionable and I would say  
> arguably would be offensive to almost everyone on the list.

> It worries me that the trully hateful ideas that lie behind some of  
> these quotations remain hidden simply because these quotations are  
> presented out of context.

I don't know how it can be made any clearer to you:

Person A makes claim X.
Person B makes an attack on person A.
Therefore A's claim is false.

The reason why an Ad Hominem (of any kind) is a fallacy is that the  
character, circumstances, or actions of a person do not (in most  
cases) have a bearing on the truth or falsity of the claim being made  
(or the quality of the argument being made).

--
"Jupiter accepts your offer..."

Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?

I never tip for water - there's entirely too much profit made from 
the water.  I don't think it's punishing the barkeep at all - they're 
PAID, tips are EXTRA.  If they provided the water for free, then I'd 
tip / donate.


sarilion

>maybe I tip on the first one but not the second, but a

>didn't.

>I can start one of those:
>
>SFRaves' usefulness has passed, and I suggest we allow it to die a
>graceful death.
>
>My argument?
>The social and discussion constructs provided by a "mailing list"
>were surpassed back when the first "forum" was created- we're talking
>5+ years ago.
>These days, with the myspace/tribe/friendster kinds of sites, forums
>have likewise now been surpassed.
>Any new dynamic people with an interest in "raves" in SF is not going
>to end up here.
>The only active discussion seems to be from about the 20 same people,

What evidence do you offer to support these claims?  In many cases, 
mailing lists provide useful information not found on forums.  I 
don't agree that forums have surpassed mailing lists, and social 
networking sites like myspace don't even come close to replacing / 
substituting for mailing lists.  If myspace was a better 
communication tool for Ravers in SF, SFR would truly be dead.  As 
such is not the case, new ravers in the area do join the list - case 
in point, Marc-O.


sarilion

>I vote for retiring SFR now while simply past it's prime, before it
>needs to be put on a ventilator.
>The archives will live on as the fond memories they are.
>Thoughts?
>

Hey All~

> on second thought, this (the late night debate idea) is kind of =20
> mean to think about this.   too late, already sent it off.  sorry.

C'mon deepfog/troll and others: lighten up! Having danced my ass off =20
at 'raves' all over the place since the late '80s, I hafta say that =20
this current DVD about the Detroit influence (Juan Atkins =3D =20
originator; Kevin Saunderson =3D elevator, and Derrick may =3D =
innovator) =20
is the best docu that I've seen on this phenom! Anyone else =20
experience it yet?

Will

Lodging in the world, the body is like a dream,
If one lives in peace, a day can be like a year.
Trying to sleep, I toss and turn on the worn out mat,
And pace around and around
In my tattered monk=E2=80=99s shawl.
The Master suggests I make my bed
Among the wind and bamboo,
And have a drink beside the waters of the rocky spring.
A nod of the head, and all worldly affairs seem wrong.
Laughing at myself,
I understand the wisdom of the Master.
=EF=BF=BC
=EF=BF=BC -- Su Shih 10

Turned from green to yellow

The triple world is narrow;

> Lodging in the world, the body is like a dream,
> If one lives in peace, a day can be like a year.
> Trying to sleep, I toss and turn on the worn out mat,
> And pace around and around
> In my tattered monk's shawl.
> The Master suggests I make my bed
> Among the wind and bamboo,
> And have a drink beside the waters of the rocky spring.
> A nod of the head, and all worldly affairs seem wrong.
> Laughing at myself,
> I understand the wisdom of the Master.
>
>  -- Su Shih 10

From: John B <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 5 Feb 2007 22:56:59 -0800
To: Ravi Pina <ravi@cow.org>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.752.2)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?

OTOH, this isn't some stinkhole state in the south (I tended bar, a  
few years in a row, in Daytona Beach for spring break, race week, and  
bike week, a while back.) where you can get away with paying your bar/ 
wait staff $2/hour under the assumption that they'll make wage once  
the tips are added in.  Bartenders and waiters here all make the same  
indexed-to-inflation automatically-increasing living wage that we  
voted into law a few years ago.  I think it's something a bit over $9/ 
hour as of this year.  Then tips are added on top of THAT.

I'm not entirely sure what stand to take.  I don't usually tip just  
to take a bottle of water out of the cooler and hand it to me, but I  
always do when it's a bottle of beer; which admittedly makes no sense  
at all when you stop and think about it.  It's just the ingrained  
habit to tip whenever alcohol's involved, regardless of the level or  
quality of service, I guess.


cya,
john


On Feb 5, 2007, at 10:54 AM, Ravi Pina wrote:

>
> Consider this: a bartender makes the majority from
> tips.  Sometimes those tips need to be split between
> barbacks.
>
> -r

All bartenders I know makes MINIMUM WAGE.

Yes, Minimum.  The bars would pay them less if they could get away with 
it.  UG venues pay $0 to bartenders so they are on 100% tips only.

Here's another tip:  Want free water?  Tip heavy when you order your 
drinks, in fact, Give the bartender a $20 when you order your first beer as 
a tip.  You can stiff the rest all night.  I can guarentee you'll get a few 
free shots and bottles water later on.

In-Reply-To: <139346.46378.qm@web32113.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
References: <139346.46378.qm@web32113.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?


Ok...  I've answered a few of these on this thread...  My favorite is "Over 
priced drinks"

Let's analize things for a minutes, since I work in this industry, actively:

PAYROLL:

Rule of thumb is that whatever the hourly wage for a staff member, the 
owner pays double for taxes, EDD, Workmans comp, etc etc.  So that Min wage 
worker costs $17/hr.   Let's say you have two bartenders and a 
barback.  $51/hr.

Got Security?  If you have Good security you're looking at $30/hr.  Let's 
say you have 3 guys.  $90/hr.

So, at $107/hr you have to sell 22 $5 drinks an hours just to pay staff.

UTILITIES:

Think that PG&E is free?  Oh hell no.  No clue what that costs but with 
club lights, DJ gear, not to mention that 10,000 watt sound system I 
imagine it's not pretty.

Got bathrooms?  Well then you gotta pay water and sewage.  Got an ice 
machine?  Oh ya...  this isn't free either.  Depending on usage, hours 
open, etc, it can get very costly.  Endup water bill in teh Carl years was 
over $5000/mo.  $60,000 a year just to have water at the club.

Garboge?  Oh ya, that ain't free either.  Gotta pay for the dumpster to get 
emptied at least once a week, maybe more.  Let's hope you sort and 
recycle.  Oh ya, that costs too.  Fortunatly you can usually get a latino 
witha  pickup to do it for you in exchange for teh recycleing 
money.  Probably talk them into sweeping the place too for the privilage fo 
sorting through club trash for those beer bottles and water bottles.

STOCK:

Yes, they get good rates, but they still have to pay.

RENT:  Does the bar own the building and property?  probably not.  Not many 
do.  Almost all of the are rented by the business owner.  That means you 
gotta pay your rent on top of everything.  One place I'm thinking of is a 
good $12,000/mo.  If you are open 3 days a week (thur-sat) you need to make 
$1000 on top of everything else, just for rent.

PERMITS:

Business licence, Alcohol Licence, Caberet licence, Live music permit, etc 
etc etc.  Those all add up to a large chunk of change.  Not sure now, but 
to have a DJ play CD's in the pre entertainment commision willie brown 
years was $15,000 a year.  I know there's a good 15-20 permits, licences, 
and such needed at a nightclub, and those fees are annual.

Tax?  Oh ya...  all those drinks, water bottles, and every time the 
bartender hits the till San Fran & the state of california are hitting you 
for sales tax.  Can't remember if they have an additional tax for 
resturaunts, but it's at least 8.5%.  So if they charge $5 for a cocktail 
they are only getting around $4.60 for that drink.

(Is anyone reminded of the Simpsons when they filmed the movie there?)


Summery....

If you have a REALLY good bar manager, you can get the cost down to 
28%.  That means that 28 cents on the dollar is paying for 
everything.  Most bars are in the 45-65% range.  I know one of the clubs 
I've worked with costs around $1500 a night just to unlock the door and 
staff it.  That means the bar need $1500 just to cover power and 
staff.  That's not getting into the permit factor.

Bars only make money on the bar.  Door is rarely bar, that goes to the 
promoter (if he's lucky).  If people are not spending at the bar, the bar 
isn't making money.

This is why your Long Island is $8.50

This is why you tip your bartender.

Everytime.

While your at it, tip the coatcheck too.  Those guys don't even get minimum 
wage, they are 100% tips.  However, most times your coatcheck fee goes 
straight to them.  I seen those guys work 8 hours and walk out with 
a  whopping $30.

I see you've been studying "Intellectual Defense for White Nationalists"  h=
ttp://www.nationalvanguard.org/story.php?id=3D6573=0AThe calling out of ad =
hominem attacks is a standard defense as you can see from the link. =0A=0AI=
 didn't think the article was "about" detention camps, I pointed out the bi=
t about detention camps as an example of an assertion made with out any fac=
tual basis.  If you study the article (which is about the predicted break u=
p of America) it is completely devoid of any facts.  It is all Mr. Evensen'=
s opinions about various things presented as if they were facts.  There are=
 no references, links or any evidence whatsoever offered for anything he sa=
ys in that article.  There is not a single piece of evidence offered about =
any of it.  Why? I guess the true believers already know its true right?=0A=
=0AThis is one of the standard tricks, making assertions without factual su=
pport of any sort.  Generally you want to start with something that is true=
, or almost true so the audience buys in.  Then you proceed to the bigger a=
nd bigger lies.  Once they've bought  to the initial "truth", they'll often=
 believe the lies too.  Evensen starts with the "Patriot's Preamble" to get=
 the buy in. Then he proceeds to argue that the nation is about to be swall=
owed in a revolution or civil war without even a single point of evidence e=
ver being presented.  (http://www.newswithviews.com/Evensen/greg8.htm)  Its=
 an old trick but it still works like a charm eh?=0A=0ASince no factual evi=
dence is presented which can be debated, any attack on the argument is imme=
diately discounted as mere baseless opinion.  Similarly questioning the cre=
dibility or expertise of an author is always called an ad hominem attack.  =
How does Evensen know about these supposed detention camps?  And if there i=
s a secret government conspiracy to incarcerate millions why hasn't he been=
 arrested or killed for exposing it?  These questions need to be answered b=
efore he has any credibility IMO.=0A=0AIf I even question his credibility b=
y merely pointing out that he holds other somewhat bizarre or nonsensical v=
iews, or is part of an organization that holds these views, I am accused of=
 an ad hominem attack.  Sorry it is up to Evensen to prove his credibility =
and present evidence for his assertions which of course he hasn't even atte=
mpted to do.  =0A=0AAs far as the links you've presented, I haven't finishe=
d reading the first article yet, but MacDonald is widely known.  I could go=
 into the scientific arguments against his analysis, but I doubt that would=
 convince you.  If I can reduce the argument presented on that webpage you =
linked to into a single sentence I'd say you think America is about to be o=
verrun by Mexicans causing the nation to descend into civil war and its the=
 Jew's fault.  Would that be a correct interpretation?  Feel free to correc=
t me if I am wrong there.  Also, I'd like to say that you should be careful=
 what you wish for because it might actually happen. =0A=0AFinally, as far =
as my assertions about the associations of Devvy Kidd, Jeff Rense, et al wh=
ich you discount as ad hominem, I am merely reporting the facts of who list=
ens to them and who appears on their programs.  You conveniently omitted th=
e link I posted to Vanguard news as an example.  Anyone can do the Google s=
earches I did and see who is listening to these people and who appears on t=
heir programs.  You call that ad hominem, but since it is all verifiable by=
 Google searches I'd say it is just reality.  Sometimes the company you kee=
p and the ideas you hold do reflect on your character and your credibility.=

-troy

> order your first beer as

> guarentee you'll get a few

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Mon)

I'm sure the list's patience has faded at the same rate as mine has,  
so I'm not going to respond to this- but I'll close with this thought:

It's a very useful skill in my opinion, being able to wade through a  
lot of shit but still pick up the gold nuggets.

Wholly dismissing pieces of work because you disagree with portions  
of them, or because you disagree with other works by the same author-  
in the end will only rob you of knowledge.

Examples abound- the Bible, the Qur'an- I personally view them as no  
evidence full of shit tales of fantasy.  But that doesn't mean that  
there aren't still important lessons to be pulled from them.

Similarly- it doesn't mean that someone who *does* believe in the  
Bible suddenly has "no credibility" about anything else with me.   
Jesse Lee Peterson and I disagree almost 100% in our views on  
religion, but I agree with a lot of his views on why the black  
community is in the shape it is today.
( http://www.bondinfo.org/ if you're interested )
Once you get past your "horror" at what ABC thinks about XYZ, only  
then can you really critically think about what ABC thinks about DEF.

--
"Jupiter accepts your offer..."
AIM:IMFDUP



On Feb 6, 2007, at 8:48 AM, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

> I see you've been studying "Intellectual Defense for White  
> Nationalists"  http://www.nationalvanguard.org/story.php?id=6573
> The calling out of ad hominem attacks is a standard defense as you  
> can see from the link.
>
> I didn't think the article was "about" detention camps, I pointed  
> out the bit about detention camps as an example of an assertion  
> made with out any factual basis.  If you study the article (which  
> is about the predicted break up of America) it is completely devoid  
> of any facts.  It is all Mr. Evensen's opinions about various  
> things presented as if they were facts.  There are no references,  
> links or any evidence whatsoever offered for anything he says in  
> that article.  There is not a single piece of evidence offered  
> about any of it.  Why? I guess the true believers already know its  
> true right?
>
> This is one of the standard tricks, making assertions without  
> factual support of any sort.  Generally you want to start with  
> something that is true, or almost true so the audience buys in.   
> Then you proceed to the bigger and bigger lies.  Once they've  
> bought  to the initial "truth", they'll often believe the lies  
> too.  Evensen starts with the "Patriot's Preamble" to get the buy  
> in. Then he proceeds to argue that the nation is about to be  
> swallowed in a revolution or civil war without even a single point  
> of evidence ever being presented.  (http://www.newswithviews.com/ 
> Evensen/greg8.htm)  Its an old trick but it still works like a  
> charm eh?
>
> Since no factual evidence is presented which can be debated, any  
> attack on the argument is immediately discounted as mere baseless  
> opinion.  Similarly questioning the credibility or expertise of an  
> author is always called an ad hominem attack.  How does Evensen  
> know about these supposed detention camps?  And if there is a  
> secret government conspiracy to incarcerate millions why hasn't he  
> been arrested or killed for exposing it?  These questions need to  
> be answered before he has any credibility IMO.
>
> If I even question his credibility by merely pointing out that he  
> holds other somewhat bizarre or nonsensical views, or is part of an  
> organization that holds these views, I am accused of an ad hominem  
> attack.  Sorry it is up to Evensen to prove his credibility and  
> present evidence for his assertions which of course he hasn't even  
> attempted to do.
>
> As far as the links you've presented, I haven't finished reading  
> the first article yet, but MacDonald is widely known.  I could go  
> into the scientific arguments against his analysis, but I doubt  
> that would convince you.  If I can reduce the argument presented on  
> that webpage you linked to into a single sentence I'd say you think  
> America is about to be overrun by Mexicans causing the nation to  
> descend into civil war and its the Jew's fault.  Would that be a  
> correct interpretation?  Feel free to correct me if I am wrong  
> there.  Also, I'd like to say that you should be careful what you  
> wish for because it might actually happen.
>
> Finally, as far as my assertions about the associations of Devvy  
> Kidd, Jeff Rense, et al which you discount as ad hominem, I am  
> merely reporting the facts of who listens to them and who appears  
> on their programs.  You conveniently omitted the link I posted to  
> Vanguard news as an example.  Anyone can do the Google searches I  
> did and see who is listening to these people and who appears on  
> their programs.  You call that ad hominem, but since it is all  
> verifiable by Google searches I'd say it is just reality.   
> Sometimes the company you keep and the ideas you hold do reflect on  
> your character and your credibility.
>
> Regards,
>
> Peter
>
>
>

>> It is not an ad hominem attack to point out the context of
>> someone's words.  I'm merely posting the context of these
>> quotations of the day.
>
> No you're not- in either this instance or in general.  How quickly
> you forget your own words:
> "Griffin, Devvy Kidd and Jeff Rense are deeply connected to the white
> power movement."
> There is no purer example of an ad hominem attack.
>
>> Taking today's QOD as an example, out of context its hard to argue
>> with it.
>
> This quote was the preamble for the article, and conveys an accurate-
> as-intentioned-by-the-author idea that stands entirely on it's own.
> There is no additional context to remove it from.
>
>> But when you understand where this quote actually came from, a
>> paranoid rant about secret detention camps, it seems to me to be a
>> quite a bit less palatable.
>
> You read that entire article, and you thought it was mainly about
> detention camps?
> It sounds like things need to be spelled out a little clearer for you:
> http://www.geocities.com/anakonda_fi/
>
>> IMO this does shed additional light on his core beliefs and frame
>> of mind.
>
>> I think this is useful information about the author and his
>> credibility on both subjects.
>
>> Some of the people being quoted here in the QOD have ideas and
>> opinions that are I think are highly objectionable and I would say
>> arguably would be offensive to almost everyone on the list.
>
>> It worries me that the trully hateful ideas that lie behind some of
>> these quotations remain hidden simply because these quotations are
>> presented out of context.
>
> I don't know how it can be made any clearer to you:
>
> Person A makes claim X.
> Person B makes an attack on person A.
> Therefore A's claim is false.
>
> The reason why an Ad Hominem (of any kind) is a fallacy is that the
> character, circumstances, or actions of a person do not (in most
> cases) have a bearing on the truth or falsity of the claim being made
> (or the quality of the argument being made).

On Feb 6, 2007, at 8:43 AM, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

> 20,000 rounds of ammunition won't
> be nearly enough to ensure your safety.
>
> I shoot 100-200 rounds a
> week (10-20 targets) just to keep
> my skills marginally close to what they used to be.  That's as much  
> as 10,000 rounds a year just for
> practice.  And that's considered to be too low by many people.  I  
> can say my skills have definitely declined without more significant  
> practice time.
>
> FWIW Olympic marksmen will shoot 1,000 rounds a week in practice or  
> sometimes even more, and I know sports shooters (aka hunters) that  
> fire at least several hundred rounds a week in practice.
>
> If you
> are going to advocate taking up arms, at least educate yourself first.
> It actually takes practice to employ a firearm effectively.  To  
> even be a half  decent shot you are going to have to shoot at least  
> ten targets a week almost every week.   And your skills decline  
> rapidly without practice.
>
> And of course if you haven't practiced at all the odds of your  
> hitting a target at distance with a "lucky shot" are slim at best.   
> That only happens in movies.  Head over to a rifle range and try  
> it; you'll see what I mean.
>
> Peter
>
>
>
> P.S.  That's right I'm a gun owning Buddhist.  Beware.

On Feb 5, 2007, at 5:36 PM, Sarilion wrote:

>
> What evidence do you offer to support these claims?  In many cases,  
> mailing lists provide useful information not found on forums.  I  
> don't agree that forums have surpassed mailing lists, and social  
> networking sites like myspace don't even come close to replacing /  
> substituting for mailing lists.  If myspace was a better  
> communication tool for Ravers in SF, SFR would truly be dead.  As  
> such is not the case, new ravers in the area do join the list -  
> case in point, Marc-O.

This is what I wrote:

>> The social and discussion constructs provided by a "mailing list"
>> were surpassed back when the first "forum" was created-

I don't see this as a "claim" and more a simple fact- a forum just  
provides more of a social construct, and more discussion oriented  
tools than a mailing list can.
Searching, avatars, persistence of information- etc.
The specific social-network sites of course take that side beyond  
forums.
I'm not saying that SFR should "turn in to a forum" or anything.

But I dunno- even on Bayraves.com there's a thread about it becoming  
dead, and I look and there's still a post every minute or so-
8,000 users.
75 users posting in the last 15 minutes.
The SFR webpage has been broken and outdated for at least 5 years:  
http://hyperreal.org/raves/sf/

I dunno- it doesn't affect me either way, but I thought I'd raise the  
"pull the plug" thought and just see if it went anywhere.
Which it hasn't, so whatever.

>

> more of a social construct, and more discussion oriented tools than a mailing 
> list can.
> Searching, avatars, persistence of information- etc.
> The specific social-network sites of course take that side beyond forums.
> I'm not saying that SFR should "turn in to a forum" or anything.
>
> But I dunno- even on Bayraves.com there's a thread about it becoming dead, 
> and I look and there's still a post every minute or so-
> 8,000 users.
> 75 users posting in the last 15 minutes.
> The SFR webpage has been broken and outdated for at least 5 years: 
> http://hyperreal.org/raves/sf/
>
> I dunno- it doesn't affect me either way, but I thought I'd raise the "pull 
> the plug" thought and just see if it went anywhere.
> Which it hasn't, so whatever.
>
> --
> "Jupiter accepts your offer..."
> AIM:IMFDUP
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?

At 05:39 AM 2/6/2007, Shatter wrote:

>All bartenders I know makes MINIMUM WAGE.
>
>Yes, Minimum.  The bars would pay them less if they could get away with it.  UG venues pay $0 to bartenders so they are on 100% tips only.
>
>Here's another tip:  Want free water?  Tip heavy when you order your drinks, in fact, Give the bartender a $20 when you order your first beer as a tip.  You can stiff the rest all night.  I can guarentee you'll get a few free shots and bottles water later on.
>

That's true.  I've had many, many years experience with developing relationships with bartenders.  Yes, relationships.  When I go to a new club I focus on one person, usually the bartender who gets to me first...but my selection might be based on other things like attraction :-)  I tip heavily for the first round and fairly, generously from then on.

But it's not just the money.  I treat my bartenders with respect, as friends over time.  And the treatment is usually returned.  I've been dancing at clubs (as well as ugs) for over 20 years in this town.  I've known some bartenders all this time -- believe it.  I've received free drinks.  Actually more than I pay for.  Stiff, stiff drinks.  And generally free water. 

For personal health reasons I haven't been going out as much these days.  Went the End Up for the first time in years a few weeks ago.  Used to spin there and had some very wild nites in the early nineties at Decadence and Uranus.  In those days there was a punk dyke tender who always served us and poured danger level drinks.  Cause of much drama :-)  Well when we went back recently she was still there and our reunion was like that with the most cherished friends.  She IS a much-loved friend.

And that's my point.  Bartenders are people folks.  Make some friends.  Don't treat them like servants.

Apollo  



<http://www.asambleapopulardeoaxaca.com/>http://www.asambleapopulardeoaxaca.com/ 

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo 

Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k 
                
House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

The wise man is a happy child."
-Arnaud Desjardins

    The Twilight Laser Outpost <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

MIME-Version: 1.0

X-Spam-Rating: localhost.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] sfraves relevence and calendar...

Eric, SFR has gone through a few iterations over the past 6-7 years, none 
that I could say were successful in the long run. Around '99-2000? we 
added member profiles. It kinda worked, some people used it for a while. I 
have no idea where that damn thing is anymore.

Then shortly after that we added this "package" dubbed star-raves. 
Someone from SFR developed it, can't remember exactly who (Colmar?).

It was essentially a turn-key calendar/events/member/profiles web-based 
suite. But it was developed using Zope's application framework, problem 
became, very few people were familiar with it. It was kinda useful for a 
few years, but eventually broke and died a horrible death and nobody ever 
came to it's rescue.

A part of me is bummed that collectively we have a pretty high IQ here, 
and enough designers and developers to shake a stick a stick at. 
Yet we can't maintain our own web site, or make it usable. Even though 
we're old crusty crab people, we could still have a pimp-home on the 'net, 
I would guess.

A lot of the problems came in people not following through (flaking), the 
rest of problems came in having people agree *what* to do (design by 
committee).

Another part of me just says leave what is there as a snapshot into a 
nostalgic past of the way the scene was.

One issue (as far as the list specifically) is I know Brian is particular 
about the security of the list, meaning, it's subscription based format 
keeps random people from googling us and reading our discussions. All the 
other hyperreal lists (to my knowledge) are ezmlm email-based lists. I 
particulary like being able to be candid on here, but I also like PHP 
forums when is comes to browsing threads when I feel like it.

I'm not opposed to a revamp, I doubt Brian is either. But everytime this 
comes up, a group comes together and nothing ever really happens in the 
end.

So it's up to you guys, if this is worth continuing discussing let's 
keep talking.

-terry

------------------------------------------
terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org
SFRaves moderator | http://www.sfraves.org

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <20070206212113.53422.qmail@web36807.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Checker-Version: SpamAssassin 3.0.3 (2005-04-27) on bit.tuplemovers.net
X-Spam-Level: 
X-Spam-Status: No, score=-5.9 required=5.0 tests=ALL_TRUSTED,BAYES_00 
	autolearn=ham version=3.0.3
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] sfraves relevence and calendar...

On Tue, Feb 06, 2007 at 01:21:13PM -0800, Eric Spire wrote:
>Why not go php with a mailing list? meaning, have a
>PHP based discussion board that also mailed out like

I'm not aware of such an animal. AFAIK, the bulletin boards
don't email you (or have the feature to do so) when messages
are posted to them.

>we currently do? This way you could subscribe as a php
>discussion member or as an email member and post and
>view as you personally desired... or for that matter,
>you could sign up for both, like many forums allow.
>The php forum software is readily available, seemingly
>secure, and I imagine nearly effortless to admin...

eek! Anything that requires php[1] makes it easier to compromise
a system. sfraves probably isn't a high security environment
where we'd really care (clean up after compromise is always
annoying, but it's not like we have proprietary data we're
trying to protect), so this doesn't mean we shouldn't use
it. It just means that we shouldn't use security as a reason
to use it, since it will increase the vulnerability[1] of the
system hosting the php based bulletin board.

[1] lots more reading for anyone interested here:
http://www.google.com/search?q=php%20vulnerability

-- 
Holt Sorenson
hso@hsomusic.com
http://www.hsomusic.com/

To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?


As I was reading I was thinking of Debbie Greene.  She's been bartending at 
The Endup since it first opened in 1972.  Best bartender in the South of 
Market.  Hands down.

Something else peopel seem to forget on this thread...

You pay the BAR for your drink, you pay your BARTENDER to make it.

I mean, if you have a really great dinner, you tip teh waiter really 
well.  Why?  They didn't make it.  They walked 30 feet and dropped it on 
your table.  The Chef made it.  Do you tip him?  (I have, I've walked back 
to a kitchen and dropped cash in the guys pocket for amazing food, 
typically sushi)

At 02:20 PM 2/6/2007, Apollo wrote:
>In those days there was a punk dyke tender who always served us and poured 
>danger level drinks.  Cause of much drama :-)  Well when we went back 
>recently she was still there and our reunion was like that with the most 
>cherished friends.  She IS a much-loved friend.


Shatter

From: Eric Spire <ericspire@yahoo.com>
