X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?

The following is true, I SWEAR...

The cocktail waitresses at the big clubs in town, not
the casino floor ones, make well over $1000 per
shift... although they are nearly required to flirt
with and entertain their Table Service guests, as well
as go out and promote on their nights off. Basically
these women have a 5 day a week job, 3 in the club, 2
promoting, and usually make about $4000 / week. YES,
THAT IS $16,000 a month to pour drinks at tables and
make dorky men feel as though they have a chance with
the waitress...

It is obviously a coveted job... but I do not know how
they sleep with themselves at night... or during the
day I guess... As you might imagine, many of them
perform "other" duties to get the positions, and are
often asked by upper management to go out with the
high-rollers after their shifts. I'm not saying
they're hookers... but they are often asked to at
least kinda act like they are.... I can't imagine
trading in my soul for the money. Not to mention the
fact that as soon as they get a few years older, their
"careers" are over. They actually have weigh-ins for
them!!!!! ... and just about the only thing thhey are
allowed to take time off for is cosmetic surgery,
which they are "encouraged" to have in order to get
and/or keep their jobs.

It's gross!

and for the record.... just in case you thought my
Fiance is one of these women... she most certainly is
not! She is a hard working bartender, which is a
different "class" of employee. Not only is she a
college graduate, she owns two homes, is getting her
masters degree, and only has to work 2 nights a week
to keep herself afloat. She is one of the few ppeople
using the ridiculous money service workers make in
this town to better herself.... most just blow it on
purses...lol

E

Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?

On Feb 6, 2007, at 3:39 PM, Shatter wrote:

> You pay the BAR for your drink, you pay your BARTENDER to make it.
>
> I mean, if you have a really great dinner, you tip teh waiter  
> really well.  Why?  They didn't make it.  They walked 30 feet and  
> dropped it on your table.  The Chef made it.  Do you tip him

I guess I see it differently.
Any tip I give is for service.
Both at a bar, and a restaurant.

Your bar analogy is right on.
Did the bartender address me in the proper order for when I got there?
Did he/she make the drink correctly and in the right proportions?
Does my glass have some crap on it that they didn't notice?
Is my change returned as promptly as can be expected?
That is the "service" involved there- and all of it determines what  
tip I give.

At a restaurant it's no different- I'm paying the price of the dish  
for the chef's abilities.
I don't know why you think it would be different at a restaurant.
The tip is for the service from the waiter.
Did my bread arrive promptly?
Is my plate and silverware clean?
Do you have knowledgeable opinions on the food, specials, and wine  
selections?
Do you keep an eye on the table to see if anything is getting low?
Etc etc.

Maybe I'm a weirdo here...

--
"Jupiter accepts your offer..."
AIM:IMFDUP

Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?

Yes Im in vegas...

And yes, the service woorkers union is powerful on
SOME properties. Wynn, The Venetian, and several
others are Union Free....

and... The high-end clubs sign at-will contracts with
their employees, allowing them to hire and fire on a
whim. Many properties that do have union support get
aruond it in the clubs by hiring "models" to serve
drinks... which means your a bartender or cocktail
waitress who is required to maintain a certain
appearance.

Most of the casino floor servers/bartenders are under
the service workers union, but those jobs are mostly
for the 40+ yr old peeps, and all men in general. I
only know of maybe 4-6 men who have bartending jobs in
clubs, and there are no cocktail waiters.


E

>If you are laying down a grand for table/bottle service, you better have a hot
>waitress flirting with you.
>
>There are tens of thousands of strippers who have to go through much worse.
>At least the high-end waitresses keep their clothes on.

>-troy

>On Tue, Feb 06, 2007 at 03:51:32PM -0800, Eric Spire wrote:
> > The following is true, I SWEAR...
> >
> > The cocktail waitresses at the big clubs in town, not
> > the casino floor ones, make well over $1000 per
> > shift... although they are nearly required to flirt
> > with and entertain their Table Service guests, as well
> > as go out and promote on their nights off. Basically
> > these women have a 5 day a week job, 3 in the club, 2
> > promoting, and usually make about $4000 / week. YES,
> > THAT IS $16,000 a month to pour drinks at tables and
> > make dorky men feel as though they have a chance with
> > the waitress...
> >
> > It is obviously a coveted job... but I do not know how
> > they sleep with themselves at night... or during the
> > day I guess... As you might imagine, many of them
> > perform "other" duties to get the positions, and are
> > often asked by upper management to go out with the
> > high-rollers after their shifts. I'm not saying
> > they're hookers... but they are often asked to at
> > least kinda act like they are.... I can't imagine
> > trading in my soul for the money. Not to mention the
> > fact that as soon as they get a few years older, their
> > "careers" are over. They actually have weigh-ins for
> > them!!!!! ... and just about the only thing thhey are
> > allowed to take time off for is cosmetic surgery,
> > which they are "encouraged" to have in order to get
> > and/or keep their jobs.
> >
> > It's gross!
> >
> > and for the record.... just in case you thought my
> > Fiance is one of these women... she most certainly is
> > not! She is a hard working bartender, which is a
> > different "class" of employee. Not only is she a
> > college graduate, she owns two homes, is getting her
> > masters degree, and only has to work 2 nights a week
> > to keep herself afloat. She is one of the few ppeople
> > using the ridiculous money service workers make in

I'm thinking that if somebody held you to the criteria you seem to hold 
others, you'd be quite offended.

Its' a fucking drink.  There's a signifigant statitsical percentage that 
with increase quantiy he likelihood of droppage.  Also, setting it down and 
forgetting about it.

As for the food, do you tip the same at Mels as you do as some places 
charging $25 for a chirp cocktail?  Do that waiter work any harder?

Bartender == Chef
Barback == Waiter

That's the parellel.


At 04:14 PM 2/6/2007, Nathan Seven wrote:
>On Feb 6, 2007, at 3:39 PM, Shatter wrote:
>
>>You pay the BAR for your drink, you pay your BARTENDER to make it.
>>
>>I mean, if you have a really great dinner, you tip teh waiter
>>really well.  Why?  They didn't make it.  They walked 30 feet and
>>dropped it on your table.  The Chef made it.  Do you tip him
>
>I guess I see it differently.
>Any tip I give is for service.
>Both at a bar, and a restaurant.
>
>Your bar analogy is right on.
>Did the bartender address me in the proper order for when I got there?
>Did he/she make the drink correctly and in the right proportions?
>Does my glass have some crap on it that they didn't notice?
>Is my change returned as promptly as can be expected?
>That is the "service" involved there- and all of it determines what
>tip I give.
>
>At a restaurant it's no different- I'm paying the price of the dish
>for the chef's abilities.
>I don't know why you think it would be different at a restaurant.
>The tip is for the service from the waiter.
>Did my bread arrive promptly?
>Is my plate and silverware clean?
>Do you have knowledgeable opinions on the food, specials, and wine
>selections?
>Do you keep an eye on the table to see if anything is getting low?
>Etc etc.
>
>Maybe I'm a weirdo here...
>
>--
>"Jupiter accepts your offer..."
>AIM:IMFDUP

Subject: [sfraves] New Liquid Mix [Pinkko - Survivor]

------=_Part_11601_30906925.1170811185129
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed

Content-Disposition: inline

This mix is the tale of my first year in San Francisco, and how I somehow
managed to pull myself up from the gutter with a lot of help from my boo. In
that respect it's really a love letter to my girlfriend, and it represents
the triumph of love over sometimes incredible circumstances. It works on a
lot of different levels.

Running time: 1 hour, 1 minute, 50 seconds.

Here's the tracklist:
1) Carlito - Diffusion Room - Creative Source
2) Lenny Fontana - Spread Love (Nu:Tone Remix) - Hospital
3) Jenna G - In Love - Bingo Beats
4) Utah Jazz - Runaway - Liquid V
5) Unknown - Unknown - Liquid V
6) Chino - Syriana - Renegade
7) Unkown - Unkown - Liquid V
8) Phobia - Quartet - Renegade
9) TK - Never Never - Liquid V
10) Sketch and Code feat Kim Nile - Evolution - Emotif
11) Jenna G - Pleasure Ride - Bingo Beats
12) Sketch and Code - Whatever - Emotif
13) Logistics - Girl from Mars - Hospital
14) Craggz & Parallel Forces - Keep Me Real - Valve
15) Danny Byrd - Dog Hill - Hospital
16) Solid State - Just a Vision (Marcus Intalex & St. Files Remix) -
Renegade
17) High Contrast - Global Love (Calibre Remix) - Hospital
18) Phobia - Sun Rising - Renegade
19) Lefunken feat Mina - Stand Up (Makoto Remix) - Bingo Beats
20) Artificial Intelligence vs D-Bridge - Better Days - Liquid V
21) Kubiks & Lomax - Edge City - Liquid V
22) Sonic - Desert Winds - Space
23) Logistics - Front to Back - Innerground
24) Perfect Combination - What Will it Take - Freeform
25) D-Bridge - China Blue - Liquid V
26) Kontrol & OB1 - Can't Have You - Bingo Beats
27) Craggz & Parallel Forces - Fizzy Piglets - Whitelabel
28) SUV feat Tali - Do You Remember Me Remix - Whitelabel
29) Destiny's Child - Survivor (DnB Remix) - Whitelabel
30) Basic Operations - Southern Lights - Renegade

This is the first mix I've ever put out for public consumption, please let
me know what you think. :-)

>From: "Alex Laughlin" <ealaughlin@gmail.com>

>Subject: [sfraves] New Liquid Mix [Pinkko - Survivor]
>Date: Tue, 6 Feb 2007 17:19:45 -0800

>This mix is the tale of my first year in San Francisco, and how I somehow
>managed to pull myself up from the gutter with a lot of help from my boo. 
>In
>that respect it's really a love letter to my girlfriend, and it represents
>the triumph of love over sometimes incredible circumstances. It works on a
>lot of different levels.
>
>Running time: 1 hour, 1 minute, 50 seconds.
>
>Here's the tracklist:
>1) Carlito - Diffusion Room - Creative Source
>2) Lenny Fontana - Spread Love (Nu:Tone Remix) - Hospital
>3) Jenna G - In Love - Bingo Beats

>29) Destiny's Child - Survivor (DnB Remix) - Whitelabel
>30) Basic Operations - Southern Lights - Renegade

>This is the first mix I've ever put out for public consumption, please let
>me know what you think. :-)

>
> It's a very useful skill in my opinion, being able to wade through a
> lot of shit but still pick up the gold nuggets.
>
> Wholly dismissing pieces of work because you disagree with portions
> of them, or because you disagree with other works by the same author-
> in the end will only rob you of knowledge.
>
> Examples abound- the Bible, the Qur'an- I personally view them as no
> evidence full of shit tales of fantasy.  But that doesn't mean that
> there aren't still important lessons to be pulled from them.

> community is in the shape it is today.

> On Feb 6, 2007, at 8:48 AM, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>
>> I see you've been studying "Intellectual Defense for White
>> Nationalists"  http://www.nationalvanguard.org/story.php?id=6573
>> The calling out of ad hominem attacks is a standard defense as you
>> can see from the link.
>>
>> I didn't think the article was "about" detention camps, I pointed
>> out the bit about detention camps as an example of an assertion
>> made with out any factual basis.  If you study the article (which
>> is about the predicted break up of America) it is completely devoid
>> of any facts.  It is all Mr. Evensen's opinions about various
>> things presented as if they were facts.  There are no references,
>> links or any evidence whatsoever offered for anything he says in
>> that article.  There is not a single piece of evidence offered
>> about any of it.  Why? I guess the true believers already know its
>> true right?
>>
>> This is one of the standard tricks, making assertions without
>> factual support of any sort.  Generally you want to start with
>> something that is true, or almost true so the audience buys in.
>> Then you proceed to the bigger and bigger lies.  Once they've
>> bought  to the initial "truth", they'll often believe the lies
>> too.  Evensen starts with the "Patriot's Preamble" to get the buy
>> in. Then he proceeds to argue that the nation is about to be
>> swallowed in a revolution or civil war without even a single point
>> of evidence ever being presented.  (http://www.newswithviews.com/
>> Evensen/greg8.htm)  Its an old trick but it still works like a
>> charm eh?
>>
>> Since no factual evidence is presented which can be debated, any
>> attack on the argument is immediately discounted as mere baseless
>> opinion.  Similarly questioning the credibility or expertise of an
>> author is always called an ad hominem attack.  How does Evensen
>> know about these supposed detention camps?  And if there is a
>> secret government conspiracy to incarcerate millions why hasn't he
>> been arrested or killed for exposing it?  These questions need to
>> be answered before he has any credibility IMO.
>>
>> If I even question his credibility by merely pointing out that he
>> holds other somewhat bizarre or nonsensical views, or is part of an
>> organization that holds these views, I am accused of an ad hominem
>> attack.  Sorry it is up to Evensen to prove his credibility and
>> present evidence for his assertions which of course he hasn't even
>> attempted to do.
>>
>> As far as the links you've presented, I haven't finished reading
>> the first article yet, but MacDonald is widely known.  I could go
>> into the scientific arguments against his analysis, but I doubt
>> that would convince you.  If I can reduce the argument presented on
>> that webpage you linked to into a single sentence I'd say you think
>> America is about to be overrun by Mexicans causing the nation to
>> descend into civil war and its the Jew's fault.  Would that be a
>> correct interpretation?  Feel free to correct me if I am wrong
>> there.  Also, I'd like to say that you should be careful what you
>> wish for because it might actually happen.
>>
>> Finally, as far as my assertions about the associations of Devvy
>> Kidd, Jeff Rense, et al which you discount as ad hominem, I am
>> merely reporting the facts of who listens to them and who appears
>> on their programs.  You conveniently omitted the link I posted to
>> Vanguard news as an example.  Anyone can do the Google searches I
>> did and see who is listening to these people and who appears on
>> their programs.  You call that ad hominem, but since it is all
>> verifiable by Google searches I'd say it is just reality.
>> Sometimes the company you keep and the ideas you hold do reflect on
>> your character and your credibility.
>>
>> Regards,
>>
>> Peter

>>
>> I don't know how it can be made any clearer to you:
>>
>> Person A makes claim X.
>> Person B makes an attack on person A.
>> Therefore A's claim is false.
>>
>> The reason why an Ad Hominem (of any kind) is a fallacy is that the
>> character, circumstances, or actions of a person do not (in most
>> cases) have a bearing on the truth or falsity of the claim being made
>> (or the quality of the argument being made).

>drinks, in fact, Give the bartender a $20 when you order your first

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Mon)

are you talking about taking aim, with sights, and firing, or just 
wildly shooting from the hip?

I've prolly shot less than 500 rounds in my LIFE, but I can hit 
reasonably close to target with proper aim.  I'm talking about 
shooting a rifle, from a stationary mount, at a stationary target.


sarilion

At 08:43 AM 2/6/2007, you wrote:
>   I shoot 100-200 rounds a week (10-20 targets) just to keep my 
> skills marginally close to what they used to be.  That's as much as 
> 10,000 rounds a year just for practice.  And that's considered to 
> be too low by many people.  I can say my skills have definitely 
> declined without more significant practice time.  FWIW Olympic 
> marksmen will shoot 1,000 rounds a week in practice or sometimes 
> even more, and I know sports shooters (aka hunters) that fire at 
> least several hundred rounds a week in practice. If you are going 
> to advocate taking up arms, at least educate yourself first. It 
> actually takes practice to employ a firearm effectively.  To even 
> be a half  decent shot you are going to have to shoot at least ten 
> targets a week almost every week.   And your skills decline rapidly 
> without practice.  And of course if you haven't practiced at all 
> the odds of your hitting a target at distance with a "lucky shot" 
> are slim at best.  That only happens in movies.  Head over to a 
> rifle range and try it; you'll see what I mean. Peter P.S.  That's 
> right I'm a gun owning Buddhist.  Beware. ----- Original Message

> This mix is the tale of my first year in San Francisco, and how I somehow
> managed to pull myself up from the gutter with a lot of help from my boo. In
> that respect it's really a love letter to my girlfriend, and it represents
> the triumph of love over sometimes incredible circumstances. It works on a
> lot of different levels.

At 01:15 PM 2/6/2007, Nathan Seven wrote:
>On Feb 5, 2007, at 5:36 PM, Sarilion wrote:
>
>>
>>What evidence do you offer to support these claims?  In many cases,
>>mailing lists provide useful information not found on forums.  I
>>don't agree that forums have surpassed mailing lists, and social
>>networking sites like myspace don't even come close to replacing /
>>substituting for mailing lists.  If myspace was a better
>>communication tool for Ravers in SF, SFR would truly be dead.  As
>>such is not the case, new ravers in the area do join the list -
>>case in point, Marc-O.
>
>This is what I wrote:
>
>>>The social and discussion constructs provided by a "mailing list"
>>>were surpassed back when the first "forum" was created-
>
>I don't see this as a "claim" and more a simple fact- a forum just
>provides more of a social construct, and more discussion oriented
>tools than a mailing list can.
>Searching, avatars, persistence of information- etc.
>The specific social-network sites of course take that side beyond
>forums.
>I'm not saying that SFR should "turn in to a forum" or anything.

Ok, let me break this down:

Just because you state it, doesn't make it fact.

That's why I asked for evidence.  I see no evidence that forums 
surpass mailing lists.

Further, I see no evidence that TV surpasses newspaper.  They're 
different ways of conveying information.


sarilion

As far as it's production / mastering. . . All I used was a live to tape
recording in Audacity. No mastering, just mixing.

It's programmed heavily, I went through at least 20-30 versions before I got
this one and decided it was finished. Other than that there's not much to
tell, two turntables, a mixer, some headphones, a big stack of vinyl, and a
lot of work is all that went into this. :-)

On 2/6/07, Alex Laughlin  wrote:
>
> This mix is the tale of my first year in San Francisco, and how I somehow
> managed to pull myself up from the gutter with a lot of help from my boo. In
> that respect it's really a love letter to my girlfriend, and it represents
> the triumph of love over sometimes incredible circumstances. It works on a
> lot of different levels.
>
> Running time: 1 hour, 1 minute, 50 seconds.
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?

At 04:24 PM 2/6/2007, Shatter wrote:

>I'm thinking that if somebody held you to the criteria you seem to 
>hold others, you'd be quite offended.

Ok, I understand that, and I'll leave NS to respond.

>Its' a fucking drink.  There's a signifigant statitsical percentage 
>that with increase quantiy he likelihood of droppage.  Also, setting 
>it down and forgetting about it.

Ok, I've read this four times, and I can't make sense out of it.  I 
also can't seem to correlate it to NS's response.


>As for the food, do you tip the same at Mels as you do as some 
>places charging $25 for a chirp cocktail?  Do that waiter work any harder?

Personally, I tip based on service.  If the service at Mel's is on 
par with the service at Il Fornaio, the tip rate will be the same.

Whether or not the wait staff works as hard is as much a function of 
restaurant design as anything else.

>Bartender == Chef
>Barback == Waiter

WTF is a barback?  There's bartenders, who serve drinks, and there's 
a bar manager.

A chef prepares dishes, and the wait staff deliver them.

A bar manager does not make drinks for the bartenders to deliver.


sarilion

>That's the parellel.
>
>
>At 04:14 PM 2/6/2007, Nathan Seven wrote:
>>On Feb 6, 2007, at 3:39 PM, Shatter wrote:
>>
>>>You pay the BAR for your drink, you pay your BARTENDER to make it.
>>>
>>>I mean, if you have a really great dinner, you tip teh waiter
>>>really well.  Why?  They didn't make it.  They walked 30 feet and
>>>dropped it on your table.  The Chef made it.  Do you tip him
>>
>>I guess I see it differently.
>>Any tip I give is for service.
>>Both at a bar, and a restaurant.
>>
>>Your bar analogy is right on.
>>Did the bartender address me in the proper order for when I got there?
>>Did he/she make the drink correctly and in the right proportions?
>>Does my glass have some crap on it that they didn't notice?
>>Is my change returned as promptly as can be expected?
>>That is the "service" involved there- and all of it determines what
>>tip I give.
>>
>>At a restaurant it's no different- I'm paying the price of the dish
>>for the chef's abilities.
>>I don't know why you think it would be different at a restaurant.
>>The tip is for the service from the waiter.
>>Did my bread arrive promptly?
>>Is my plate and silverware clean?
>>Do you have knowledgeable opinions on the food, specials, and wine
>>selections?
>>Do you keep an eye on the table to see if anything is getting low?
>>Etc etc.
>>
>>Maybe I'm a weirdo here...
>>
>>--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Mon)

For reference, the Predator thing is entirely fake-

It's a GE .308- normally mounted in helicopter doors.
The recoil from that gun would put you on your ass almost instantly,  
and any amount of power that you could pack-carry for it would be  
depleted just as quick.
(gatling guns requiring an external power source to spin em)

And dangrsmind- i'm not quite sure what scenario you're planning for-

We don't live in deer country here- in an apocalyptic scenario my  
priorities are hunting and defense.  And the only things I'm going to  
be hunting are squirrels, pigeons, dogs, cats, and the occasional  
raccoon and opossum.
Engagement ranges for this kind of hunting or for defense are almost  
always going to be <25yds- which is why I've focused on the 12ga  
shotgun.
There is nothing more capable at this range for either hunting or  
defense, and if need be I can always drop a slug in and reach out and  
touch someone.

--
"Jupiter accepts your offer..."

>> Sure at like 15 or 25 yards right?  Try 100. I learned to shoot in  
>> summer camp originally as part of the Civilian Marksmanship  
>> Program (http://www.odcmp.com/CRProgram.htm) so I learned to shoot  
>> from the standard positions of standing, kneeling, and prone.  You  
>> start out at 50 feet.  Targets are scored based on your shot  
>> placement on the target, and the closer to the center the higher  
>> the score.  I am talking about aiming and firing from a fixed  
>> position.  I have friends that can put ten rounds inthe bulls eye  
>> consistently at 100 yards, but I've never been that good.  FYI,

Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?

At 06:37 PM 2/6/2007, Sarilion wrote:

>>Its' a fucking drink.  There's a signifigant statitsical percentage that 
>>with increase quantiy he likelihood of droppage.  Also, setting it down 
>>and forgetting about it.
>
>Ok, I've read this four times, and I can't make sense out of it.  I also 
>can't seem to correlate it to NS's response.

The drunker you get, the more likely you are to spill or walk off and 
forget about that drink that you are being so overly critical of.


>>As for the food, do you tip the same at Mels as you do as some places 
>>charging $25 for a chirp cocktail?  Do that waiter work any harder?
>
>Personally, I tip based on service.  If the service at Mel's is on par 
>with the service at Il Fornaio, the tip rate will be the same.
>
>Whether or not the wait staff works as hard is as much a function of 
>restaurant design as anything else.

Right.   So a 15% dinner at Mels would be around $2 and a expenice place a 
tip would rack $20 or more.  So are you saying that you would leave a $2 
top at teh expenive place if both places server very well or would you give 
somebody at mels $20 for great service?

This is my point.  You'll give minimum 15% to a guy that carries a plate 20 
feet and balk at giving a bartender a dollar.

>WTF is a barback?  There's bartenders, who serve drinks, and there's a bar 
>manager.

Bar back:   Preps the bar, stocks the bar, clean the bar, washes the 
glasses, cleans the tables, the floor, the bathrooms, and sweeps the place.

Bar managers set prices and handle staffing.  The do not wash glasses.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?

On Tue, Feb 06, 2007 at 06:37:58PM -0800, Sarilion wrote:
> 
> 
> WTF is a barback?  There's bartenders, who serve drinks, and there's 
> a bar manager.

A barback is the person who keeps the ice bin full, beer stocked,
and gets new bottles of liquer as needed.  This person often times
will clear empties.  From time to time they will serve a drink if
the bartender went out for a smoke or if things are really backed
up.

-r

Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?

I'll take both sides of the arguement here.

1) They can.  Supply and demand.  Same reason why water
is $2.00 from vending machines at rest stops.

2) So on the high end its about $0.30/bottle -- wholesale.
This does not consider cost to cool the bottles, storage,
and labor.  And bars don't stay open by selling beverages
at or below cost.

-r

Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?

On Feb 6, 2007, at 8:33 PM, Shatter wrote:

> Right.   So a 15% dinner at Mels would be around $2 and a expenice  
> place a tip would rack $20 or more.  So are you saying that you  
> would leave a $2 top at teh expenive place if both places server  
> very well or would you give somebody at mels $20 for great service?
>
> This is my point.  You'll give minimum 15% to a guy that carries a  
> plate 20 feet and balk at giving a bartender a dollar.

You dismiss expectations.
Do I expect that waiters at Mels will ask to contain my bag/coat for  
me should they see it placed next to me?  As well as my companions'?
Do I expect that they will consult me in my wine selection?
Do I expect that they will bring me examples of said wine to aid in  
my decision?
Do I expect that they will bring me complimentary hor'deurves while  
the main course is being figured out?

No.

I'f I'm paying $40 for a steak, there comes along with that an  
expected level of service.
If I'm paying $7.99 for the steak, then my expectations are thus  
appropriately set.

Your point I fear, is lost among the ether.

At 09:06 PM 2/6/2007, Ravi Pina wrote:
>What is your source?
>
>-r

This is a San Francisco ordinance.

(f) Free Drinking Water. If the location for which the dance hall permit is issued holds over 500 persons the permit holder shall provide free cool drinking water to patrons by means of an automatic drinking fountain or by providing without charge cups of water at all beverage service locations, or both. 

(Amended by Ord. 260-81, App. 5/21/81; Ord. 176-00, File No. 000477, App. 7/28/2000; Ord. 164-02, File No. 020783, App. 7/26/2002)



>On Tue, Feb 06, 2007 at 10:24:11AM -0800, Ben Haus wrote:
>> If I'm not mistaken, california state law requires bars to provide water to
>> their patrons.  Which is the route I usually go... then tipping a dollar
>> isn't such a big deal  ;)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] tipping for water?


ya..  I mean, let's do some more math...

Bartender pours one drink an hour.  They're making $8.65 per drink.  woo!

Bartender knocks out 180 drinks an hour.  Now they're getting paid $.05 per 
drink by the house!

If a bartener can move 180 drinks an hour, they are a rockstar, since 
that's 1 drink every 20 seconds, and that has to include stopping to play 
register jockey.  (I also grabbed that number to make the math easy and 
make a point)

If they get $1 a drink, they just made $180/hr.  The bar paid them $8.65.

Now...  Bottom line...

It takes a bartender just as much time, energy, and effort, to serve a 
bottle of beer, as it does a bottle of water.  Nobody has argued against 
giving a tip for a bottle of beer, but you're squacking about a bottle of 
water.




At 09:22 PM 2/6/2007, Ravi Pina wrote:
>Only a fraction of the money for the water goes into the
>person's pocket who served it to you.  The latter is
>counting on people to tip so they can earn an income.
>
>-r
>
>

Absolutely.  As Chomsky points out, free speech cuts both ways.  Like Manju=
shri's sword.=0A=0ALook how much we've already learned here on sfraves by a=
llowing everyone to speak their true minds and hearts.=0A =0ANote that Chom=
sky doesn't say we should listen to the views of those we despise, just tha=
t we should allow them to speak.  That's an important point.  What you list=
en to, and what you believe in, is still your own responsibility.=0A =0ASom=
e people seem to think that freedom of speech means the freedom to express =
yourself without opposition.  Opposition is targeted under the banner of fr=
ee speech as an attempt to "silence" the speaker.  What these people really=
 want is the freedom to speak without dealing with opposing arguments or fa=
cts.  But that isn't how it works.  Freedom of speech also includes the fre=
edom to point out the evil, bullshit, errors, and just plain old stupidity =
you see in what other people have to say.  =0A=0AI'd suggest we all start e=
xercising our right to speak freely.  Use it or lose it.=0A=0APeace,=0A =0A=

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Mon)

No sane or educated person likes war.  But it is important I think to educa=
te yourself to war's reality.  War remains part of the human situation.=0A=
=0AI grew up in Berkeley in the 70s before video games and we spent a lot o=
f our time in those days playing paper map wargames and military simulation=
s.  I became sort of an amateur military historian as a result and I have a=
 decent library of military history books.  I've never read this one so tha=
nks for the recommendation.=0A=0AWhen I worked in the aerospace field, I go=
t to work with a number of different warriors ranging from highly trained A=
ir Force fighter pilots and Special Operations Forces to the average infant=
ry grunt.  When you meet someone that has really seen combat they rarely (a=
ctually never in my experience) glorify it.  Everyone I worked with took th=
ese matters with deadly seriousness.  Some of them had lost friends and man=
y of them had killed people.  Often the reality is that you shoot at a targ=
et but never really know if you hit anyone.=0A=0ASo while as I said I haven=
't read this particular book, if you hate war you should in fact read lots =
of books about war.  Talk to warriors.  Educate yourself about military his=
tory and theory.  Learn about how wars are started and how they are won or =
lost.  Once you've educated yourself you will find that you can also conver=
se/debate with those that support war in their own terms.  This approach ca=
rries much more weight with the people that matter than protesting in my ex=
perience.  =0A=0A"The real Art of Peace is not to sacrifice a single one of=
 your warriors to defeat an enemy. Vanquish your foes by always keeping you=
rself in a safe and unassailable position; then no one will suffer any loss=
es. The Way of a Warrior, the Art of Politics, is to stop trouble before it=
 starts. It consists in defeating your adversaries spiritually by making th=
em realize the folly of their actions. The Way of a Warrior is to establish=
 harmony."=0A=0A-- Morihei Ueshiba=0A=0ARegards,=0A=0APeter=0A=0A=0A----- O=

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR - Fernet Branca - SF is top Consumer LOL

Okay.. I should learn to answer my own questions -  Wikopedia says:

Widely popular in Argentina, it is often mistaken as a national beverage. 
The most common preparation is with Coca-Cola. To make a Fernet and Coke, 
use a tall glass filled with ice (tubo), then pour the Fernet up to 2/3 of 
the glass, top off with Coke. Serve with the can of Coke and a straw. More 
recently, it has become very popular in San Francisco, which now consumes 
more Fernet per capita than any other locale in the world.[1]

>Okay.. I should learn to answer my own questions -  Wikopedia says:
>
>Widely popular in Argentina, it is often mistaken as a national beverage. 
>The most common preparation is with Coca-Cola. To make a Fernet and Coke, 
>use a tall glass filled with ice (tubo), then pour the Fernet up to 2/3 of 
>the glass, top off with Coke. Serve with the can of Coke and a straw. More 
>recently, it has become very popular in San Francisco, which now consumes 
>more Fernet per capita than any other locale in the world.[1]

Subject: Re: [sfraves] And now for something completely rave related...

Great story.. e has been a notable savior for so many I know.. comepletely 
changed the balance of what it meant to get high into something - 
meaningful.  I love the end of that story:  Better living through chemistry. 
  That;s what mom used to say.. I just don't think she quite meant it that 
way :)

[My son? He is 19 now, and in his spare time - having some months ago kicked 
the Ecstasy habit himself - he spins mixes at raves, and this fall he is 
entering college, quite a reputable college, as a psychology major. And he 
is writing poetry again. More brilliant than ever. Minor triumphs, perhaps. 
Still, it does make one wonder. Would he have made it back intact without E? 
Would he have arrived at that which all of us deserve and so few manage to 
find, his chance for happiness? And it makes one wonder, too, about what 
they say: better living through chemistry.]






SFR: Ranger
San Francisco
plurranger@hotmail.com
Who knows where the night leads
It's dark and no one can see

>It's awesome...  It's like Jager, only without any of that syrupy 
>disgustingness!  ;) ;)

>Basically it's a STRONG tasting herbal tonic that will put a thizz face on 
>all but the most hardy of shot drinkers.  It is the best thing I've found 
>for waking myself up when energy drops late at night.  Better than Red 
>Bull, for sure.
>
>I've been known to tote a flask of it when I go out to keep myself and my 
>friends running into the wee hours.
>
>Note: Unless you are a freak (or a true believer), Fernet does not taste 
>"good".  Then again, neither do most drugs, and you crazies do them anyhow!

> >use a tall glass filled with ice (tubo), then pour the Fernet up to 2/3 
>of

hahaha

even wikipedia knows of this town's odd obsession with fernet... awesome.
i have no idea what the connection is, but it's very real. it's supposed to be a digestive aid, so the idea is that you drink fernet after a meal. however, in san francisco if you order fernet, it basically says to the people behind the bar, "attention please! i am a server, bartender, etc. please give me the industry hookup." strange indeed. 

i'm also curious to know what it is about san francisco particularly that encourages so many fernet whores. if anyone finds out, please share with the class!

love,
mo

recall there being an SF weekly article about it last year, but i've
slept since then.


-jasonh

> > Coke,
> > > >use a tall glass filled with ice (tubo), then pour the Fernet up to 2/3
> > >of
> > > >the glass, top off with Coke. Serve with the can of Coke and a straw.
> > >More
> > > >recently, it has become very popular in San Francisco, which now
> > consumes
> > > >more Fernet per capita than any other locale in the world.[1]

SEVENTY-TWO VIRGINS

by STEVE MARTIN

Issue of 2007-01-29
Posted 2007-01-22

Virgin No. 1: Yuck.

Virgin No. 2: Ick.

Virgin No. 3: Ew.

Virgin No. 4: Ow.

Virgin No. 5: Do you like cats? I have fourteen!

Virgin No. 6: I=92m Becky. I=92ll be legal in two years.

Virgin No. 7: Here, I=92ll just pull down your zipper. Oh, sorry!

Virgin No. 8: Can we cuddle first?

Virgin No. 9: It was a garlic-and-onion pizza. Why?

Virgin No. 10: . . . so I see Heath, and he goes, =93Like, what are you =20=

doing here?,=94 and I go, =93I=92m hangin=92 out,=94 so he goes, =93Like, =
=20
what?=94 . . .

"No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path =20
toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and =20
enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras, =20
sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and =20
Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can =20
find in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and =20
economic regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond =20
what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative =20
pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and work in =20
squalor."
-Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of =20
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will =20
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--Apple-Mail-3--692959434--

From: Will Penna <w.penna@comcast.net>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR - Fernet Branca - SF is top Consumer LOL

I grew up in San Francisco, as did my parents and grandparents from  
Italy, before moving on to other parts  of northern Cali. It's the  
drink my grandpa Penna always drank a shot of when he said things  
didn't feel right in his stomach, and he lived to his 90s. It's been  
a big hit in the City for generations, especially among families  
originally from Europe. More recently, in newage health circles,  
especially those knowing the Asian five elements, the bitter element  
as found in Fernet Branca is known also to settle the digestive  
system when the other four can't or are out of balance. Later yet-- 
around the late '80s or so--it came into popularity in clubs  
worldwide on the heels of other bitters, notably Jagermeister, and  
its makers even came up with Fernet Branca Menta--which IMNSHO is  
ghastly! Until the late '70s or so, Fernet Branca's label still  
listed the herbal ingredients.

On Feb 7, 2007, at 2:20 PM, mo corleone wrote:

> this might be the sf weekly article mentioned earlier:
> http://www.sfweekly.com/Issues/2005-12-07/news/feature.html
> mo corleone <mo_corleone2@yahoo.com> wrote: hahaha
> even wikipedia knows of this town's odd obsession with fernet...  
> awesome.
> i have no idea what the connection is, but it's very real. it's  
> supposed to be a digestive aid, so the idea is that you drink  
> fernet after a meal. however, in san francisco if you order fernet,  
> it basically says to the people behind the bar, "attention please!  
> i am a server, bartender, etc. please give me the industry hookup."  
> strange indeed.
> i'm also curious to know what it is about san francisco  
> particularly that encourages so many fernet whores. if anyone finds  
> out, please share with the class!
> love,
> mo
> jason hemmenway  wrote: Does anyone know where the SF -> fernet  
> connection comes from?  I
> recall there being an SF weekly article about it last year, but i've
> slept since then.
> -jasonh

actually secretly doing just that.  a total new world order lapdog,

On 2/7/07, Will Penna <w.penna@comcast.net> wrote:
>
> I grew up in San Francisco, as did my parents and grandparents from
> Italy, before moving on to other parts  of northern Cali. It's the
> drink my grandpa Penna always drank a shot of when he said things
> didn't feel right in his stomach, and he lived to his 90s. It's been
> a big hit in the City for generations, especially among families
> originally from Europe. More recently, in newage health circles,
> especially those knowing the Asian five elements, the bitter element
> as found in Fernet Branca is known also to settle the digestive
> system when the other four can't or are out of balance. Later yet--
> around the late '80s or so--it came into popularity in clubs
> worldwide on the heels of other bitters, notably Jagermeister, and
> its makers even came up with Fernet Branca Menta--which IMNSHO is
> ghastly! Until the late '70s or so, Fernet Branca's label still
> listed the herbal ingredients.
>
>

X-ELNK-Trace: b815ca255710aa4c0ba167aeb931aee97e972de0d01da940d0b6e100b834ca1a9c8557ae35d1c624350badd9bab72f9c350badd9bab72f9c350badd9bab72f9c
X-Originating-IP: 207.101.242.2
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] need a dome for the playa?

i like to give myself design projects every so often to keep myself  
occupied.

recently, i gave myself the task of designing a shelter that is  
relatively inexpensive to make, packs/stores/ships flat, is easy and  
quick to assemble & disassemble, is comprised of modular parts, is  
completely compost-able/biodegradable and made from recycled and non- 
toxic materials. it should also stand up to high winds and wet  
weather - basically, i wanted it ALL.

my intent was to create a design that could be used as disaster  
relief shelter. of course in meeting all the requirements, the end  
result ended up being the ultimate tree-hugger playa shelter.

a couple quickie JPEGs of the design are here:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/44124395037@N01/sets/72157594523625639/

the footprint is roughly 15 ft x 19 ft., and it has 240 sq ft of  
enclosed floor space!
packed for transporting, the overall dimensions are 4 ft x 8 ft x 3  
ft, with no odd shapes or protrusions - just like a box from Ikea
total weight is about 60 lbs. - your rebar stakes alone will probably  
weigh this much!

needless to say, i'm pretty excited about this.

the next step is to make one or two to test, and find some human  
guinea pigs who wanna do some camping. I figure the best way to go  
about this is to find someone who wants one, have them purchase the  
materials, and i'll make it. i'd buy the materials myself, but the  
cash is kinda tight right now with the new house and all.

i'm waiting to hear back from a few local suppliers to get an idea of  
the cost of the materials, but it shouldn't be much - i'm guessing,  
and this is only a guess - that the material for the panels will cost  
roughly $150 total, plus maybe $20 or so for fastener hardware.

so... the question again is:  need a dome for the playa?  email or  
give me a call. :-)

-philip-

Subject: Re: [sfraves] sfraves relevence and calendar...

terry i wouldn't be too hard on ourselves.  from what i've seen, web  
tools are hard to produce, and when no one's getting paid for it,  
it's usually one maybe two people doing the work.

and to maybe add to your mention of security, which, when i think  
about it, i agree with, i think there's a bit of anonymity on the  
list that is kind of nice when you compare it to say tribe or  
myspace.  i'd say about half the regulars here i've met and some of  
the others i can guess ... like peter's probably 45 with 2 kids and  
jewish ... =]

anyway i appreciate some of the intelligent discussions that happen  
here.  i used to be totally against message boards and i still prefer  
the pop3 mail client world over web based solutions, but if the  
profiles came back at some point in the future it might be fun.  like  
i said though i think it's fine the way it is now.


On Feb 6, 2007, at 5:35 PM, Terry Estioko wrote:

>
> A part of me is bummed that collectively we have a pretty high IQ  
> here, and enough designers and developers to shake a stick a stick  
> at. Yet we can't maintain our own web site, or make it usable. Even  
> though we're old crusty crab people, we could still have a pimp- 
> home on the 'net, I would guess.
>
> A lot of the problems came in people not following through  
> (flaking), the rest of problems came in having people agree *what*  
> to do (design by committee).
>
> Another part of me just says leave what is there as a snapshot into  
> a nostalgic past of the way the scene was.
>
> One issue (as far as the list specifically) is I know Brian is  
> particular about the security of the list, meaning, it's  
> subscription based format keeps random people from googling us and  
> reading our discussions. All the other hyperreal lists (to my  
> knowledge) are ezmlm email-based lists. I particulary like being  
> able to be candid on here, but I also like PHP forums when is comes  
> to browsing threads when I feel like it.
>
> I'm not opposed to a revamp, I doubt Brian is either. But everytime  
> this comes up, a group comes together and nothing ever really  
> happens in the end.
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Tue)


HHonestly I see too much of people putting too much important on non 
related issues.  As soon as somebody says something, nobody is talking 
about tehy're they saying, immediately all things about them, or unrelated 
issues are brought up.

This is done by both sides, and honestly, i'm really fucking sick of it.

Argueing that somebody's opinion is invalid, or whatever they are saying 
isn't worth listening to becaus ethey disagree with homosexuality is as 
logical as somebody who refuses to listen to what somebody says JUST 
because they are a homosexual.

Anyone else agree?

Will you disagree when I say I'm tired of homosexuality being a rallying 
cry for all issues?  Homosexuals are no more rightious than anyone 
else?  The idea that I don't hold Homosexuals in high regard just becaus 
ethey are a homosexual?

See....   Apply what I call the Shatter test..   Exchange words in a 
statement and see if it matters.  When reading things, interchange the word 
homosexual with the word hetrosexual.  If the entire meaning is lost, then 
guess what, it was irrelevent in the first place. If the statement makes 
sense, or remains unoffensive, then it's applicable.

Cause honestly, anti-hetrosexuals are as funny as anti-homosexuals.


The bottom line, the integrity of our nations, culture, borders, and what 
have you, has as much to do with sexual preference as what brand of tires 
you have on your car.  Seperate issues.

Subject: [sfraves] From Eddy: NEW COMPANY POLICY FOR NEW EMPLOYEES EFFECTIVE 01/01/07

Hi Willie~

Stupidly, from my old friend Stash! However, I rather like the last
one.  Kind of goes along with the fat rant you [Will] sent out the
other day.  I, by the way, am sick of really fat people squashing
down into a MUNI seat next to me, when they really need two, or
better yet they can simply stand unless the bus is not crowded.  Eddy

NEW COMPANY POLICY FOR NEW EMPLOYEES EFFECTIVE 01/01/07

Dress Code

It is advised that you come to work dressed according to your   
salary.  If we
see you wearing Prada shoes and carrying a Gucci bag, we assume you are
doing well financially and therefore do not need a raise. If you dress
poorly, you need to learn to manage your money better, so that you  
may buy  nicer
clothes, and therefore you do not need a raise. If you dress just
right, youare right where you need to be and therefore you do not  
need a  raise.

Sick Days

We will no longer accept a doctor's statement as proof of sickness.
If you are able to go to the doctor , you are able to come to work.

Personal Days

Each employee will receive 104 personal days a year. They are called
Saturday & Sunday.

Bereavement Leave

This is no excuse for missing work. There is nothing you can do for dead
friends, relatives or co-workers. Every effort should be made to have
non-employees attend to the arrangements. In rare cases where employee
involvement is necessary, the funeral should be scheduled in the  
late  afternoon. We
will be glad to allow you to work through your lunch hour and
subsequently leave one hour early.

Toilet Use

Entirely too much time is being spent in the toilet. There is now a
strict three-minute time limit in the stalls. At the end of three  
minutes,
an alarm will sound, the toilet paper roll will retract, the stall  
door will
open, and a picture will be taken. After your second offence, your  
picture
will be posted on the company bulletin board under the "Chronic  
Offenders
Category". Anyone caught smiling in the picture will be sanctioned  
under the
company's mental health policy.

Lunch Break

Skinny people get 30 minutes for lunch, as they need to eat more, so
that they can look healthy. Normal size people get 15 minutes for  
lunch to
get a balanced meal to maintain their average figure. Chubby people  
get 5
minutes for lunch, because that's all the time needed to drink a Slim- 
Fast.
___________________________________
Thank you for your loyalty to our company.  We are here
to provide a positive employment experience.

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

"Robby G"/ longtime SFR-lurker here, chiming in about Fernet...=0A=0AI woul=
dn't be surprised if the SF-Fernet connection traces its roots to the old I=
talian immigrant/North Beach influence.  My understanding of the drink is t=
hat is typically sipped exclusively (outside SF) by "old Italian men".  Its=
 fanatically enjoyed but its also supposed to be "an aquired taste".  I tot=
ally believe this since, well, I love scotch and bourbon, but I can't say I=
 always did.  Heck, I don't know if I even liked beer that much when I had =
my first taste.=0A=0AAs far as its medicinal properties, it falls into the =
general category of "bitters".  Like dry vermouth in a martini, or sweet ve=
rmouth in a manhattan.  A really cool thing about all bitters is that they =
really really really are awesome if you have a stomach ache. =0A=0AI had on=
e recently and I reached for a bottle of this stuff my Croatian father in l=
aw gave me as a gift, something called Pelinkovac.  (Pronouced "pel-link-ko=
-vatz").  Anyway, like Fernet, its not exactly smooth going down, but damn =
my stomach felt 150% better in minutes. =0A=0A----- Original Message ----=

Subject: Re: [sfraves] DFUSE sat. @ ruby skye

On Thu, Feb 08, 2007 at 02:57:51PM -0800, Mallorieknoxx wrote:
>This Sat a friend and i are going see DFUSE @ ruby skye and was
>wondering if anyone else is going ? We've never been here before and
>was wondering if there is good parking!? other places we should check
>out? have a good and safe weekend ppls!
>  thanx
>  ~Raina
>
>  http://www.club-calendar.com/cgi-bin/DJcalendar.cgi?TEMPLATE=rubyweb-event.html&EVENTNO=00369

When I go to Ruby Skye, I park at 5th and Mission[1] because it's
inexpensive. I then walk over to Ruby Skye[2] (staying on Mason, unlike
the route depicted on the map).

There are several closer garages (one of which is Downtown Center
Garage[3]), but they're quite expensive because of the theatre district.
I've also seen them full several times.

I saw D:FUSE at Ruby Skye a while ago and it was good show.
Have a good time!

[1]
http://maps.google.com/maps?q=5th%20and%20Mission%2C%2094103(5th%20and%20Mission%20City%20Parking)

[2]
http://maps.google.com/maps?f=d&saddr=5th+and+Mission,+94103&daddr=420+Mason,94102

[3]
http://maps.google.com/maps?q=325%20Mason%2C94102

--
Holt Sorenson
hso@hsomusic.com
http://www.hsomusic.com/

Subject: [sfraves] James Kim Memorial and Celebration 2/17/07 (Re: [sfraves] Hit me
 with your best BSP

One week away for this one. But some of you have known James Kim. Should 
be lots of CF/FnFer's in attendance...

Babus
A Memorial and Celebration of James Kim's Life

Saturday, February 17th, 2007
1:00pm: Memorial
2:00pm - Sunset: Celebration
Location: Golden Gate Park Memorial Bandshell and Music Concourse

The family and friends of James Kim would like to extend a warm
invitation to join us in celebrating and remembering James's life.
This outdoor gathering serves to remind us of the deep ties that
bring us together, and honors James's appreciation for his family,
friends, and community.

This will be a family event -- bring your kids, bring a picnic, and
bring warm clothes. We will be celebrating with DJs, music,
and dancing until sunset.

In addition, we are proud to announce and unveil The James Kim
Technology Foundation. The purpose of the fund is to benefit technology
programs in public schools. Donations to the foundation will be
appreciated.

For more information and donations:
http://www.jamesandkati.com

For media inquiries and press passes:
news@jamesandkati.com

Volunteer and event coordination:
friendsandfamily@jamesandkati.com


------------------------------------
terry estioko | terry@viberation.com
http://www.estioko.com
http://www.viberation.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR - Fernet Branca - SF is top Consumer LOL

I find that most bars around this city have it. It has no "wake me up" 
properties that I am aware of...it's basically like Jaegermeister, sans 
Anise flavoring. More "herbal" tasting. Kind of like if Ricola cough drops 
were made into liquid and got ya drunk. lol

(but I think it tastes worse than Ricola)

> >of
> > >the glass, top off with Coke. Serve with the can of Coke and a straw.

I'm trying to take it easy this weekend...thinking about checking this New
Wave thing out though...for a change of pace

3. DECADE

Candy and Skip present...

DECADE - The DJ Dance Club
Every hour a different decade!
FREE ~ No Cover Charge All Night
Now on the 2nd Friday of the month

Friday, February 9th, 2007
"LOVE BITES NIGHT"
All songs about heartbreak and falling in & out of love.
Free Valentine's cards for everyone. Sign your name (or someone
else's!) and pass it to someone at the club!

9-10pm
1980's =96 "THE SWEETER SIDE OF LOVE WITH CANDY"
DJ Candy (DECADE) starts the night off with a little tenderness and
seduces you with Book of Love - You Make Me Feel So Good, Eurythmics -
Love is a Stranger, ABC - Look of Love, The Cure - Love Cats and more
sweet hard candy you can suck on.

10-11pm
1990's =96 "LOVE AND HATE =96 BRITPOP STYE"
DJ Skip (New Wave City) spins the Battle of Britpop, as bands like
Oasis, Blur, Pulp, The Verve and more teach us about love on a
farmboy's wages.

11-12am
1970's =96 "50 WAYS TO LEAVE YOUR LOVER"
Tomas Diablo (Strangelove, Rock This Town) takes us back to the most
volatile decade of popular music ever =96 the 70's! Expect to hear
Buzzcocks - Ever Fallen in Love?, Joe Jackson - Is She Really Going Out
with Him?, Pat Benatar =96 Heartbreaker, Foreigner - Cold As Ice and much
more.

12-1am
1980's =96 "LOVE STINKS!"
DJ Skip (New Wave City) says Love is Tainted, Love is a Battlefield,
and Love will definitely Tear Us Apart. Don't Talk to Me About Love
'cause Love Comes Quickly and Who Needs Love Like That? All these songs
and more in this set that will prove once and for all that Love Stinks!

1am-2am
2000's =96 "MODERN LOVE IS AUTOMATIC"
DJ Candy (DECADE) traditionally ends the evening with a killer set of
Indie, Pop, Electronica and remixes that has quickly become a
don't-miss-this-final-set dancing frenzy. Expect to hear Rinocerose -
Lost Love, White Rose Movement - Love is a Number, Louix XIV - Finding
Out True Love is Blind, She Wants Revenge - Broken Promises for Broken
Hearts and much more.

Special one-night-only showing of paintings by local artist Jard.

Hostess Candy has sweet treats for you from every decade.
9pm until 2am
FREE ~ No Cover Charge All Night
21+ with valid ID

Catalyst Cocktails
(recently picked by CitySearch editors as one of the "Top 10 New Bars")
312 Harriet St. (off Bryant between 6th & 7th) San Francisco
One block from The Endup

>3. DECADE
>
>Candy and Skip present...
>
>DECADE - The DJ Dance Club
>Every hour a different decade!
>FREE ~ No Cover Charge All Night
>Now on the 2nd Friday of the month
>
>Friday, February 9th, 2007
>"LOVE BITES NIGHT"
>All songs about heartbreak and falling in & out of love.
>Free Valentine's cards for everyone. Sign your name (or someone
>else's!) and pass it to someone at the club!
>
>9-10pm
>1980's =96 "THE SWEETER SIDE OF LOVE WITH CANDY"
>DJ Candy (DECADE) starts the night off with a little tenderness and
>seduces you with Book of Love - You Make Me Feel So Good, Eurythmics -
>Love is a Stranger, ABC - Look of Love, The Cure - Love Cats and more
>sweet hard candy you can suck on.
>
>10-11pm
>1990's =96 "LOVE AND HATE =96 BRITPOP STYE"
>DJ Skip (New Wave City) spins the Battle of Britpop, as bands like
>Oasis, Blur, Pulp, The Verve and more teach us about love on a
>farmboy's wages.
>
>11-12am
>1970's =96 "50 WAYS TO LEAVE YOUR LOVER"
>Tomas Diablo (Strangelove, Rock This Town) takes us back to the most
>volatile decade of popular music ever =96 the 70's! Expect to hear
>Buzzcocks - Ever Fallen in Love?, Joe Jackson - Is She Really Going Out
>with Him?, Pat Benatar =96 Heartbreaker, Foreigner - Cold As Ice and much
>more.
>
>12-1am
>1980's =96 "LOVE STINKS!"
>DJ Skip (New Wave City) says Love is Tainted, Love is a Battlefield,
>and Love will definitely Tear Us Apart. Don't Talk to Me About Love
>'cause Love Comes Quickly and Who Needs Love Like That? All these songs
>and more in this set that will prove once and for all that Love Stinks!
>
>1am-2am
>2000's =96 "MODERN LOVE IS AUTOMATIC"
>DJ Candy (DECADE) traditionally ends the evening with a killer set of
>Indie, Pop, Electronica and remixes that has quickly become a
>don't-miss-this-final-set dancing frenzy. Expect to hear Rinocerose -
>Lost Love, White Rose Movement - Love is a Number, Louix XIV - Finding
>Out True Love is Blind, She Wants Revenge - Broken Promises for Broken
>Hearts and much more.
>
>Special one-night-only showing of paintings by local artist Jard.
>
>Hostess Candy has sweet treats for you from every decade.
>9pm until 2am
>FREE ~ No Cover Charge All Night
>21+ with valid ID
>
>Catalyst Cocktails
>(recently picked by CitySearch editors as one of the "Top 10 New Bars")
>312 Harriet St. (off Bryant between 6th & 7th) San Francisco
>One block from The Endup
>

"No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path  
toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and  
enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras,  
sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and  
Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can  
find in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and  
economic regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond  
what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative  
pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and work in  
squalor."
-Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of  
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will  
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

opinion.  things like this are being done by design to demoralize the  
american people and legitimize unequal treatment.  while they're  
abandoning people like this they're bound by law, i can't remember  
the name of the act right now so help me i'll look through my notes,  
to give free emergency room care to illegal aliens.  they shouldn't  
dump anyone in an alleyway.  in fact, a lot of these homeless people  
belong in psychiatric hospitals because they simply don't have the  
ability to take care of themselves.  we can thank former governor  
ronald reagan for decimating that system and turning out thousands to  
the streets of san francisco and berkeley, to name a few cities.

total criminals, total tyranny!  i'll have the suggestion for a  
solution on friday.  no guns required, no useless phone calls to  
politicians, either.  buy some paperboard.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] homeless dumping

Wow- it sounds like they just rolled past and kicked him right out  
the door mafia-style without even stopping:

According to Springer, the patient was brought to the hospital  
Wednesday about 10 p.m. by Los Angeles Fire Department paramedics.

The man was admitted and evaluated by medical staff, who determined  
he was in satisfactory condition to be released, Springer said. The  
patient was taken by ambulance to the home address he had listed in  
his admission form -- which turned out to be the Midnight Mission,  
which did not have a vacancy, Springer said.

He was then returned to the hospital in the ambulance, was provided a  
wheelchair in the emergency room lobby and was asked to wait for a  
clinical social worker who could help him, according to Springer.

At about 8 a.m. Thursday, after a new shift of emergency room  
staffers had come to work, the man told nurses he wanted to go home  
and they called a van to transport him, according to the hospital.

``He was taken to the address a second time and he instructed the  
driver to open the door and let him out at a local park,'' according  
to the hospital's statement. ``He assured the driver his wheelchair  
was at his home and he could propel himself to his home from the  
park. When the driver opened the door, he propelled himself to the  
sidewalk and waved the driver away.''

--
"Jupiter accepts your offer..."

spital is required to treat him even if he is destitute under a law called =
the Emergency Medical Treatment and Active Labor Act enacted in 1985.  (See=
 http://www.emtala.com/)  Hopefully the investigation described in the arti=
cle will also address that aspect of this case.  Unfortunately, I don't thi=
nk EMTALA authorizes criminal penalties because IMO someone should go to ja=
il here.  But they probably won't.=0A=0AWe can afford and should have a sys=

so i had my first taste of fernet last night at the Ambient Mafia
happy hour.  mixed with coke on the rocks.

the first few sips were....interesting.  i made strange, grimmacing
faces.  i stared at the glass and pondered many things.

by the time i finished it, i think i'd grown accustomed to the flavor.

and not think about it.

From: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR - Fernet Branca - SF is top Consumer LOL
Date: Sat, 10 Feb 2007 09:48:55 -0800

so i had my first taste of fernet last night at the Ambient Mafia
happy hour.  mixed with coke on the rocks.

the first few sips were....interesting.  i made strange, grimmacing
faces.  i stared at the glass and pondered many things.

by the time i finished it, i think i'd grown accustomed to the flavor.
i think it will take several more times before i can finish a glass
and not think about it.

> >Coke,
> > > >use a tall glass filled with ice (tubo), then pour the Fernet up to 
>2/3
> > >of
> > > >the glass, top off with Coke. Serve with the can of Coke and a straw.
> > >More
> > > >recently, it has become very popular in San Francisco, which now

as a teen in the early90's, i volunteer every winter & summers at frontline in skidrow...

this case that i just read isnt the first nor the last...

even LAPD did the same thing they dump off homeless somewhere on skid row...more like relocating them to another area...because they didnt want to bother with it...it's very sad...as a kid it bummed me out because i couldnt do more than what i was already doing....you hear so many stories from each person that ends up in skid row...it literally breaks your heart...

shelters are full everyday....

people from all walks of nature end up there...i know cause i was there & was  homeless for 4 months in 2001...

you get turned away from shelters when they reach their max...even in the rain and even with kids...

i know some homeless go to the hospitals late at night so they can have a warm place to sleep...

but their is many who are hurt, sick or have real bad mental issues who are dumped back to skid row because they have no health insurance...

anywho...i dont like our government...our state is crap...
anyone remember the movie demolition man....the homeless & rebellions lived underground...i could see that happening...maybe not now but in the future..

*sighs*

adriana

Subject: Re: [sfraves] homeless dumping

Conspiracy, or not, the net result is the same.

It's home grown, All American, served up with hot dogs, apple pie and a 
smile, genocide, man.

We the people of the United States of America are running a slo-mo, slow 
burn, version of what happened in Germany society in the late 1920s 
early 1930s.
(Feel free to call "Godwin" on this thread....... now.)

Back then men in the position of the guy in this article were called 
"useless eaters" and they were methodically removed from German society.

http://www.regent.edu/acad/schedu/uselesseaters/

Then they moved up the food chain and took care of the infirm, 
alcoholic, drug addicted, free spirited, (AKA Gypsies, the American 
parallel to them are us ravers and anyone with a piercing or 
non-military tattoo), elderly, and so on, and so forth, until they ran 
out of them, and then went to work on the Jewish people.

Even though we're not aware of it, we're totally running the same 
playbook here in the USA today.

90% of the mentally ill people that then President Ronald Reagan dumped 
on the street in the mid 1980's are no longer with us.

They didn't go back to their families and they didn't go back into the 
hospitals, since they were never re-opened, which means that, oh they're 
dead.

Which places Reagan right in between Adolph Hitler and Pol Pot in the 
'how many of your own people can you kill category.'

For this we've named at least one airport after him and lord knows how 
many schools and Post Offices.

The question that needs to be asked now is 'who have they got next in 
their sights for elimination'?

My money is on old people before they go after the likes of me,
(though if Ghouliani wins the Presidential election in '08, then that 
will be a then be a 50-50 proposition).

Why on earth do you think it is that Medicare Plan D is so confusing to
elderly people?

Don't you think the smartest minds in the world that dream that kind of 
shit up could have made that as simple as possible?

Or is this "Golden Age of Information Processing" that we're allegedly 
living in just so much bullshit PR?

Can't be both, can it?

On purpose, or not, a statistically meaningful percentage of our elderly 
will die because they couldn't fill out a form properly.

This won't be readily apparent, but over time, say the next decade, this 
will happen, but it will happen in a decentralized way that won't make 
its way into the papers, so you'll never hear about it, except when it 
happens to your family or the family of a friend.

Nobody will know, or care, that this is happening because it'll be old 
people it's happening to.

Right now what's happening is for those that are insured, or have 
assets, they're being kept alive so they can be bled dry.

A friend was recently in a local hospital for a minor injury that they 
received at home and in the next bed was a 92 year old woman that was 
receiving a battery of tests.

What's that all about, do you think?

Extending her full and happy life, or adding to the hospital's bottom line?

Happy Trails, campers and I"ll see you all in New New Orleans.

~nyc

Subject: Re: [sfraves] homeless dumping

pretty much everything you said here i agree with, except i was  
talking about ronald reagan decimating the california psychiatric  
hospital system when he was governor of california back in the what,  
1960's.  this is the kind of stuff my grandmother used to tell me and  
that was one of the reasons she hated reagan.  but anyway, i suppose  
that's just apples and oranges, the homeless problem is here and  
that's probably why.

now as far as conspiracy goes, we can thank peter for injecting that  
into this conversation.  and thank you, EMTALA is the one that i was  
trying to think of.  i want to keep this on the topic as much as  
possible for my contribution, all i'm saying is illegal aliens and  
the pro-groups use this act to make sure hospitals treat them, you  
have taxi drivers in mexico driving across the border to drop off  
patients in san diego hospitals, but on the other hand we have this  
homeless dumping going on.  that's specifically the inequality i'm  
talking about that is almost surely engineered to some degree,  
otherwise you'd see stories of illegal alien dumping too.

sure it's about economics, but that's not the point.  no one should  
be denied care if they're that sick.  and what makes anyone think  
there will be any kind of fair investigation into this?  i know i've  
definitely heard stories of homeless dumping before in the news, and  
never ever hear anything more about it.

anyone thought of contacting the hospital directly to ask them WTF?    
a presbyterian hospital huh.  i sure as HELL wouldn't want to spend  
any of my money there if these allegations are true.

http://www.hollywoodpresbyterian.com/contactus.asp

a valentine's day psy-party
::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::

Valentine's Day is for romance and fun, and happiness with the
knowledge that you have loved ones in this life. What better way to
celebrate than with a killer underground party?

We'd like to share this year's Valentine's Day with you, our friends
and family, by inviting you to a very special event at a very special
place. Featuring some of San Francisco's best psychedelic trance DJs,
as well as excellent sound and deco. We hope that you will join us on
Saturday, February 10th, and be one of our BELOVED.

CYBERT
TANDAVA
KJ
SENTIENT
KODE IV
DOUGLAS

KNOW-AUDIO

References: <20070117193958.43468.qmail@web60812.mail.yahoo.com>

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
From: Nyc Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Some cool mods for the computer geeks

About 5 years ago one of the Ops Geeks at work showed up with a MB that 
he just bought that had a 2 gig flash memory BIOS installed.

When I asked him why he said he was going to drop the entire Linux 
kernel into it and when I asked why about that he said it's going to 
turn it into an instant on box with no boot times.

Ever since then I've wanted to do that myself.

Turns out somebody already has:
http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=-51784544344753709
http://techreport.com/reviews/2006q1/gigabyte-iram/index.x?pg=1

Building high end boxes that are pure solid state HDs is going to be a 
nice business for somebody, (I'll do it if somebody here wants to back 
me on this), but they better hurry because with prices dropping like a 
brick on flash memory this will be standard on all new boxes sold in 5 
to 7 years from now, at most.

Biggest issue, besides price, is going to be licking the write/rewrite 
limits of flash memory, but with flash being so cheap at that time, if 
the w/r problem isn't solved people will just transfer their data and 
replace the flash chips at regular intervals.

Goodbye whirring HDs, I can't wait.

~nyc

> original manufacturer)
>
> I then programmed the LCD to display song/artist track names and to
> say "Welcome to the Osteen media center" when I first turn it on. I
> also used large (slow) fans and suspended the drives using rubber
> mounts to quiet it down. It has 5.1 DTS and also analog surround,
> along with an ATI component or DVI connection to my 1080i HD tv (which
> I bought cheap and with better quality using a tube tv). I tested out
> a few different wireless keyboards and mice and finally got a decent
> logitech setup, but would rather go RF when I can find a set up cheap
> enough. I can watch videos/DVD, play games, music, winamp visuals, or
> browse the internet in my living room in 32 inches. I use an ATI RF
> remote, but prefer to just use a mouse. The only issue I have is boot
> time, I wish I could figure out a way to speed up the boot time, I
> used msconfig, but it is still at least 40 seconds.
>
> Anyway, its great for parties because you can just set up a playlist
> and put visuals on and leave it alone. It beats the hell out of those
> manufacturer media centers.
>
> On 1/16/07, Sarilion  wrote:
>   
>> no furniture, I'm surprised.  I've been thinking computer in couch
>> would be nice.
>>
>>
>> sarilion

haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever

well as some outside law enforcement agencies, of dumping patients  
and criminals on Skid Row."

wanted to be dropped on the street without a wheel chair to lie in  
his shit until he dragged himself somewhere?

"No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path  
toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and  
enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras,  
sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and  
Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can  
find in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and  
economic regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond  
what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative  
pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and work in  
squalor."
-Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of  
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will  
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

I don't.  =0A =0AAnd it can't ever be proved either way.  That's one of the=
 wonderful things about most conspiracy theories.  =0A =0AOn occasion the e=
xistence of a real conspiracy is revealed, but in general a conspiracy theo=
ry can never be disproven.  Why?  By its very nature conspiracy is secretiv=
e, and hence failure to find evidence of a conspiracy doesn't and can't eve=
r disprove its existence.  Perhaps the conspiracy has just been successful =
in concealing itself right?  Maybe the evdence against the conspiracy has b=
een fabricated?  Who can say.=0A =0A"Not that the incredulous person doesn'=
t believe in anything. It's just that he doesn't believe in everything."=0A=
 -- Casaubon, in Umberto Eco's Focault's Pendulum=0A =0ASee also http://en.=
wikipedia.org/wiki/Falsifiable=0A =0ANote that this doesn't mean there are =
no evil conspiracies, its just that it is pretty unlikely that you are goin=
g to be the one to discover and expose them.  =0A =0A"Everybody who has eve=
r worked for a corporation knows that corporations conspire all the time. P=
oliticians conspire all the time, pot-dealers conspire not to get caught by=
 the narcs, the world is full of conspiracies. Conspiracy is natural primat=
e behavior."=0A-- Robert Anton Wilson=0A=0AI'm conspiring right now to make=
 the world a better place than it was when I woke up.   How about you? =0AP=

Subject: Re: [sfraves] homeless dumping

On Feb 10, 2007, at 11:36 AM, Nyc Alberts wrote:

> 90% of the mentally ill people that then President Ronald Reagan  
> dumped on the street in the mid 1980's are no longer with us.
>
> They didn't go back to their families and they didn't go back into  
> the hospitals, since they were never re-opened, which means that,  
> oh they're dead.
>
> Which places Reagan right in between Adolph Hitler and Pol Pot in  
> the 'how many of your own people can you kill category.'

Well- let's be sure to make a distinction here- without judging  
either way any right/wrong aspect of that, he didn't "kill" anyone-  
to compare that to Hitler and Pol Pot or Stalin for that matter is  
ridiculous.

He returned said people to their own devices.

And distasteful as it is, the only way to advance a society is  
through the promotion of it's most beneficial members and the culling  
of it's most useless.
The nicer alternative to fratricide is thus the removal of support  
systems for those that can not "help themselves".

Any feeling man will find it unsavory, but it is a truth nonetheless.

X-FiveAngle-MailScanner-Information: Please contact FiveAngle for more information

X-MailScanner-From: scosol@scosol.org
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] homeless dumping

On Feb 10, 2007, at 2:25 PM, Apollo wrote:
>
> Sometime, Nathan, you can be such an annoying troll.  Springer is  
> the hospital spokesperson.  What do you expect him to say:  "We  
> were just dumping trash"?
>
I'm not sure how I can be called a "troll" for simply posting an  
excerpt from the linked article that it seemed the initial  
commentators seemed to have missed, but that's your prerogative I  
suppose.

As for the hospital's statement, yes it is exactly inline with what I  
would expect.  We all know there are two sides to every story, but if  
you're asking me whether I initially put more faith in the statements  
of a hospital or in the statements of a couple homeless crackhead  
witnesses, it's probably obvious which way I lean.  Likely the truth  
is somewhere in the middle.

> Do you really think, as Springer suggested, this homeless  
> paraplegic wanted to be dropped on the street without a wheel chair  
> to lie in his shit until he dragged himself somewhere?

You've dealt with the homeless on many occasions I presume- as  
someone else stated, the dismantling of public mental-health  
facilities has left the insane to end up in three places: dead, the  
streets, or jail.  You're likely familiar with the triage system as  
well?  Those that would likely survive with or without help are given  
no help.  Those that would likely *not* survive with or without help  
are also given no help.  Instead, efforts are focused on those that  
will likely survive with help, but will likely perish without.  This  
system is usually instituted in a time of crisis.  I would wager that  
both the police departments and the hospitals in Los Angeles are in a  
state of crisis.  Even if the events occurred exactly as the  
witnesses describe, the hospital's actions are still morally  
defensible.  The hospital is not a shelter.  Its duty is to provide  
care to those in need, then send them back where they came from as  
quickly as possible, to make room for others in need.  Perhaps this  
man was judged to be in the "beyond help" category.  An unfortunate  
circumstance for sure, but it's not the hospital's actions that are  
responsible here, it's the cause of the state of crisis that is  
responsible.

--
"Jupiter accepts your offer..."
