Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Some cool mods for the computer geeks


I saw the first solid state drives in '98.  They had a 15 second faster 
boot than standard.

The only benefit you get is for drive acess times.  A lot of the boot 
process isn't involved with that aspect.  What you would get would be 
incredibly fast file saves for things like video editing and any large 
files you need to read/write.

At 12:52 PM 2/10/2007, Nyc Alberts wrote:
>Building high end boxes that are pure solid state HDs is going to be a 
>nice business for somebody, (I'll do it if somebody here wants to back me 
>on this), but they better hurry because with prices dropping like a brick 
>on flash memory this will be standard on all new boxes sold in 5 to 7 
>years from now, at most.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Some cool mods for the computer geeks


That was popular in teh dos days to copy a few files into a ramdrive.  Most 
of us didn't have rgar much to spare, but it was useful.

Back in my Apple ][ days I had a full meg on my machine, so I would set up 
a 512k ramdrive, and copy the OS and many tool from flopping onto teh ram 
drive at boot.  Once I did that I never had to access the floppy anymore, 
and since I was running at 7MHz, well, it was VERY fast.

Mind you, Apple ][e stock was 128k and 1MHz.

Still have that machine too.  runs great.

At 02:11 PM 2/10/2007, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>This was back when most personal computers just had a 5 1/4 floppy and no 
>hard disk.  I seem to recall RAM drive sizes of 64 and 128K back then.

"Our job this day is to become part of the answer to the world's  
immense and protracted suffering rather than continuing our ancient  
task of being part of the difficulty."

Hugh Prather - Author, minister

=
"There is suffering in life, and there are defeats. No one can avoid  
them. But it's better to lose some of the battles in the struggles  
for your dreams than to be defeated without ever knowing what you're  
fighting for"

Paulo Coelho

=
"Suffering and joy teach us, if we allow them, how to make the leap  
of empathy, which transports us into the soul and heart of another  
person. ln those transparent moments we know other people's joys and  
sorrows, and we care about their concerns as if they were our own."

Fritz Williams

=
"...when we finally know we are dying, and all other sentient beings  
are dying with us, we start to have a burning, almost heartbreaking  
sense of the
fragility and preciousness of each moment and each being, and from  
this can grow a deep, clear, limitless compassion for all being."

Sogyal Rinpoche



--Apple-Mail-1--403746230--

You know how, during the Preflight Safety Demonstration, flight attendants 
tell you that in the event of an emergency, oxygen masks will pop out of the 
ceiling? My question is: Who wants oxygen? If I'm going to be in an 
emergency seven miles up, I want nitrous oxide, followed immediately by 
Emergency Intravenous Beverage Cart Service, so that I and my fellow 
passengers can be as relaxed as possible. ("Wow! Those are some beautiful 
engine flames!")

-- Dave Barry

Shatter wrote:
>
> It's called Eugenics now.
Yeah and really smart people have fucked up their careers and reps by 
subscribing to it:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Shockley#Beliefs_about_populations_and_genetics

The best answer to the question:

"How did a brown eyed, brown haired, dude convince a nation that the

I'd Rather Be A Matin' Than A Hatin' ~ Me

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

"Ha ha!  Ever had the feeling you've been cheated?" ~ J. Lydon, SF, 1978

Nathan, did you just say that?

How did you get into a rave scene that subscribes to the notion of PURL, 
(ok, ok, plur, but I think PURL sounds better), anyways?

In my youth, when I was setting out on a study of the classics of our 
Western civilization I was raking leaves in our backyard with my dad one 
afternoon and he pointed out that the 100 books I was going to study 
were much like the acorns that we were picking up.

An oak tree will spew out millions of acorn seeds in the course of its 
life and only an incredibly few will take root and grow into another tree.

Same thing with people.

Here's the thing.....

There is NO way of knowing which seed is going to grow into a mighty 
oak, Nathan, and which human is going to advance the human race.

No way.

None.

To pretend to say that you know that, Nathan, is a cheap rhetorical 
trick that attempts to put you on the level of god, which you, and I, 
are most decidedly not.

Moron.

Get a clue, you.

It makes me ill to know that there are millions in The United States of 
America, (what's left of it), that have been brainwashed and 
indoctrinated to think like you.

You're too old, and too far gone, for any of this to sink into your head 
full of mush, so I'm not going to waste your precious time, or mine, 
trying to convince you of anything, but I will tell you this.

You can't have it both ways, bitch.

You can't agree with a "man" like President George W. Bush who says that 
"It's important to promote a culture of life" and say what you're saying 
here.

Nathan, either "All life is precious" or it isn't.

Try to hold all your thoughts on this subject, in what passes for your 
brain, without having it explode, m'kay?

Then go watch "Cashin' In" on Fox News and leave us alone.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR - Fernet Branca - SF is top Consumer LOL


after hearing all this talk, i picked up a bottle of
Fernet-Branca at my local Beverages & More! (aka
BevMo) down here in The OC.  I had a small glass of it
mixed with Pepsi last night and I have to say it's
quite nice.  I agree with the earlier assessment that
the first couple of sips make you think "What am I
doing?" but by the bottom of the glass, you find that
it was really a nice drink.  I stuck the bottle in the
freezer, as it seemed like it's best when highly
chilled.

Thanks, SFR! :D

Subject: Re: [sfraves] homeless dumping - bumfights !

From: "Nathan Seven" <scosol@scosol.org>
To: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Subject: Re: [sfraves] homeless dumping


> On Feb 10, 2007, at 2:25 PM, Apollo wrote:
>> Do you really think, as Springer suggested, this homeless  paraplegic 
>> wanted to be dropped on the street without a wheel chair  to lie in his 
>> shit until he dragged himself somewhere?
>
> You've dealt with the homeless on many occasions I presume- as  someone 
> else stated, the dismantling of public mental-health  facilities has left 
> the insane to end up in three places: dead, the  streets, or jail.

I'll have to side with Mr. 7 on this one.  I've witnessed an avalanche of 
poor judgment on the part of the homeless compared to that of hospital 
workers.

Some very listers may recall an episode outside Anu where Mr. 7, Chester 
Copperpot, and I were all waiting for Mr. Phelan, Origami, and other friends 
to emerge for the continuance of that nights festivities after a wonderfully 
Folded evening.  Inexcusably intoxicated, the three of us were sparing with 
each other with the goal of simply hitting each other on the shoulder 
without exposing our shoulder and getting hit in the shoulder first. 
Childish drunken high-school antics assured, but what happened next clearly 
demonstrates how out of touch many homeless are with reality...

A large transient-looking man approached me and began to hunker down with 
his dukes up in the sparing position.  Those familiar with the SOMA district 
at 6th street just off Market will know the incorrigible nature of 
post-bar-closure transients approaching with  the most ludicrous stories or 
behavior in their attempts at separating you from the  few gin-soaked 
dollars left in your shirt pocket after a night of house music and G-n-T's. 
I thought to myself, "oh look, the guy wants to join in with hopes that 
we'll laugh, or get annoyed, or <insert any possible reaction here> and give 
him some money..."   No sooner did I finish this thought did I begin to 
regain focus on the big man in front of me, only to instead find a huge fist 
clocking me dead in the face.

What happened next is anybody's guess.  For all intents and purposes I am a 
happy and benevolent person.  However, I do believe in the most basic 
inalienable rights one has to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness and 
anyone who deny's me that right, will be dealt with swiftly and decisively. 
I don't recall anything after the blow to my head except Mr. 7 and Mr. 
Copperpot, under each  of my arms, lifting me up from the ground where now 
cowled a shaking frightened person where once a large menacing man once 
stood.

The next morning, while crafting a splint to secure the broken pinky knuckle 
on my "throwing" hand, the lack of sanity was the only thing I cursed of 
toward the man I had beaten to the ground the night before.

If anyone has a problem believing the claims of the hospital worker in this 
story, I have a knuckle on my right fist that is about twice the size of 
that on my left that I think you should have a meet with... I'm more than 
happy to ablidge.

-=dave

ps- crazy homeless people are g r a t e !

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any

haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever

From: Nyc Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] homeless dumping

This thread, and these psychotic responses, by you, Dave, and others, 
are growing tiresome, but I'll answer you the best I can.

Let's start with I don't need to cite *a goddamned thing* to you, Dave, 
or anyone else, on this, but since you want an authoritative response, 
I'll tell you one, m'kay?

Then come and try and smear me and tell me I'm the one that's full of shit.

Fair enough?

When I moved to DC in late 2002, from Palo Alto, to live with my 
Attorney girlfriend in Bethesda, MD, I would visit her at  the  Court 
House she worked at, (the site of the Scooter Libby trial that's 
currently underway), at Third & Constitution, NW, in DC, where the 
dominant feature of the landscape is the United States Capitol Building.

Apollo used to have a sig line that read

"Music is Prophecy"

Here's an example of that for you, Dave.

There's a line from a Clash song, Car Jamming", from 1982, that goes:

"Ventilation units where towers
Meet the streets
The ragged stand in bags
Soaking heat up through their feet

This was their only kindness
And it was accidental too...."

February 2003 was the coldest winter in DC history that has ever been 
recorded, ever since they began keeping temperature records in the 
1860s,  and every day that month that I went to go see my girl at her 
job at the DC Superior Courthouse, by the US Capitol Building, I was 
greeted by the sight, while in direct line-of-sight of the US Capitol 
Building, of DC's mentally ill lying down on top of the steam grates 
that were on the on the sidewalk that released the excess heat from the 
Courthouses, in an attempt by them to stave off the bitter cold of that 
winter.

Every day that month was like wading through a frozen hurricane.

And I saw this little tableau of human misery on the streets of The 
Capital of the Wealthiest Nation on Earth each and every fucking day.

Since it was steam that was coming off those grates, they weren't going 
to stay dry, and no doubt in some of the more fragile cases of people 
doing this they were going to get sick and certainly some of them would 
die from the exposure and the rapid shifts between hot and cold air.

Disgusting.

Makes me ashamed to be a cheap ass American that puts dollars over lives.

I drew her attention to this behavior by these men and women, and the 
fact that there are also mentally ill on practically every street corner 
of our Nation's Capital begging for their lives, and getting stepped 
over and ignored by our Nation's Policy Setting Elites, and she told me 
what I was seeing was nothing.

That in the mid 1980s when Reagan and David Stockman closed the Mental 
Hospitals, the most charitable way to describe the scene on the streets 
of DC was that it looked like exactly like the poor section of India's 
Calcutta, and that there were TEN TIMES as many people on the streets of 
DC at that time then I was seeing today.

Also, when they closed those Hospitals what they did is they took the 
patients out to all sort of remote areas in buses, without telling them 
what they were doing, and just put them out of the buses onto the street 
and drove off, leaving them to fend for themselves without so much a 
dime in their pockets to call their relatives.

I don't know how old you are, but my guess is that you're somewhere 
around the age of 30, which means that when all this crap went down over 
20 years ago you must have been around 10 years old, or so, and probably 
don't remember just how big this flood of mentally ill Americans was on 
the city streets of our Nation.

It was huge.

Overwhelming in fact.

One of the more disgraceful acts ever perpetrated by our US Government, 
much worse than the internment of our Japanese citizenry during WW II, 
since at least we kept the majority of those people alive.

Most of those mentally ill people have vanished from the streets today, 
a good 90% of them, and again *I will assert* that since they weren't 
taken back into the hospitals, since we are to cheap to re-open them, 
and since the bulk of them were not taken back by their families, that 
they are dead.

Murdered, in fact, by our own Government.

And, Dave, I have exactly zero need to "prove" any of this to you.

Whatever, you have no shame about any of this, to the point of being 
sociopathic, so it's pointless to get you to see any of this.

I will tell you this, what happened to the mentally ill in America, over 
the course of these past two decades, in this war of homicide by 
attrition, is only a prelude of what's to come, Dave.

Now that we're done with them, and there aren't so many left to kill, 
we're going to start working our way up the food chain.

Don't know if your folks are still around, but if they are, and you have 
a shred of human decency in you, it will behoove you to stand over their 
shoulder while they fill out their Medicare Plan D Forms so you can be 
sure that they'll be adequately provided for.

I'd do it if I were you, as an act of self-preservation, because it's 
only going to be a matter of time before we start going after the 'free 
spirits' of our culture, people like ravers, and you're going to need 
the practice in sticking up for yourself.

Then you can take your heartless attitude and go enlist and serve in 
Iraq, which I'm sure you'll enjoy, Dave, because you'll find a lot of 
like-minded individuals that you can share your hatred of human life with.

Peisces,

~nyc




~nyc

I'd Rather Be A Matin' Than A Hatin' ~ Me

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

"Ha ha!  Ever had the feeling you've been cheated?" ~ J. Lydon, SF, 1978

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: our own devices

My favorite bit of Nathan's post is the part of returning people "to their =
own devices".  What does that really mean?=0A=0AMost of us if left complete=
ly to our "own devices" would simply starve to death.  That is if we didn't=
 die of thirst or loneliness first.=0A=0AEven the most independent person, =
a radical survivalist say, uses items built and designed by other people.  =
Only a person living like an animal can truthfully be said to be relying on=
 "their own devices" and even they still depend on others for their existen=
ce.  The rest of us, if we believe we are really independent, are just fool=
ing ourselves or faking it.  The truthis that we need each other for almost=
 every aspect of our daily lives.=0A=0AThink about what it would mean to tr=
uly be without the help of even a single other human being.  Consider your =
clothes, shoes, job, and the food you eat.  Books.  Electricity.  Music.  H=
eat.  Water.  Where do these things come from?=0A=0AUnless you grow, harves=
t, store, and prepare all of your food yourself, every meal you have depend=
s on other people's efforts.  Your clothes were likely made half way around=
 the world by someone you've never even met.  Something as simple as readil=
y available safe drinking water depends on the efforts of hundreds or thous=
ands of other people for its existence.  Most of us just conveniently don't=
 want to think about these other people and how they help us each day.  =0A=
=0AIn Buddhism we call it "co-dependent arising".   See also: http://theidp=
roject.com/index.htm=0A=0AAnyone that thinks they are actually self reliant=
 in this sort of way is simply deluded.  They are lost in the forest and ar=
e in need of rescue.  =0A=0AInstead of responding in anger reach out a hand=
 to help them. When someone is offensive or disgusting to us, this is much =
easier said than done of course, but it is still a worthy goal.=0A=0ASimple=
 human kindness.  Try it and see.=0A=0APeace,=0A=0APeter=0A=0A=0A=0A=0A----=

what he did as President to the mentally ill when he was Governor, 
(surprised my CSPAN junkie Godmother in Berkeley never told me about 
it), but it doesn't surprise me, it's a pattern with these people.

About a year after Katrina and the murder of New Orleans by bureaucratic 
incompetence that went far past anything Michael Brown did, or didn't 
do, I came across this year 2000 piece on the then Repukelican 
Presidential candidate, Governor Bush of Texas, written by Gail Sheehy 
that ran in Vanity Fair:

http://gailsheehy.com/Politics/polimain_bush3.html

It's super long, so if you start about 7/8ths of the way down at the 
sentences that starts

"Odessa, Texas, is the backyard of Midlandin every way. It is where the 
dirty services of the local oil and petrochemical industries are 
performed. The industry executives live in Midland. The working people 
live in Odessa."

You'll see what happened in New Orleans was no accident.

These people are monsters that will never be held to account.

At least not by the American Public, a full 30% that still believe that 
Bush and Cheney are doing a good job of not driving the country over a 
cliff.

How did we get to this point in just 6 short years?

And why, oh why, didn't George Bush just settle for being Commissioner 
of Baseball, like he originally planned, instead of becoming selected 
President?

On Feb 11, 2007, at 12:47 PM, Nyc Alberts wrote:

> This thread, and these psychotic responses, by you, Dave, and  
> others, are growing tiresome, but I'll answer you the best I can.
>
> Let's start with I don't need to cite *a goddamned thing* to you,  
> Dave, or anyone else, on this, but since you want an authoritative  
> response, I'll tell you one, m'kay?
>
> Then come and try and smear me and tell me I'm the one that's full  
> of shit.
>
> Fair enough?
>
> When I moved to DC in late 2002, from Palo Alto, to live with my  
> Attorney girlfriend in Bethesda, MD, I would visit her at  the   
> Court House she worked at, (the site of the Scooter Libby trial  
> that's currently underway), at Third & Constitution, NW, in DC,  
> where the dominant feature of the landscape is the United States  
> Capitol Building.
>
> Apollo used to have a sig line that read
>
> "Music is Prophecy"
>
> Here's an example of that for you, Dave.
>
> There's a line from a Clash song, Car Jamming", from 1982, that goes:
>
> "Ventilation units where towers
> Meet the streets
> The ragged stand in bags
> Soaking heat up through their feet
>
> This was their only kindness
> And it was accidental too...."
>
> February 2003 was the coldest winter in DC history that has ever  
> been recorded, ever since they began keeping temperature records in  
> the 1860s,  and every day that month that I went to go see my girl  
> at her job at the DC Superior Courthouse, by the US Capitol  
> Building, I was greeted by the sight, while in direct line-of-sight  
> of the US Capitol Building, of DC's mentally ill lying down on top  
> of the steam grates that were on the on the sidewalk that released  
> the excess heat from the Courthouses, in an attempt by them to  
> stave off the bitter cold of that winter.
>
> Every day that month was like wading through a frozen hurricane.
>
> And I saw this little tableau of human misery on the streets of The  
> Capital of the Wealthiest Nation on Earth each and every fucking day.
>
> Since it was steam that was coming off those grates, they weren't  
> going to stay dry, and no doubt in some of the more fragile cases  
> of people doing this they were going to get sick and certainly some  
> of them would die from the exposure and the rapid shifts between  
> hot and cold air.
>
> Disgusting.
>
> Makes me ashamed to be a cheap ass American that puts dollars over  
> lives.
>
> I drew her attention to this behavior by these men and women, and  
> the fact that there are also mentally ill on practically every  
> street corner of our Nation's Capital begging for their lives, and  
> getting stepped over and ignored by our Nation's Policy Setting  
> Elites, and she told me what I was seeing was nothing.
>
> That in the mid 1980s when Reagan and David Stockman closed the  
> Mental Hospitals, the most charitable way to describe the scene on  
> the streets of DC was that it looked like exactly like the poor  
> section of India's Calcutta, and that there were TEN TIMES as many  
> people on the streets of DC at that time then I was seeing today.
>
> Also, when they closed those Hospitals what they did is they took  
> the patients out to all sort of remote areas in buses, without  
> telling them what they were doing, and just put them out of the  
> buses onto the street and drove off, leaving them to fend for  
> themselves without so much a dime in their pockets to call their  
> relatives.
>
> I don't know how old you are, but my guess is that you're somewhere  
> around the age of 30, which means that when all this crap went down  
> over 20 years ago you must have been around 10 years old, or so,  
> and probably don't remember just how big this flood of mentally ill  
> Americans was on the city streets of our Nation.
>
> It was huge.
>
> Overwhelming in fact.
>
> One of the more disgraceful acts ever perpetrated by our US  
> Government, much worse than the internment of our Japanese  
> citizenry during WW II, since at least we kept the majority of  
> those people alive.
>
> Most of those mentally ill people have vanished from the streets  
> today, a good 90% of them, and again *I will assert* that since  
> they weren't taken back into the hospitals, since we are to cheap  
> to re-open them, and since the bulk of them were not taken back by  
> their families, that they are dead.
>
> Murdered, in fact, by our own Government.
>
> And, Dave, I have exactly zero need to "prove" any of this to you.
>
> Whatever, you have no shame about any of this, to the point of  
> being sociopathic, so it's pointless to get you to see any of this.
>
> I will tell you this, what happened to the mentally ill in America,  
> over the course of these past two decades, in this war of homicide  
> by attrition, is only a prelude of what's to come, Dave.
>
> Now that we're done with them, and there aren't so many left to  
> kill, we're going to start working our way up the food chain.
>
> Don't know if your folks are still around, but if they are, and you  
> have a shred of human decency in you, it will behoove you to stand  
> over their shoulder while they fill out their Medicare Plan D Forms  
> so you can be sure that they'll be adequately provided for.
>
> I'd do it if I were you, as an act of self-preservation, because  
> it's only going to be a matter of time before we start going after  
> the 'free spirits' of our culture, people like ravers, and you're  
> going to need the practice in sticking up for yourself.
>
> Then you can take your heartless attitude and go enlist and serve  
> in Iraq, which I'm sure you'll enjoy, Dave, because you'll find a  
> lot of like-minded individuals that you can share your hatred of  
> human life with.

I'd Rather Be A Matin' Than A Hatin' ~ Me

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

"Ha ha!  Ever had the feeling you've been cheated?" ~ J. Lydon, SF, 1978

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  THEY THOUGHT THEY WERE FREE

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

"What no one seemed to notice was the ever widening gap between the  
government and the people. And it became always wider.....the whole  
process of its coming into being, was above all diverting, it  
provided an excuse not to think....for people who did not want to  
think anyway gave us some dreadful, fundamental things to think  
about.....and kept us so busy with continuous changes and 'crises'  
and so fascinated.....by the machinations of the 'national enemies,'  
without and within, that we had no time to think about these dreadful  
things that were growing, little by little, all around us.....

"Each step was so small, so inconsequential, so well explained or, on  
occasion, 'regretted,' that unless one understood what the whole  
thing was in principle, what all these 'little measures'.....must  
some day lead to, one no more saw it developing from day to day than  
a farmer in his field sees the corn growing.....Each act is worse  
than the last, but only a little worse. You wait for the next and the  
next.

"You wait for one great shocking occasion, thinking that others, when  
such a shock comes, will join you in resisting somehow. You don't  
want to act, or even talk, alone.....you don't want to 'go out of  
your way to make trouble.' But the one great shocking occasion, when  
tens or hundreds or thousands will join with you, never comes.

"That's the difficulty. The forms are all there, all untouched, all  
reassuring, the houses, the shops, the jobs, the mealtimes, the  
visits, the concerts, the cinema, the holidays. But the spirit, which  
you never noticed because you made the lifelong mistake of  
identifying it with the forms, is changed. Now you live in a world of  
hate and fear, and the people who hate and fear do not even know it  
themselves, when everyone is transformed, no one is transformed.

"You have accepted things you would not have accepted five years ago,  
a year ago, things your father.....could never have imagined."

Milton Mayer, They Thought They Were Free, The Germans, 1938-45  
(Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1955)





apollo@speakeasy.org

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo

Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm



"No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path  
toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and  
enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras,  
sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and  
Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can  
find in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and  
economic regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond  
what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative  
pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and work in  
squalor."
-Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of  
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will  
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--Apple-Mail-2--334213936--

As they stirred Heaven and Earth, they combined to one,
and everything was everyone and each one was all.

and everything was everyone and each one was all.

Why must "your own devices" be so rigidly defined as the extreme (and most
simple) example ?

I attribute my ability to interact with others in an effort to trade
something I have that is valuable to others, for something they have that is
valuable to me, as one of my own "devices" that I rely on for my
livelihood.  My relatively good instincts, relatively sound reasoning,
relatively decent self-control, relatively high intelligence, relatively
high tolerance for ignorance, my command of physics, and my right foot (!),
all my own "devices", without which I doubt I would be as capable as I am of
surviving in the society I live in.

That said, I see others who are not so fortunate.  Most just need an
occasional helping hand.  We have all been there at one time or another.
Others have proven themselves beyond the reproach of others and instead rely
on their unscrupulous ability to take advantage of systems designed to help
those in need... that ability is one of *their* "devices" which, while
unsavory to those who detest the undermining it does, is a trait that allows
them to continue to survive, and sometimes even thrive.

Now there is one more group to mention -the "others"- whose "devices" are
skewed away from those basic survival instincts due to social or
physiological factors -those with "devices" of survival that fall below the
threshold required to do just that- who will unfortunately suffer the most
when the supply of spoon-fed safety systems is removed.  The systems may
have become overloaded due to undermining from the unscrupulous, neglect or
even wilful disregard from those benefactors who make up the first group of
which I and most of you belong.  The benefactors may have fallen below their
own threshold of tolerance due to their survival "devices" becoming
triggered but whatever the reason, make no mistake, in the face of being
left to *their* own "devices", members of this last group will no doubt
suffer.

None of us want those mentally of physically incapable of providing for
themselves to suffer, but with the removal of help, they will.  You can
accept this truth or not but those who that cry foul from the rooftops
should look to themselves for resolution rather than to others for blame.
The next time you're walking down Beale St between Mission and Howard
lifting your collar as a filter to shield your lungs from the wretched
stench of urine with the faint wafts of delousing solution, think to
yourselves how you can help.  I can tell you straight away that your vote
for the presidency should be the last action on your mind.  If you think
otherwise, I have news for you; no matter how much you might wish to buy
peace of mind with your dollar, you're living a fucking like.

Ask yourself, have you allowed a transient to squat in your "work" van while
it sat parked in your driveway unused, telling them they could stay there if
they kept and eye on your property ?  Why not ?  Ask yourself how you would
feel if that transient then took advantage of the situation and turned on
you and stole from you ?  Now take this example and repeat it or some
situation like it every year and a half or so, always giving the
underprivileged "another benefit of the doubt" and invariably getting the
short end of the stick, let time pass, then do it over again ?  After you've
done that, then maybe your argument might hold some worth to me over Mr.
7's.  Until then, look inside for solution before looking to others for
blame.

acting locally is g r a t e !

-=dave

ps- yo Nathan, that van still parked in your yard ? :-P


On 2/11/07, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
> My favorite bit of Nathan's post is the part of returning people "to their
> own devices".  What does that really mean?
>
> Most of us if left completely to our "own devices" would simply starve to
> death.  That is if we didn't die of thirst or loneliness first.
>
> Even the most independent person, a radical survivalist say, uses items
> built and designed by other people.  Only a person living like an animal can
> truthfully be said to be relying on "their own devices" and even they still
> depend on others for their existence.  The rest of us, if we believe we are
> really independent, are just fooling ourselves or faking it.  The truthis
> that we need each other for almost every aspect of our daily lives.
>
> Think about what it would mean to truly be without the help of even a
> single other human being.  Consider your clothes, shoes, job, and the food
> you eat.  Books.  Electricity.  Music.  Heat.  Water.  Where do these things
> come from?
>
> Unless you grow, harvest, store, and prepare all of your food yourself,
> every meal you have depends on other people's efforts.  Your clothes were
> likely made half way around the world by someone you've never even
> met.  Something as simple as readily available safe drinking water depends
> on the efforts of hundreds or thousands of other people for its
> existence.  Most of us just conveniently don't want to think about these
> other people and how they help us each day.
>
> In Buddhism we call it "co-dependent arising".   See also:
> http://theidproject.com/index.htm
>
> Anyone that thinks they are actually self reliant in this sort of way is
> simply deluded.  They are lost in the forest and are in need of rescue.
>
> Instead of responding in anger reach out a hand to help them. When someone
> is offensive or disgusting to us, this is much easier said than done of
> course, but it is still a worthy goal.
>
> Simple human kindness.  Try it and see.
>
> Peace,
>
> Peter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:  THEY THOUGHT THEY WERE FREE

In the winter of the year of 1994, (218 years after the founding of the 
experiment in democracy that is the republic that is The United States 
of America), the prison population passed the 1,000,000 incarcerated 
American citizens mark, for the very first time.

In the winter of 2006, a scant 12 years later, the prison population  of 
The United States of America stood at the threshold of crossing the 
7,000,000 incarcerated American citizens mark.

Do the math.

Shit's not creeping up on us anymore, it's at full gallop, bitches, with 
no end in sight.

Moore's Law doesn't just apply to computers, y'know, it's got some real 
world applications as well.

heheheh.

If, former Nixon White House Counsel, John Dean's, last book is to be 
believed, then it is a given that an Authoritarian Presidential 
candidate, (such as one Rudy Ghouliani, former Mayor of NYC), already 
has 25% of the vote in their back pocket, which means they only need 
another 26% of the vote, on top of that 25%, in 2008 to do to the USA 
what he did to NYC under his reign.

This stands more of a chance than happening, than not, thanks to Father 
Ted Haggard blowing up the Evangelical Right as a voting bloc, due to 
his whole speed/male hooker thing.

My bags are already packed and my 3, legal, Passports are current, 
(German, Slovenian, and American), and if you've got a lick of sense, 
and any sense of self-preservation, if I were you, I'd start making 
plans like I've done, because a Ghouliani Administration will make the 
Bush years look like the Lollapalooza Festival, before it went all 
commercial, and shit, man.

But, hey, feel free to blow me off and say what I'm saying is "hogwash" 
because you're too damn lazy to google this crap yourself.

You'll see, and time will tell, as it always has, won't it?

~nyc




Apollo wrote:
> "What no one seemed to notice was the ever widening gap between the 
> government and the people. And it became always wider.....the whole 
> process of its coming into being, was above all diverting, it provided 
> an excuse not to think....for people who did not want to think anyway 
> gave us some dreadful, fundamental things to think about.....and kept 
> us so busy with continuous changes and 'crises' and so 
> fascinated.....by the machinations of the 'national enemies,' without 
> and within, that we had no time to think about these dreadful things 
> that were growing, little by little, all around us.....
>
> "Each step was so small, so inconsequential, so well explained or, on 
> occasion, 'regretted,' that unless one understood what the whole thing 
> was in principle, what all these 'little measures'.....must some day 
> lead to, one no more saw it developing from day to day than a farmer 
> in his field sees the corn growing.....Each act is worse than the 
> last, but only a little worse. You wait for the next and the next.
>
> "You wait for one great shocking occasion, thinking that others, when 
> such a shock comes, will join you in resisting somehow. You don't want 
> to act, or even talk, alone.....you don't want to 'go out of your way 
> to make trouble.' But the one great shocking occasion, when tens or 
> hundreds or thousands will join with you, never comes.
>
> "That's the difficulty. The forms are all there, all untouched, all 
> reassuring, the houses, the shops, the jobs, the mealtimes, the 
> visits, the concerts, the cinema, the holidays. But the spirit, which 
> you never noticed because you made the lifelong mistake of identifying 
> it with the forms, is changed. Now you live in a world of hate and 
> fear, and the people who hate and fear do not even know it themselves, 
> when everyone is transformed, no one is transformed.
>
> "You have accepted things you would not have accepted five years ago, 
> a year ago, things your father.....could never have imagined."
>
> Milton Mayer, They Thought They Were Free, The Germans, 1938-45 
> (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1955)

> "No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path 
> toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and 
> enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras, 
> sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and 
> Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can find 
> in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and economic 
> regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond what is 
> needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative pleasures -- of 
> life while consigning the masses to live and work in squalor."
> -Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.
>
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of 
> the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will 
> gradually become visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>
>
>

I'd Rather Be A Matin' Than A Hatin' ~ Me

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

On 2/11/07, SE/30 <grindingbassline@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> Why must "your own devices" be so rigidly defined as the extreme (and most
> simple) example ?
>
> I attribute my ability to interact with others in an effort to trade
> something I have that is valuable to others, for something they have that is
> valuable to me, as one of my own "devices" that I rely on for my
> livelihood.  My relatively good instincts, relatively sound reasoning,
> relatively decent self-control, relatively high intelligence, relatively
> high tolerance for ignorance, my command of physics, and my right foot (!),
> all my own "devices", without which I doubt I would be as capable as I am of
> surviving in the society I live in.
>
> That said, I see others who are not so fortunate.  Most just need an
> occasional helping hand.  We have all been there at one time or another.
> Others have proven themselves beyond the reproach of others and instead rely
> on their unscrupulous ability to take advantage of systems designed to help
> those in need... that ability is one of *their* "devices" which, while
> unsavory to those who detest the undermining it does, is a trait that allows
> them to continue to survive, and sometimes even thrive.
>
> Now there is one more group to mention -the "others"- whose "devices" are
> skewed away from those basic survival instincts due to social or
> physiological factors -those with "devices" of survival that fall below the
> threshold required to do just that- who will unfortunately suffer the most
> when the supply of spoon-fed safety systems is removed.  The systems may
> have become overloaded due to undermining from the unscrupulous, neglect or
> even wilful disregard from those benefactors who make up the first group of
> which I and most of you belong.  The benefactors may have fallen below their
> own threshold of tolerance due to their survival "devices" becoming
> triggered but whatever the reason, make no mistake, in the face of being
> left to *their* own "devices", members of this last group will no doubt
> suffer.
>
> None of us want those mentally of physically incapable of providing for
> themselves to suffer, but with the removal of help, they will.  You can
> accept this truth or not but those who that cry foul from the rooftops
> should look to themselves for resolution rather than to others for blame.
> The next time you're walking down Beale St between Mission and Howard
> lifting your collar as a filter to shield your lungs from the wretched
> stench of urine with the faint wafts of delousing solution, think to
> yourselves how you can help.  I can tell you straight away that your vote
> for the presidency should be the last action on your mind.  If you think
> otherwise, I have news for you; no matter how much you might wish to buy
> peace of mind with your dollar, you're living a fucking like.
>
> Ask yourself, have you allowed a transient to squat in your "work" van
> while it sat parked in your driveway unused, telling them they could stay
> there if they kept and eye on your property ?  Why not ?  Ask yourself how
> you would feel if that transient then took advantage of the situation and
> turned on you and stole from you ?  Now take this example and repeat it or
> some situation like it every year and a half or so, always giving the
> underprivileged "another benefit of the doubt" and invariably getting the
> short end of the stick, let time pass, then do it over again ?  After you've
> done that, then maybe your argument might hold some worth to me over Mr.
> 7's.  Until then, look inside for solution before looking to others for
> blame.
>
> acting locally is g r a t e !
>
> -=dave
>
> ps- yo Nathan, that van still parked in your yard ? :-P
>
>
>  On 2/11/07, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
> >
> > My favorite bit of Nathan's post is the part of returning people "to
> > their own devices".  What does that really mean?
> >
> > Most of us if left completely to our "own devices" would simply starve
> > to death.  That is if we didn't die of thirst or loneliness first.
> >
> > Even the most independent person, a radical survivalist say, uses items
> > built and designed by other people.  Only a person living like an animal can
> > truthfully be said to be relying on "their own devices" and even they still
> > depend on others for their existence.  The rest of us, if we believe we are
> > really independent, are just fooling ourselves or faking it.  The truthis
> > that we need each other for almost every aspect of our daily lives.
> >
> > Think about what it would mean to truly be without the help of even a
> > single other human being.  Consider your clothes, shoes, job, and the food
> > you eat.  Books.  Electricity.  Music.  Heat.  Water.  Where do these things
> > come from?
> >
> > Unless you grow, harvest, store, and prepare all of your food yourself,
> > every meal you have depends on other people's efforts.  Your clothes were
> > likely made half way around the world by someone you've never even
> > met.  Something as simple as readily available safe drinking water depends
> > on the efforts of hundreds or thousands of other people for its
> > existence.  Most of us just conveniently don't want to think about these
> > other people and how they help us each day.
> >
> > In Buddhism we call it "co-dependent arising".   See also:
> > http://theidproject.com/index.htm
> >
> > Anyone that thinks they are actually self reliant in this sort of way is
> > simply deluded.  They are lost in the forest and are in need of rescue.
> >
> > Instead of responding in anger reach out a hand to help them. When
> > someone is offensive or disgusting to us, this is much easier said than done
> > of course, but it is still a worthy goal.
> >
> > Simple human kindness.  Try it and see.
> >

On 11 February 2007, Nyc Alberts wrote:

> In the winter of the year of 1994, (218 years after the founding of the 
> experiment in democracy that is the republic that is The United States of 
> America), the prison population passed the 1,000,000 incarcerated American 
> citizens mark, for the very first time.
>
> In the winter of 2006, a scant 12 years later, the prison population  of The 
> United States of America stood at the threshold of crossing the 7,000,000 
> incarcerated American citizens mark.
>
> Do the math.

Sorry Nick.  The math is wrong.
Here's the details:
http://www.ojp.usdoj.gov/bjs/pub/pdf/pjim05.pdf

June 30, 2005 saw 2,186,230 inmates.  And it was SOMEWHERE (the online 
data has a gap) between '85 (742,579) and '90 (1,146,401) when the 
1,000,000 mark was reached.  See 
http://www.ojp.usdoj.gov/bjs/pub/pdf/pam95.pdf for those details.

I agree with your earlier homeless rebutal however.

Math is right.

Both the 1994 1 million American citizen incarcerated figure and the 
2006 *7 million* American citizen incarcerated figure includes all those 
in Gulags, on parole, and on probation.

http://www.ojp.usdoj.gov/bjs/pub/press/ppus03pr.htm

I promise not to waste my time or yours on bullshit and when I'm wrong, 
please call me on it.

Thanks!

~nyc

PS: note to Dave:

Yes, I know NYC is grate!!!!!

I live here, (within line of sight of the former Twin Towers), and 
outside of Vegas, it's one of the few places on Earth you can get a 
decent ham sandwich at 3am.

But please don't confuse the two.

I'm Nyc, the worthless piece of shit person, in your view, and NYC is 
the greatest city on Earth, but not for long if the Chinese and Indians 
have any say in the matter.

Which, btw, they will, and sooner than later too.

Enjoy your time on top, while it lasts, dawg.

J.C. wrote:
> On 11 February 2007, Nyc Alberts wrote:
>
>> In the winter of the year of 1994, (218 years after the founding of 
>> the experiment in democracy that is the republic that is The United 
>> States of America), the prison population passed the 1,000,000 
>> incarcerated American citizens mark, for the very first time.
>>
>> In the winter of 2006, a scant 12 years later, the prison population  
>> of The United States of America stood at the threshold of crossing 
>> the 7,000,000 incarcerated American citizens mark.
>>
>> Do the math.

> data has a gap) between '85 (742,579) and '90 (1,146,401) when the 
> 1,000,000 mark was reached.  See 
> http://www.ojp.usdoj.gov/bjs/pub/pdf/pam95.pdf for those details.

I'd Rather Be A Matin' Than A Hatin' ~ Me

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

"Ha ha!  Ever had the feeling you've been cheated?" ~ J. Lydon, SF, 1978

correctional population in '95 vs. 6,889,800 on 12/31/2003.  SO, the 
jump you claim happened just didn't happen.  At least not at the 
magnitude you claimed.

I'd Rather Be A Matin' Than A Hatin' ~ Me

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: our own devices

I don't believe I blamed Mr. Seven or anyone else for that matter for the h=
omeless problem in that posting.  I just pointed out that few of us would a=
ctually survive for long being left "to our own devices", a turn of phrase =
which Mr. Seven used originally.  That includes both you and me.  I am sorr=
y if it is hard to hear this very fundamental truth.=0A=0ACertainly the sol=
ution to the homeless problem is complex, difficult, and challenging.  Whil=
e I agree that acting locally is a good way to start, doing something is st=
ill better than doing nothing.  I also agree that risking your own life and=
 property is a lot to ask, especially when some certainly would abuse that =
trust.  That's why a good way to start giving is by giving something you ar=
e not attached to.  Try giving out water or fruit for example.  I usually h=
ave an apple or orange in my car for this purpose.=0A=0AAs far as giving so=
meone the benefit of the doubt, it is my personal goal to give everyone I m=
eet the benefit of the doubt.  Whether it is the homeless person smelling o=
f urine, the guy that cut me off on the freeway on the way to work, or even=
 a person posting offensive racist remarks to a rave list, I try to give th=
em all the benefit of the doubt.  Sometimes I even succeed.=0A=0ABy the way=
, not all of the homeless pee on themselves or smell bad.  This is a very l=
imited and biased view of the homeless problem.  Do you really believe that=
?  Why?=0A=0AHere's an exercise.  For one week, whenever you find yourself =
thinking a negative thought about someone you interact with instead try to =
come up with a new script or story that puts them in a positive light.  May=
be that guy who cut you off on the way to work is racing home to his wife w=
ho is in labor.  Maybe the homeless guy was kidnapped, tortured and dumped =
by a secret government conspiracy.   Use whatever positive story works for =
you.  =0A=0AThe truth is that most of the time when we are thinking somethi=
ng negative about someone else it is simply because we have constructed a s=
cript in our mind where that person is at fault.  In fact we rarely know th=
e true circumstances of others well enough to know their stories and this s=
cript we have is just a fantasy which we have made up.  Often our scripts r=
einforce our preexisting beliefs and sometimes they are simply habitual pat=
terns that we play out over and over again.  Maybe the guy on the freeway i=
s a selfish asshole or maybe he is racing home to take care of a sick child=
.  Which story you pick is up to you.=0A=0ASo for one week, every time you =
find yourself constructing a negative fiction about someone you meet, simpl=
y replace it with a positive one.=0A=0AJust try this for a single week and =
I think you'll notice something interesting.=0A=0APeace,=0A=0APeter=0A=0A=

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:  THEY THOUGHT THEY WERE FREE


Are they talking about Inmates, as in people who are doing hard time, or 
ALL incarcerated people, including at the county level (3 year stetch)

I'm guessing one stat is counting one of those, and the other, well, the other.

Considering there are more new prisons, jails and such than schools, it 
does say something.  The gov't is more apt to expand, remodel and modernize 
a jail/prison, than they are to make sure that students have text books 
that were printed within the last 20 years.

(DANGER DANGER!!  SHATTER TANGENT)

Now, since most the peopel on this list seem prety smart...  explain THIS 
one to me.

The Gov't goes around testing schools.  They see how smart the kids 
are.  The schools with teh highest score get the funding.  The goes toward 
school improvement, text books, computer, classrooms, what have you.  Sound 
great right?

Fuck no it doesn't.  It's obvious they are giving the money to the schools 
that NEED IT LEAST!  If these kids are scoreing high on tests, then 
obviously they already HAVE great books, great teachers, and everything 
they need for a proper education.  Shouldn't the money go to the school 
with teh worst scores so the kids can maybe get a better education, better 
themselves, and maybe take a stab at the kids with the best scores?

I know, I know...  "What's to stop a school from taking a dive on the tests 
to get the worst score to get the money?   EASY -- Same thing that's 
stopping a school from submitting false tests that are all marked correct.

I thought a lot about this back when I was in High School (80's) and a lot 
of us talked about it, and thought it was messe dup.  So...  what did we 
do?  We sat and worke dout the test, figure dout the correct answer, then 
marked a wrong one.  See, IMHO, it's harder to get 0.00% right than it is 
to get 100%.  See, you might have guesse don a few and guess right to get 
100%.  To get 0.00% right you have to KNOW the answer in order to make sur 
you don't accidently guess right.

Some of my stoner friends however were too lazy to care, so, they just made 
pretty pictures on the scan tron.

At 12:50 PM 2/11/2007, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>My favorite bit of Nathan's post is the part of returning people "to their 
>own devices".  What does that really mean?
>
>Most of us if left completely to our "own devices" would simply starve to 
>death.  That is if we didn't die of thirst or loneliness first.
>
>Even the most independent person, a radical survivalist say, uses items 
>built and designed by other people.  Only a person living like an animal 
>can truthfully be said to be relying on "their own devices" and even they 
>still depend on others for their existence.  The rest of us, if we believe 
>we are really independent, are just fooling ourselves or faking it.  The 
>truthis that we need each other for almost every aspect of our daily lives.
>
>Think about what it would mean to truly be without the help of even a 
>single other human being.  Consider your clothes, shoes, job, and the food 
>you eat.  Books.  Electricity.  Music.  Heat.  Water.  Where do these 
>things come from?
>
>Unless you grow, harvest, store, and prepare all of your food yourself, 
>every meal you have depends on other people's efforts.  Your clothes were 
>likely made half way around the world by someone you've never even 
>met.  Something as simple as readily available safe drinking water depends 
>on the efforts of hundreds or thousands of other people for its 
>existence.  Most of us just conveniently don't want to think about these 
>other people and how they help us each day.
>
>In Buddhism we call it "co-dependent arising".   See also: 
>http://theidproject.com/index.htm
>
>Anyone that thinks they are actually self reliant in this sort of way is 
>simply deluded.  They are lost in the forest and are in need of rescue.
>
>Instead of responding in anger reach out a hand to help them. When someone 
>is offensive or disgusting to us, this is much easier said than done of 
>course, but it is still a worthy goal.
>
>Simple human kindness.  Try it and see.
>
>Peace,
>
>Peter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] homeless dumping


Gotta say...

Nail on da head.

My ex was a worker at a State mental institution (the ONLY one regan didn't 
shut down, Sonoma State in Glen Ellen).  Her mom worked at the hospital as 
well.  Her grandmother retired, after working there here whole 
life.  Suffice to say, I would say that it would qualify that their family 
were, mental health workers.

There's the types of units:  Behavioral, and Bed.  Everyone in teh hospital 
falls into one of those catagories.  If they cannot get up and walk around 
on their own, they are a bed unit.  If they can walk, Behavioral.  There's 
no middle ground.

If you mentioned Regan around that family, you could see the seething 
vitriol and bile swelling up from the darkest pits of their 
angerpool.  Hatred isn't a strong enough word for what they 
felt.  See...  a lot of the peopel who were "left to their own devices" 
ended up on their door step.  They were FORCED to turn them away because 
they were already over crowded.  State couldn't shut'em down becaus ethey 
had a 100% clean track record, best in the state, not so for many 
others.  One mistake made and that's how they shut down the hosital because 
"These people would be better off on their own than living in these 
horrible conditions" or something like that was the sound bite used to sell 
it at the time.  They were doing all these mentally ill people a favor by 
turning them loose into the wild.

Does anyone think the Soma Screamer is better off?

So, since they couldn't shut'em down, the state simply said "No new 
patients" so even ehen they would leave, they wouldn't take on new ones.

Now, if that's not bad enough, chekc this one out:

Wanna make some extra cash?  Well have I got a great offer for you!  The 
state of california presents -- "Adopt-o-tard!"  That's right!  You can 
adopt your very one "ready for the outside world" mentally ill person to 
living in your home, and the state will pay you!  Why?  Because it's 
cheaper to kick you down acash each month than to run a hospital!  They're 
paying you, and saving the tax payers money!  What a perfect system?  Adopt 
two and get a bonus check for FREE!

So one girl they had worked with was ready to go out into one of these 
houses.  She was calm, hadn't had a freak out attack in over a year.  Nice 
looking, long hair they would brush which made her quite happy.

One week later she was back.  Most of the hair was gone, and what wans't 
ripped out was shorn very shory.  Horrid bruises, welts, an such all over 
her.  She apparently looked like somebody that had been raped then tossed 
off an overpass onto 101 at 3am and hit by a drunk guy in a ryder 
truck.  They of course, investigated.

"Self Inflicted"

Nice eh?  They had to isolate her because she came back a complete spastic 
screaming biting spitting shit flinger.  Yes, I write dramatically at 
times, however the previous sentence is pretty much word for word how she 
was described to me.

nice eh?

>
>Then come and try and smear me and tell me I'm the one that's full of shit.
>
>Fair enough?
>
>When I moved to DC in late 2002, from Palo Alto, to live with my Attorney 
>girlfriend in Bethesda, MD, I would visit her at  the  Court House she 
>worked at, (the site of the Scooter Libby trial that's currently 
>underway), at Third & Constitution, NW, in DC, where the dominant feature 
>of the landscape is the United States Capitol Building.
>
>Apollo used to have a sig line that read
>
>"Music is Prophecy"
>
>Here's an example of that for you, Dave.
>
>There's a line from a Clash song, Car Jamming", from 1982, that goes:
>
>"Ventilation units where towers
>Meet the streets
>The ragged stand in bags
>Soaking heat up through their feet
>
>This was their only kindness
>And it was accidental too...."
>
>February 2003 was the coldest winter in DC history that has ever been 
>recorded, ever since they began keeping temperature records in the 
>1860s,  and every day that month that I went to go see my girl at her job 
>at the DC Superior Courthouse, by the US Capitol Building, I was greeted 
>by the sight, while in direct line-of-sight of the US Capitol Building, of 
>DC's mentally ill lying down on top of the steam grates that were on the 
>on the sidewalk that released the excess heat from the Courthouses, in an 
>attempt by them to stave off the bitter cold of that winter.
>
>Every day that month was like wading through a frozen hurricane.
>
>And I saw this little tableau of human misery on the streets of The 
>Capital of the Wealthiest Nation on Earth each and every fucking day.
>
>Since it was steam that was coming off those grates, they weren't going to 
>stay dry, and no doubt in some of the more fragile cases of people doing 
>this they were going to get sick and certainly some of them would die from 
>the exposure and the rapid shifts between hot and cold air.
>
>Disgusting.
>
>Makes me ashamed to be a cheap ass American that puts dollars over lives.
>
>I drew her attention to this behavior by these men and women, and the fact 
>that there are also mentally ill on practically every street corner of our 
>Nation's Capital begging for their lives, and getting stepped over and 
>ignored by our Nation's Policy Setting Elites, and she told me what I was 
>seeing was nothing.
>
>That in the mid 1980s when Reagan and David Stockman closed the Mental 
>Hospitals, the most charitable way to describe the scene on the streets of 
>DC was that it looked like exactly like the poor section of India's 
>Calcutta, and that there were TEN TIMES as many people on the streets of 
>DC at that time then I was seeing today.
>
>Also, when they closed those Hospitals what they did is they took the 
>patients out to all sort of remote areas in buses, without telling them 
>what they were doing, and just put them out of the buses onto the street 
>and drove off, leaving them to fend for themselves without so much a dime 
>in their pockets to call their relatives.
>
>I don't know how old you are, but my guess is that you're somewhere around 
>the age of 30, which means that when all this crap went down over 20 years 
>ago you must have been around 10 years old, or so, and probably don't 
>remember just how big this flood of mentally ill Americans was on the city 
>streets of our Nation.
>
>It was huge.
>
>Overwhelming in fact.
>
>One of the more disgraceful acts ever perpetrated by our US Government, 
>much worse than the internment of our Japanese citizenry during WW II, 
>since at least we kept the majority of those people alive.
>
>Most of those mentally ill people have vanished from the streets today, a 
>good 90% of them, and again *I will assert* that since they weren't taken 
>back into the hospitals, since we are to cheap to re-open them, and since 
>the bulk of them were not taken back by their families, that they are dead.
>
>Murdered, in fact, by our own Government.
>
>And, Dave, I have exactly zero need to "prove" any of this to you.
>
>Whatever, you have no shame about any of this, to the point of being 
>sociopathic, so it's pointless to get you to see any of this.
>
>I will tell you this, what happened to the mentally ill in America, over 
>the course of these past two decades, in this war of homicide by 
>attrition, is only a prelude of what's to come, Dave.
>
>Now that we're done with them, and there aren't so many left to kill, 
>we're going to start working our way up the food chain.
>
>Don't know if your folks are still around, but if they are, and you have a 
>shred of human decency in you, it will behoove you to stand over their 
>shoulder while they fill out their Medicare Plan D Forms so you can be 
>sure that they'll be adequately provided for.
>
>I'd do it if I were you, as an act of self-preservation, because it's only 
>going to be a matter of time before we start going after the 'free 
>spirits' of our culture, people like ravers, and you're going to need the 
>practice in sticking up for yourself.
>
>Then you can take your heartless attitude and go enlist and serve in Iraq, 
>which I'm sure you'll enjoy, Dave, because you'll find a lot of 
>like-minded individuals that you can share your hatred of human life with.
>
>Peisces,
>
>~nyc
>

Apollo still uses the "music is prophesy" line in his .sig

One small set of questions about the "costs" involved in taking care of 
our mentally ill here in The United States of America.

Is The United States of America richer, or poorer, today, in the year 
2007 than it was it was in the year 1985?

If it's poorer, that's one thing, but if it's richer, then how is it 
that we can't "afford" to take care of our own people properly?

Where's the logic in that?

If we could afford it when we weren't as well off as we are today, then 
why can't we afford it now?

What's up with that?

Unless, of course, We Americans are just a bunch of sadistic 
cheapskates, with no conscience, or ethics, then it's just a moot 
question, isn't it?

See you in hell.

~nyc

> My ex was a worker at a State mental institution (the ONLY one regan 
> didn't shut down, Sonoma State in Glen Ellen).  Her mom worked at the 
> hospital as well.  Her grandmother retired, after working there here 
> whole life.  Suffice to say, I would say that it would qualify that 
> their family were, mental health workers.
>
> There's the types of units:  Behavioral, and Bed.  Everyone in teh 
> hospital falls into one of those catagories.  If they cannot get up 
> and walk around on their own, they are a bed unit.  If they can walk, 
> Behavioral.  There's no middle ground.
>
> If you mentioned Regan around that family, you could see the seething 
> vitriol and bile swelling up from the darkest pits of their 
> angerpool.  Hatred isn't a strong enough word for what they felt.  
> See...  a lot of the peopel who were "left to their own devices" ended 
> up on their door step.  They were FORCED to turn them away because 
> they were already over crowded.  State couldn't shut'em down becaus 
> ethey had a 100% clean track record, best in the state, not so for 
> many others.  One mistake made and that's how they shut down the 
> hosital because "These people would be better off on their own than 
> living in these horrible conditions" or something like that was the 
> sound bite used to sell it at the time.  They were doing all these 
> mentally ill people a favor by turning them loose into the wild.
>
> Does anyone think the Soma Screamer is better off?
>
> So, since they couldn't shut'em down, the state simply said "No new 
> patients" so even ehen they would leave, they wouldn't take on new ones.
>
> Now, if that's not bad enough, chekc this one out:
>
> Wanna make some extra cash?  Well have I got a great offer for you!  
> The state of california presents -- "Adopt-o-tard!"  That's right!  
> You can adopt your very one "ready for the outside world" mentally ill 
> person to living in your home, and the state will pay you!  Why?  
> Because it's cheaper to kick you down acash each month than to run a 
> hospital!  They're paying you, and saving the tax payers money!  What 
> a perfect system?  Adopt two and get a bonus check for FREE!
>
> So one girl they had worked with was ready to go out into one of these 
> houses.  She was calm, hadn't had a freak out attack in over a year.  
> Nice looking, long hair they would brush which made her quite happy.
>
> One week later she was back.  Most of the hair was gone, and what 
> wans't ripped out was shorn very shory.  Horrid bruises, welts, an 
> such all over her.  She apparently looked like somebody that had been 
> raped then tossed off an overpass onto 101 at 3am and hit by a drunk 
> guy in a ryder truck.  They of course, investigated.
>

I'd Rather Be A Matin' Than A Hatin' ~ Me

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

"Ha ha!  Ever had the feeling you've been cheated?" ~ J. Lydon, SF, 1978

I'd Rather Be A Matin' Than A Hatin' ~ Me

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

"Ha ha!  Ever had the feeling you've been cheated?" ~ J. Lydon, SF, 1978

On 12 February 2007, Shatter wrote:

>
> Are they talking about Inmates, as in people who are doing hard time, or ALL 
> incarcerated people, including at the county level (3 year stetch)
>
> I'm guessing one stat is counting one of those, and the other, well, the 
> other.
>
> Considering there are more new prisons, jails and such than schools, it does 
> say something.  The gov't is more apt to expand, remodel and modernize a 
> jail/prison, than they are to make sure that students have text books that 
> were printed within the last 20 years.
>
> (DANGER DANGER!!  SHATTER TANGENT)
>
> Now, since most the peopel on this list seem prety smart...  explain THIS one 
> to me.
>
> The Gov't goes around testing schools.  They see how smart the kids are.  The 
> schools with teh highest score get the funding.  The goes toward school 
> improvement, text books, computer, classrooms, what have you.  Sound great 
> right?
>
> Fuck no it doesn't.  It's obvious they are giving the money to the schools 
> that NEED IT LEAST!  If these kids are scoreing high on tests, then obviously 
> they already HAVE great books, great teachers, and everything they need for a 
> proper education.  Shouldn't the money go to the school with teh worst scores 
> so the kids can maybe get a better education, better themselves, and maybe 
> take a stab at the kids with the best scores?

In my mind, a more logical approach to this matter would be to have a 
baseline, likely tied in to the actual cost of living in a local area, 
and then have funding vary AT A NOMINAL LEVEL above or below that to at 
least provide SOME incentive to a school system to be above average.

>
> I know, I know...  "What's to stop a school from taking a dive on the tests 
> to get the worst score to get the money?   EASY -- Same thing that's stopping 
> a school from submitting false tests that are all marked correct.
>
> I thought a lot about this back when I was in High School (80's) and a lot of 
> us talked about it, and thought it was messe dup.  So...  what did we do?  We 
> sat and worke dout the test, figure dout the correct answer, then marked a 
> wrong one.  See, IMHO, it's harder to get 0.00% right than it is to get 100%. 
> See, you might have guesse don a few and guess right to get 100%.  To get 
> 0.00% right you have to KNOW the answer in order to make sur you don't 
> accidently guess right.
>
> Some of my stoner friends however were too lazy to care, so, they just made 
> pretty pictures on the scan tron.
>

There is definitely a lot of reform that needs to be done in American
Schools.  There was news report on 60 minutes that compared out public
schooling to the Belgian public schooling system.  I think we could learn a
thing or two from the belgians.  Some of the things the Belgians did was to
fire teachers who weren't up to standards, and the closing down of schools
which weren't performing up to expected standards.  Try incorporating this
into public schools without the teacher's union getting involved...

My understanding is that the US school system pretty muc keeps up with 
the rest of the world, up until the 4th grade.  After that, the drop in 
test scores keeps accelerating until we're pretty low on the scale once 
it's time for people to graduate H.S.  Definitely sad, but an educated 
populace definitely isn't high on the list of the powers that be.

Babus
A Memorial and Celebration of James Kim's Life

Saturday, February 17th, 2007
1:00pm: Memorial
2:00pm - Sunset: Celebration
Location: Golden Gate Park Memorial Bandshell and Music Concourse

The family and friends of James Kim would like to extend a warm
invitation to join us in celebrating and remembering James' life.
This outdoor gathering serves to remind us of the deep ties that
bring us together, and honors James' appreciation for his family,
friends, and community.

This will be a family event -- bring your kids, bring a picnic, and
bring warm clothes. We will be celebrating with DJs, music,
and dancing until sunset.

In addition, we are proud to announce and unveil The James Kim
Technology Foundation. The purpose of the fund is to benefit
technology
programs in public schools. Donations to the foundation will be
appreciated.

that hate the freedom we have in our country and right now are  
bankrupting it so they can have their little 1984 playground.  there  
may be pockets of good teachers in the public school system of  
america, but largely you've got a system that's designed to fail, and  
teachers and staff that are indoctrinated to indoctrinate.  when i  
have kids they'll either be home schooled or private schooled,  
probably a combination of both, and when we come to the sunset  
parties for geriatrics i'll also make sure to tell them "don't mind  
uncle peter now, he's just paranoid."

Publicity is always a good motivator IMHO.  Spotlight the kids, the 
administrations, etc.  Schools LOVE to put big awards on the sides of the 
buildings and such.

My problem is giving funding based on rewards makes from a school that's 
going to remodel their football field while another handing out particle 
masks to studenst so they don't breathe the deteriorating asbestos falling 
from the ceiling while they have to double up on their history book 
published in 1952.

people were one of the most educated and advanced people, and we all know 
what happened to them (as pointed out by Apollo in that very good post)

I think it's a matter of what they're educated in.  The curriculums don't 
impress me in the least with the american school system.  So many subjects 
are skipped until college.  I mean, why don't kids get Plato in High 
school?  Shouldn't the Jr high and High school classes all be a lead in 
towards what you study in college?  So that college courses are a continued 
education as they should be instead of beginning of it?

laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any

haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever

it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly

least here with SFUSD) are much deeper than simply some bad teachers.=0A=0A=
One recent example: my daughter is a special ed student in SFUSD and theref=
ore gets transportation from her home to her school.  This year her bus was=
 late virtually every day  resulting in her and all of the other children o=
n the bus being late for school by 15-20 minutes.  The bus was on time exac=
tly 7 days for the entire period from August through December 31st and this=
 was documented by multiple parents and the school.  Despite the efforts of=
 the parents reporting this, demanding the school and principal do somethin=
g, reporting it to the district and the transportation office, nothing was =
done.  I was repeatedly told that nothing could be done by various people f=
rom SFUSD.  Two weeks ago I retained an attorney for $300.  Today I heard t=
hat a new driver has been assigned to the route.=0A=0AAnd this isn't the fi=
rst incident of this sort.  Previously I've had to spend thousands of dolla=

cher tried to trick me into signing papers which stated my daughter no long=

Luckily I'm not and I read the forms they wanted me to sign.  Sometimes it =
is almost a full time job just to keep your kid from getting screwed by thi=

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: THEY THOUGHT THEY WERE FREE


My problem is the whole system of Tenure.  Once they reach that then they 
become untouchable, and can pretty much get away with anything they 
want.  Teacher should be held accountable for keeping their work quality 
high, just liek any other job out there.

I don't mean fire them all, I'm saying if they can make the cut, then they 
need to go away and make room for somebody who will do a better job.

Just like the bus driver you pointed out.

From: Nyc Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>
