Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: THEY THOUGHT THEY WERE FREE

Shatter wrote:

>
> That's what everyone says, however as it's been pointed out,  the 
> German people were one of the most educated and advanced people, and 
> we all know what happened to them (as pointed out by Apollo in that 
> very good post)


.
I'm going to repost this Alice Miller essay on the subject, since she 
does a bang-up job of explaining how a man with brown hair and brown 
eyes could hoodwink an entire nation into believing in the lie of the 
superiority of the Aryan Ideal of blue eyed and blonde haired people: 
http://www.naturalchild.org/alice_miller/adolf_hitler.html

Again, What Miller says about the nature of German society being primed 
to accept a guy like Hitler as a leader doesn't explain  how we 
Americans ended up with Herr Uber Chancellor El Commandante President 4 
Life George W. Busch, as well, for that you need to read John Dean's 
latest book:
http://www.amazon.com/Conservatives-Without-Conscience-John-Dean/dp/0670037745

(Also, and I'm not joking, I believe that the "Star Wars" movie series 
is one of the largest contributing factors in our culture that led to 
the rise of Herr Georgie Busch, but that one's complicated to explain, 
and it's got a lot of moving parts to it, and so I'll talk about that at 
another time.)

Also, if Dean is to be believed in this new book of his, he indirectly 
makes the case that an Authoritarian figure like  Rudy Ghouliani has 
more than a solid chance of being elected President in 2008.

Ghouliani would only need 26% of the vote, to win the election, outside 
of the 25% block of slavish, Authoritarian followers, that would vote 
for him automatically, according to Dean's theory, without question.

Guarantee you that simple set of numbers are what his Republican 
handlers are banking on for him to win the election, and I'm afraid 
they're right.

Scary stuff, yo.


.

>
> I think it's a matter of what they're educated in.  The curriculums 
> don't impress me in the least with the american school system.  So 
> many subjects are skipped until college.  I mean, why don't kids get 
> Plato in High school?  Shouldn't the Jr high and High school classes 
> all be a lead in towards what you study in college?  So that college 
> courses are a continued education as they should be instead of 
> beginning of it?



.
I've a lot to say on this, so please bear with.

I was blessed in that the NYC Public Junior High I went to had a math 
teacher that, each and every year, would shut down the school's regular 
curriculum for an entire week and teach the *whole* 7th grade the 
history of Math, up to, and including the Theory of Relativity and what 
was then current.

His premise that there was no better time to get this sort of thing into 
kids heads and the "Shop Kids" were just as capable as grasping this 
shit as the College bound ones were.

So we were lucky.

I've never seen a latitudinal, over time, follow-up study, but I'll bet 
a significant proportion of us kids that studied under this guy ended up 
having better lives as a result of this man having this kind of faith in 
us and our capabilities.

It's a shame no one has followed his work.

I'm sure our American culture would not look like anything it does today 
if we had made that choice a generation ago.

Now when you ask, Shatter,"why don't kids get Plato in High school?"the 
answer to that question actually puts you in with some really weird company.

Like Leo Strauss, The Neo-Cons, and The Project For A New American Century.

Robert Pirsig, in his non-fiction, biography, "Zen & The Art Of 
Motorcycle Maintenance ", writes about the University of Chicago, and 
its "Great Books Program" where he studied under the Straussians, in the 
late 1950s.

Here's a brief description of what he found there.:

"In the Aristotelian tradition as interpreted by the medieval 
scholastics, man is counted a rational animal, capable of seeking and 
defining the good life and achieving it.

When this "first principle" about the nature of man was accepted by the 
president of the University of Chicago, it was inevitable that it would 
have educational repercussions.

The famous University of Chicago Great Books program and the 
reorganization of the University structure along Aristotelian lines and 
*the establishment of the "College," in which a reading of classics was 
initiated in fifteen-year-old students,* were some of the results." 
(emphasis added)
http://www.virtualschool.edu/mon/Quality/PirsigZen/part4.html

These University of Chicago people he writes about in his book are 
today's Neo-Conservatives.

How far does their reach and influence go?

All the way to the top.

They run the fucking country, and have for quite a while.

Don't believe it?

I studied under them here, http://tinyurl.com/5nr9x , so let me assert 
my expertise on the subject, by showing you this picture of one of my 
Tutors, Eva Brann, (Yes, that's her real name), getting a 2005 National 
Humanities Medal from President George Bush in the Oval Office: 
http://www.whitehouse.gov/news/releases/2005/11/images/20051110-2_d-0317-515h.html
(If you doubt the Leo Strauss connection, please bear in mind that 
Strauss spent the last 3 years of his life teaching at the College 
mentioned in the caption of that photo, and in fact he *died on the 
campus* there in 1973, and when I was there Brann was known as a faculty 
member that belonged to the "Cult of Leo Strauss." No, I'm not making 
this shit up. Why would I, and on a rave list no less? Where's the 
quarter in that for me?)

I know these assholes, like I said, I studied under them, and they're 
full of shit.

What they believe, and they get this out of their Plato, is that they 
are the self-appointed "Philosopher Kings" of this culture, and it is 
their "job" to keep us pieces of shit  in our place.

And believe me that's how they see us, the General Public, we are 
nothing but pieces of shit to them to be run roughshod over, by any 
means necessary.

Bill Kristol of Fox News is one of them, and I guarantee you when he 
does his bit on his show he has nothing but disdain for what he 
considers the rubes of his viewing audience.

That's how these people think.

What they've been doing, for the last quarter century, is making a 
concerted effort, to borrow one of their terms from one of their guys, 
Harold Bloom, is to "close the American Mind."

In that, they've succeeded spectacularily.

The destruction of the American Educational System under Reagan\Bush & 
Bush II is Prima Facie evidence of that.

See, it's alright for them and theirs to be the educated Elites of this 
culture, but god forbid we the people get a decent education.

Let me go back to this list of books:

http://tinyurl.com/5nr9x

The Conventional Wisdom is that that is a set of reading that one should 
not attempt until one is of College age because it is too difficult for 
the average person to grasp.

Pernicious nonsense.

There is not a goddamned thing on that list that the average 14 to 18 
year old kid in America can't mentally handle.

Sure, it's not "easy" stuff to wade through, it's not supposed to be, if 
the goal is to educate the populace.

The question really is is why aren't we doing it in the first fucking place?

And the answer comes flying back, because they don't want it, because if 
we, the American People, were an educated populace, thre is no way in 
hell they could put across on tenth of the con jobs that they've foisted 
on the American populace.

What's the "solution" to this?

I don't know because they've now got the deck pretty well stacked in 
their favor being that they have control of the media, the military, the 
Government, Courts, jails and educational system.

If past history is any indication, the way they will ultimately lose is 
the same way every other corrupt elite has lost, their shit is 
unsustainable over time and at a certain point it will come collapsing 
down upon their heads.

In the meantime they are going to fuck up a lot of innocent people just 
so they can keep running their game.

So keep your friends and family close and watch out for each other.

OK, now back to the music!!!

Xin Nian Hao!!!

~nyc

laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever

Subject: [sfraves] Purina Diet

--0-1559639929-1171406601=:22754
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit



I was in Wal-Mart buying a large bag of Purina for my dogs and was in line to check out. A woman behind me asked if I had a dog........ Duh!


I was feeling a bit crabby so on impulse, I told her no, I was starting  The Purina Diet again, although I probably shouldn't because I'd ended up in the hospital last time, but that I'd lost 50 pounds before I awakened in an intensive care unit with tubes coming out of most of my orifices and IVs in both arms. Her eyes about bugged out of her head. 

I went on and on with the bogus diet story and she was totally buying it. I told her that it was an easy, inexpensive diet and that the way it works is to load your pockets or purse with Purina nuggets and simply eat one or two every time you feel hungry. The package said the food is nutritionally complete so I was going to try it again. 

I have to mention here that practically everyone in the line was by now enthralled with my story, particularly a tall guy behind her.  Horrified, she asked if something in the dog food had poisoned me and was that was why I ended up in the hospital. 

I said no.....I'd been sitting in the street licking my butt when a car hit me. 

I thought the tall guy was going to have to be carried out the door.

>enthralled with my story, particularly a tall guy behind her. Horrified, 
>she asked if something in the dog food had poisoned me and was that was why 
>I ended up in the hospital.
>
>I said no.....I'd been sitting in the street licking my butt when a car hit 
>me.
>
>I thought the tall guy was going to have to be
carried out the door.

Ya...  I get that a lot...

My problem is the there's quite a bit of "New Conservative" (definition as 
in the quotes would give you from a dictionry, meaning, a conservative that 
has nothing to do with the old conservatives) I agree with, however please 
don't think I'm a Neo-Con because I can't stand those assholes either.

I say this because, i thik our education sucks, and we should get back to 
some subjects that are beyond science.  If we're going to push for 
"liberal" education, then let' get some real Liberal Arts instead of the 
standard study of "White people, their cuture are bad, and anything not 
american should be celebrated and put on a pedastal." (No, I'm not a 
multi-culturalist, and i don't celebrate diversity, sorry guys.  As I've 
said before, I'm an American, I have a culture.  Everyone I live with and 
know are Americans, and we have american culture.  We are still a melting 
pot, so no one thing should be previlant.)

Some philosophy, perhaps language beyond Spanish being 
taught.  Sociology?  Why not?  Shouldn't high school kids grasp the 
concepts of the mind set of large groups of people, analize the problems 
from a clinical point of veiw, and learn the reasons why we and the world 
have the problems we face?

How about real political science, and not just a semester on the 
constitution.  Cover theconstitution as well, obviously, but why don't high 
school kids hear more about levithan, Calvin, The Federalist papers and 
"Pluvius"?   Teach the kids about Politcal PACS, the money trail, 
lobbyists, etc.  Half od teh kids in high school are of voting age after all.

Course we know why.  Don't educate them.  Let them get their political 
views from MTV and Politically Incorrect.  Let some rock star tell them how 
to vote.  Better yet, let the apathy seeth in and convince them their vote 
doesn't count.  Reduce the voting populace.  Every person that doesn't vote 
makes your vote more important after all.

Ok....   ranting now.

Back to the new con thing...

I think we should worry about ourselves first.  Our people, our country, 
our economy.  Why???  Simple.

Until we have abolished poverty, homelessness, and creatied a good standard 
of loving for ALL citizens regardless of economic standing, we are in no 
position to tell anyone else how to run their country.  Would you take 
economic advice from a broke homeless guy? Then what country would listen 
to the U.S. about how to end poverty when our streets are filled with 
people starving.

So while I might occasionally spout off with neocon crud, my basis of 
reasoning and intent is usually very different.

He's hostile to life and freedom as we know it.

His 8 years as Mayor of NYC are a living testament to that fact.

Last week I did a brief two day stint working as a canvasser on the 
Upper West and East Sides of Manhattan for Howard Dean's Democratic 
National Committee and I saw the truth of the "Authoritarian Complex" 
that John Dean describes in his new book.

As soon as the "progressive minded" kid I was working with and I got 
onto the subject of Ghouliani, and his Presidential chances, I watched 
his mind close like a steel trap when I brought up just how much damage 
Ghouliani has done to the City of New York under his Reign of Terror.

It was surreal.

He tried to float the bullshit meme that's in currency of how Ghouliani 
had the guts to"clean up NYC", and when I gently corrected him and told 
him that Ghouliani did nothing of the sort, and all he did was replace 
one group of completely disorganized criminal thugs and replaced them 
with another, much organized group of thugs, complete with badges, guns 
and uniforms, via his empowerment of the NYPD, and that the average New 
Yorker today is much more afraid of the cops than they ever were of the 
street thugs of the past, this poor kid's face just completely froze up 
and he refused to discuss it any further with me.

Indoctrinated kids like him are the ones that are going to elect a 
monster like this as an American President, and when that happens, 
having your night life disrupted is going to be the least of your worries.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Links to a few of my mixes

------=_Part_110770_30186996.1171416940559
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed

So here's a bit of blatant self-promotion on my part.  J.C. was kind enough
to have me as a guest DJ on his show last week, and as I uploaded the
recording I thought I'd share a bit of my work with y'all.

This is dual purpose.  First, I'd just really like you guys to hear the
music I'm digging these days and see what you think of my style (feedback
more than welcome).
Second, I really love performing, and I figure this is one way to start
putting myself out there and see if any opportunities to play out come of
it.

So here goes.  First, a link to the full 2hrs 25mins worth of mix that I
broadcasted on Epiphany of Sound last Thursday.  At one point my laptop
deleted a number of warp markers in one song, so I took the liberty of
editing out this technology-driven trainwreck.  It's not all the newest
stuff, just songs I like, primarily techno but with some tech/progressive
house too.  Here's the link:
http://progressivemojo.phang.net/progressiveMOJO%20-%20Live%20on%20Epiphany%20Of%20Sound%202007-02-08.mp3<https://webmail.stanford.edu/horde/util/go.php?url=http%3A%2F%2Fprogressivemojo.phang.net%2FprogressiveMOJO%2520-%2520Live%2520on%2520Epiphany%2520Of%2520Sound%25202007-02-08.mp3&Horde=850c05286ecdabf29beeeb2604c5185b>

Next, a little techno thing I put together during exams last semester.  It
was also the first mix I ever did in Ableton Live!:
http://progressivemojo.phang.net/progressiveMOJO%20-%20It%20Rains%20Too%20Much%20Here%20(December%202006).mp3<https://webmail.stanford.edu/horde/util/go.php?url=http%3A%2F%2Fprogressivemojo.phang.net%2FprogressiveMOJO%2520-%2520It%2520Rains%2520Too%2520Much%2520Here%2520%28December%25202006%29.mp3&Horde=850c05286ecdabf29beeeb2604c5185b>

Lastly, something I recorded over the summer.  This one was the result of
messing around with a few months' worth of vinyl one afternoon and seeing
what I could come up with
http://progressivemojo.phang.net/progressiveMOJO%20-%20July%202006.mp3<https://webmail.stanford.edu/horde/util/go.php?url=http%3A%2F%2Fprogressivemojo.phang.net%2FprogressiveMOJO%2520-%2520July%25202006.mp3&Horde=850c05286ecdabf29beeeb2604c5185b>

In the interests of saving space, I won't post the tracklists here but I'll
gladly supply them on request.  Please let me know if you have any problems
getting them to download.
Your feedback is VERY welcome, I'm always trying to improve and knowing what
people think about my work is essential for that.

If you are interested in booking me, or if you know someone who might be,
just shoot me an email at this address or call me at (281) 687-0393.

Thanks, and I hope you listen and enjoy!

Matt

total "one shot" dealio, and as the title suggests, it's just the raw mix. I 
wound up turing down the bass about 15 minutes (give or take) into it, but 
OTT the mix still sounds bumpin'. Or at least, for being my 1st decent mix 
ever, I think it's at least worth a DL. Feel free to comment iof you 
like...sadly a track listing is impossible since I sold off all the vinyl 
since then, heh.


http://www.yousendit.com/download/ZGJlcmxlK3hRYTk1VEE9PQ

got capped in Dallas in 1963 and I live too damn close to the 9/!! 
Memorial Pit to tolerate this shit.

At 10:45am, est, on the morning of September 1th, 2001, you know for a 
goddamn fact that at least 5 teams of real life "Lone Gunmen", as seen 
on TV, showed up on the corner of Church and Liberty with an array of 
electronic chemical sniffing equipment and not *one* of them found any 
trace of a C-4 or thermite signature.

chemical signature in the air down there they'd never shut their yaps

That was no dig at you, I was kind of making a joke.

It's obvious that you're an old school conservative andnot one of these 
neo-con artist whackos.

Though I don't post much anymore on SFR, I have been lurking here for 
years. I've just recently ported all my online activities over to this 
email addy, (since it's the name of the electronics company my dad had 
in the early 1970's),  and away from my "nwa420" persona, since I've 
decided to get serious about what I'm doing, and saying, a move I should 
have made a decade ago, and, well, I've been reading your stuff here, 
and we're pretty much on the same page, so I thought you'd get the joke 
without getting all defensive on my lily white ass.

Damned email, it still hasn't licked that "convey tone" issue.

But no joke, you should have seen my eyes pinwheel when I saw that 
picture of my tutor Eva Brann in the WH Oval Office getting that Medal 
from Herr Busch.

Freaked me the fuck out.

I was sipping coffee at the time, and yes, I did a god's honest spit 
take when I saw it.

That's the kind of validation of what I've been telling people, for 
years, that I could have gone my whole life without getting.

Who needs that kind of waking nightmare?

I know I don't.

But you, judging by everything you wrote below, get where I'm coming 
from, and what you've written here are ideas I'd like to explore further 
and this seems to be the ideal proving ground for it, irregardless of 
how many rabid indoctrinated puppy dogs want to nip at our heels.

~nyc

I'd Rather Be A Matin' Than A Hatin' ~ Me

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

"Ha ha!  Ever had the feeling you've been cheated?" ~ J. Lydon, SF, 1978

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: THEY THOUGHT THEY WERE FREE


Hate to argue...

(I'll assume you mean Sept 11 not 1st)

but at that time I think everyone in visual range of the towers were too 
busy worrying about survival, figureing out what happened, and being 
shocked by plane #2 to think about breaking out the tech toys and sniffing 
around for a conspiracy.

They still havn't explained the Pentagon or flight 91.

Mind you, I would be happy with the ugly truth.  If they shot planes down, 
say so.  Really, I'd be ok with it, as would most people, IMHO. Tell the 
honest truth that it's bette rto shoot down one of our own passenger 
liners, yes, filled with innocent people, than to let some fucked up 
radical try this stunt again.  Send a message.

Do I think the planes took the towers down?  Yes.  Could the towers have 
stood up as designed to withstand the hits?  Yes, howeve rthose planes were 
larger than the towers were designed for and the impact knocked off a 
signifigant amount of the fire retardarnt inner coasting, which as we know, 
was put on my the owerest bidder.  Do I think the pilots (if there were 
any) did this with no outside help?  No.  You don't get flight lessons on a 
prop and fly a commercial jet liner into a building.  That's like taking 3 
day intro to C programming class and writing the current incarnation of 
Firefox the following weekend.  Could the plane of been remote piloted by 
an AWAX?  Oh yes, yes indeed.  Was it strange that all key personel had 
already left or never showed up to teh buildings the say of (just like the 
OK Federal building)?  Yes.  Did the Bush admin have a clue it was going to 
happen?  Yes.  Did they capitalize on it for their agenda that 6 months 
previous had been shot down in Congress (Patriot Act)  Yes.  Are they the 
types who like to talk about Omlettes and Eggs?  Yes, oh yes they are.

From: Shatter <shatter@sonic.net>
In-Reply-To: <745081.42786.qm@web32404.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: More tech geekery


Smart sources are speculating (and I'm in total agreement) that the future 
won't be these multi core chips.  We're already seeing diminishing returns 
on them.  Quad will be the end for a bit while they push them harder and 
faster, and then we'll see a break toward distributed processing systems of 
varying bit size.  A return to 16bit, 24 bit etc that we're already seeing, 
but at a much larger level.

Already we have GPU's, and NPU's are stating to emerge.  If you geeks 
havn't looked at KillerNIC do look at it.  I'm really thinking of going 
that route.  There's also the Physics sub processor that's on many 
motherboards now, that's increasing game performance by unloading all 
physics calculations to a dedicated processor.  Befor ethe days of the 
Floating point processing will remember when all system had a math 
co-processor to operate.

Essentially instead of a standard NIC you have a NPU card running a 400MHz 
chip with it's own ram and non volitale storage.  It's running Linus and 
acts as it's own sub computer handling all network traffic.  Your computer 
simply send data and the NIC does the rest.  All TCP/IP functions happen on 
the card, freeing up you CPU to do other things.  You can also have on card 
Firewall, Applications (Teamspeak, Vent, etc) all running on card, and not 
on computer.

Control is done from a simple terminal, like you would with any *nix system.

Consider other aspect that could be done via a distributed system and you 
can see where this can go.  We already have sound moving off the main bus 
and onto dedicated sub processing systems.  Music peopel have been doing 
thsi for years to some extent, but now it's becoming defacto.

Essentially, in another 5-8 years we shoudl start seeing what amounts to a 
distributed cluster into the box.

Then of course, many years after that they'll being it all back into the 
next interation of super chip, most likely something in the Quantum realm, 
or photonics.

Oh I'm sure they'll go past the quad, but the problem is going to be the 
OS's keeping up, much how that article mentions.  You're almost going to 
have to have an interpreter Sub proc to handle the OS talking to the CPU, 
passing on tasks regardless of OS or something weird.  Donno.

Remember the Neural Networks?  Whatever happened to those?  Those were 
supposed to be the rage, but didn't seem to get very far.

Wonder how many cross talking cores you need before the chip becomes self 
aware.


At 07:07 AM 2/14/2007, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>I happen to work on a project that benefits from multi-core
>architectures so we're pretty excited about both these developments.  The 
>"network on a chip" idea is exciting also.  Our application already runs 
>in a similar environment so porting to such an architecture would be a breeze.
>
>I'm pretty excited about some of the demonstrations Intel has been giving 
>even if their path turns out to be the one not taken.   Real time video 
>based motion capture.  Synthetic video.  Deep physical simulation and AI.
>
>There are some really exciting (and also scary) possibilities that will 
>come from the next big jump in computing power.  And its going to 
>accelerate change in other areas like biotech as well.
>
>Peace,
>
>Peter
>
>----- Original Message ----
>From: Shatter <shatter@sonic.net>
>To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com; sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Sent: Wednesday, February 14, 2007 4:16:37 AM
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: More tech geekery
>
>
>Smart sources are speculating (and I'm in total agreement) that the future
>won't be these multi core chips.  We're already seeing diminishing returns
>on them.  Quad will be the end for a bit while they push them harder and
>faster, and then we'll see a break toward distributed processing systems of
>varying bit size.  A return to 16bit, 24 bit etc that we're already seeing,
>but at a much larger level.
>
>Already we have GPU's, and NPU's are stating to emerge.  If you geeks
>havn't looked at KillerNIC do look at it.  I'm really thinking of going
>that route.  There's also the Physics sub processor that's on many
>motherboards now, that's increasing game performance by unloading all
>physics calculations to a dedicated processor.  Befor ethe days of the
>Floating point processing will remember when all system had a math
>co-processor to operate.
>
>Essentially instead of a standard NIC you have a NPU card running a 400MHz
>chip with it's own ram and non volitale storage.  It's running Linus and
>acts as it's own sub computer handling all network traffic.  Your computer
>simply send data and the NIC does the rest.  All TCP/IP functions happen on
>the card, freeing up you CPU to do other things.  You can also have on card
>Firewall, Applications (Teamspeak, Vent, etc) all running on card, and not
>on computer.
>
>Control is done from a simple terminal, like you would with any *nix system.
>
>Consider other aspect that could be done via a distributed system and you
>can see where this can go.  We already have sound moving off the main bus
>and onto dedicated sub processing systems.  Music peopel have been doing
>thsi for years to some extent, but now it's becoming defacto.
>
>Essentially, in another 5-8 years we shoudl start seeing what amounts to a
>distributed cluster into the box.
>
>Then of course, many years after that they'll being it all back into the
>next interation of super chip, most likely something in the Quantum realm,
>or photonics.
>
>At 12:28 AM 2/14/2007, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Purina Diet

You are my guitar hero of the day!

Like your email alias, judging by this post of yours, it probably fits 
you IRL as well..

We should join forces, I get a kick doing stuff like this, and it's 
always more fun if you have a like minded partner to work with.

I usually work off the phone with inbound calls from telemarketers, 
here's a brief description of what I do that I posted elsewhere about a 
week ago:

~~~

I love making phone calls like this.

The week President Nixon died my desk partner and I played merry hell 
out with every building that didn't fly their flags at half mast in San 
Francisco's Financial District, most notably the Pacific Stock Exchange.

They didn't see that one coming.

Also, what's really fun for me is messing with telemarketers, I can keep 
them on the phone for hours until they realize that I'm just fucking 
with them.

Sometimes I pretend that I've got Down's Syndrome, and if it's a woman I 
immediately ask her what she's wearing and move the conversation in that 
direction.

I once got this one girl in New Delhi so upset, (the call immediately 
devolved into a "what are you wearing" from me and went downhill from 
there for 15 minutes), she called me back on her own cell phone just to 
cuss me out, never mind what she must have had to pay to get some 
satisfaction out of me.

heheheh.

I've been faulted for doing this, but it beats screaming "Do Not Call!!" 
at them and gets better results, they tend to never call back after 
dealing with me on the phone.

I should record this bit and put out a CD.

The diff is I don't make the calls, they call me, which gives me mad 
license to go to town.

A phone is a WMD in my hands and I don't know why more people don't do 
this, it's fun to turn tables, y'know.

I once bumped into NYT Select*, (bitches), columnist Paul Krugman* on 
the corner of 17th and K Street, NW, as we were both leaving Farragut 
Park one day, and I asked him to relay the following story of one of 
these calls of mine to his colleague, Mr. Tom "The World Is Flat" 
Friedman, since what I'm about to tell you is his bailiwick more than 
Krugman's.

I pretended to have LaTourette's Syndrome on this one call that came in 
and abused, (believe it or don't, she never once lost her cool and was 
polite throughout),  this one female telemarketer, (who was selling a 
*local* landscaping firm's services), for about a half hour until *I* 
the one that was spent, and then I dropped it and started talking with her.

Turns out she was 23, was calling from Romania, had just graduated 
college, spoke 5 languages, and here's the punch line....

Was being paid $200USD a month to put up with my shit on the phone.

Make a decision, if you're a businessman, who would you hire?

A surly US GED holder that you pay $1,200.00 a month that's going to 
drive away your customers, or her?

And yet you people still hold on to the quaint notion that America isn't 
doomed by its own shit and ain't gonna have its lunch eaten by the 
Second World.

~nyc

* Fuck the NYT Select, go here: http://welcome-to-pottersville.blogspot.com/

Mallorieknoxx wrote:

>I was in Wal-Mart buying a large bag of Purina for my dogs and was in line to check out. A woman behind me asked if I had a dog........ Duh!
>
>
>I was feeling a bit crabby so on impulse, I told her no, I was starting  The Purina Diet again, although I probably shouldn't because I'd ended up in the hospital last time, but that I'd lost 50 pounds before I awakened in an intensive care unit with tubes coming out of most of my orifices and IVs in both arms. Her eyes about bugged out of her head. 
>
>I went on and on with the bogus diet story and she was totally buying it. I told her that it was an easy, inexpensive diet and that the way it works is to load your pockets or purse with Purina nuggets and simply eat one or two every time you feel hungry. The package said the food is nutritionally complete so I was going to try it again. 
>
>I have to mention here that practically everyone in the line was by now enthralled with my story, particularly a tall guy behind her.  Horrified, she asked if something in the dog food had poisoned me and was that was why I ended up in the hospital. 
>
>I said no.....I'd been sitting in the street licking my butt when a car hit me.

>I thought the tall guy was going to have to be carried out the door.

Speaking of f*cking with people on the phone.......   
   
   
  >Subject: Anger management
>
>
>
>When you occasionally have a really bad  day, and you just need to take it
>out on someone, don't take it out on someone  you know, take it out on someone
>you don't know.
>
>I was sitting at my  desk when I remembered a phone call I'd
>forgotten to make. I found the  number and dialed it. A man
>answered, saying "Hello." I politely said,  "This is Chris. Could I
>please speak with Robyn Carter?"
>
>Suddenly  a manic voice yelled out in my ear "Get the right f***ing number!"
>and the  phone was slammed down on me. I couldn't believe that anyone could be
>so  rude. When I tracked down Robyn's correct number to call her, I found
>that  I had accidentally transposed the last two digits.
>
>After hanging up  with her, I decided to call the 'wrong' number
>again.
>
>When the same  guy answered the phone, I yelled, "You're an
>asshole!" and hung up. I wrote  his number down with the word
>'asshole' next to it and put it  in my desk drawer.
>
>Every couple of weeks, when I was paying bills or  had a really bad day, I'd
>call him up and yell, "You're an  asshole!"
>
>It always cheered me up.
>
>When Caller ID was  introduced, I thought my therapeutic 'asshole' calling
>would have to stop.  So, I called his number and said, "Hi, this is John Smith
>from the telephone  company.
>I'm calling to see if you're familiar with our Caller ID  Program?"
>
>He yelled "NO!" and slammed down the phone. I quickly  called him back and
>said, "That's because you're an asshole!" and hung  up.
>
>
>One day I was at the store, getting ready to pull  into a parking
>Spot. Some guy in a black BMW cut me off and pulled into  the spot I had
>patiently waited for. I hit the horn and yelled that I'd
>been  waiting for that spot, but the idiot ignored me. I noticed a
>"For Sale" sign in his back window, so I wrote down his      number.
>
>A couple of days later, right after calling the first  asshole (I
>had his number on speed dial,) I thought  that I'd better  call the
>BMW asshole, too.
>
>I said, "Is this the man with the  black BMW for sale?"
>
>He said, "Yes, it is." I asked, "Can you tell  me where I can see
>it?"
>
>He said, "Yes, I live at  34  Oaktree Blvd, in Fairfax. It's a
>yellow rambler, and the car's  parked right out in front."
>
>I asked,  "What's your name?" He said,  "My name is Don Hansen,"
>
>I asked, "When's a good time to catch you,  Don?"
>
>He said, "I'm home every evening after  five."
>
>I said,  "Listen, Don, can I tell you something?"
>
>He said,  "Yes?"
>
>I  said, "Don, you're an asshole!"
>
>Then I hung up, and added  his number to my speed dial, too.
>
>Now, when I had a problem, I had  two assholes to call.
>
>Then I came up with an i dea. I called asshole  #1.
>
>He said, "Hello."
>
>I said, "You're an  asshole!" (But I didn't hang up.)
>
>He asked, "Are you      still there?"
>
>I said, "Yeah,"
>
>He screamed, "Stop  calling me,"
>
>I said, "Make me,"
>
>He asked, "Who are  you?"
>
>I said,  "My name is Don Hansen."
>
>He said, "Yeah? Where  do you live?"
>
>I said, "Asshole, I live at  34 Oaktree Blvd, in  Fairfax, a
>yellow rambler, I have a black Beamer parked in front."
>
>He said, "I'm coming over right now, Don. And you had better start  saying
>your prayers."
>
>I said, "Yeah, like I'm really scared,  asshole," and hung up.
>
>Then I called Asshole #2.
>
>He said,   "Hello?"
>
>I said, "Hello, asshole,"
>
>He yelled, "If I ever find  out who you are..."
>
>I said, "You'll what?"
>
>He exclaimed,  "I'll kick your ass,"
>
>I answered, "Well, asshole, here's your chance.  I'm coming over  right now".
>
>Then I hung up and immediately called  the police, saying that I
>lived at 34 Oaktree Blvd, in Fairfax,  and that I was on my way
>over there to kill my gay lover.
>
>Then I  called Channel 9 News about the gang war going down  in
>Oaktree Blvd. in Fairfax.
>
>
>
>I quickly got into my car and headed over to Fairfax. I got
>there just in time to watch two assholes beating the crap out of each other
>in front of six cop cars, an overhead news helicopter and surrounded by a
>news crew.
>
>NOW I feel much better.
>
>Anger management really  does work!
  

Nyc Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com> wrote:
  You are my guitar hero of the day!

Like your email alias, judging by this post of yours, it probably fits 
you IRL as well..

We should join forces, I get a kick doing stuff like this, and it's 
always more fun if you have a like minded partner to work with.

I usually work off the phone with inbound calls from telemarketers, 
here's a brief description of what I do that I posted elsewhere about a 
week ago:

~~~

I love making phone calls like this.

The week President Nixon died my desk partner and I played merry hell 
out with every building that didn't fly their flags at half mast in San 
Francisco's Financial District, most notably the Pacific Stock Exchange.

They didn't see that one coming.

Also, what's really fun for me is messing with telemarketers, I can keep 
them on the phone for hours until they realize that I'm just fucking 
with them.

Sometimes I pretend that I've got Down's Syndrome, and if it's a woman I 
immediately ask her what she's wearing and move the conversation in that 
direction.

I once got this one girl in New Delhi so upset, (the call immediately 
devolved into a "what are you wearing" from me and went downhill from 
there for 15 minutes), she called me back on her own cell phone just to 
cuss me out, never mind what she must have had to pay to get some 
satisfaction out of me.

heheheh.

I've been faulted for doing this, but it beats screaming "Do Not Call!!" 
at them and gets better results, they tend to never call back after 
dealing with me on the phone.

I should record this bit and put out a CD.

The diff is I don't make the calls, they call me, which gives me mad 
license to go to town.

A phone is a WMD in my hands and I don't know why more people don't do 
this, it's fun to turn tables, y'know.

I once bumped into NYT Select*, (bitches), columnist Paul Krugman* on 
the corner of 17th and K Street, NW, as we were both leaving Farragut 
Park one day, and I asked him to relay the following story of one of 
these calls of mine to his colleague, Mr. Tom "The World Is Flat" 
Friedman, since what I'm about to tell you is his bailiwick more than 
Krugman's.

I pretended to have LaTourette's Syndrome on this one call that came in 
and abused, (believe it or don't, she never once lost her cool and was 
polite throughout), this one female telemarketer, (who was selling a 
*local* landscaping firm's services), for about a half hour until *I* 
the one that was spent, and then I dropped it and started talking with her.

Turns out she was 23, was calling from Romania, had just graduated 
college, spoke 5 languages, and here's the punch line....

Was being paid $200USD a month to put up with my shit on the phone.

Make a decision, if you're a businessman, who would you hire?

A surly US GED holder that you pay $1,200.00 a month that's going to 
drive away your customers, or her?

And yet you people still hold on to the quaint notion that America isn't 
doomed by its own shit and ain't gonna have its lunch eaten by the 
Second World.

~nyc

* Fuck the NYT Select, go here: http://welcome-to-pottersville.blogspot.com/

Mallorieknoxx wrote:

>I was in Wal-Mart buying a large bag of Purina for my dogs and was in line to check out. A woman behind me asked if I had a dog........ Duh!
>
>
>I was feeling a bit crabby so on impulse, I told her no, I was starting The Purina Diet again, although I probably shouldn't because I'd ended up in the hospital last time, but that I'd lost 50 pounds before I awakened in an intensive care unit with tubes coming out of most of my orifices and IVs in both arms. Her eyes about bugged out of her head. 
>
>I went on and on with the bogus diet story and she was totally buying it. I told her that it was an easy, inexpensive diet and that the way it works is to load your pockets or purse with Purina nuggets and simply eat one or two every time you feel hungry. The package said the food is nutritionally complete so I was going to try it again. 
>
>I have to mention here that practically everyone in the line was by now enthralled with my story, particularly a tall guy behind her. Horrified, she asked if something in the dog food had poisoned me and was that was why I ended up in the hospital. 
>
>I said no.....I'd been sitting in the street licking my butt when a car hit me. 
>
>I thought the tall guy was going to have to be carried out the door.
>
>
> 
>---------------------------------
>Finding fabulous fares is fun.
>Let Yahoo! FareChase search your favorite travel sites to find flight and hotel bargains.

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

Mallorieknoxx <ina_dream@yahoo.com> wrote:  Speaking of f*cking with people on the phone....... 


>Subject: Anger management
>
>
>
>When you occasionally have a really bad day, and you just need to take it
>out on someone, don't take it out on someone you know, take it out on someone
>you don't know.
>
>I was sitting at my desk when I remembered a phone call I'd
>forgotten to make. I found the number and dialed it. A man
>answered, saying "Hello." I politely said, "This is Chris. Could I
>please speak with Robyn Carter?"
>
>Suddenly a manic voice yelled out in my ear "Get the right f***ing number!"
>and the phone was slammed down on me. I couldn't believe that anyone could be
>so rude. When I tracked down Robyn's correct number to call her, I found
>that I had accidentally transposed the last two digits.
>
>After hanging up with her, I decided to call the 'wrong' number
>again.
>
>When the same guy answered the phone, I yelled, "You're an
>asshole!" and hung up. I wrote his number down with the word
>'asshole' next to it and put it in my desk drawer.
>
>Every couple of weeks, when I was paying bills or had a really bad day, I'd
>call him up and yell, "You're an asshole!"
>
>It always cheered me up.
>
>When Caller ID was introduced, I thought my therapeutic 'asshole' calling
>would have to stop. So, I called his number and said, "Hi, this is John Smith
>from the telephone company.
>I'm calling to see if you're familiar with our Caller ID Program?"
>
>He yelled "NO!" and slammed down the phone. I quickly called him back and
>said, "That's because you're an asshole!" and hung up.
>
>
>One day I was at the store, getting ready to pull into a parking
>Spot. Some guy in a black BMW cut me off and pulled into the spot I had
>patiently waited for. I hit the horn and yelled that I'd
>been waiting for that spot, but the idiot ignored me. I noticed a
>"For Sale" sign in his back window, so I wrote down his number.
>
>A couple of days later, right after calling the first asshole (I
>had his number on speed dial,) I thought that I'd better call the
>BMW asshole, too.
>
>I said, "Is this the man with the black BMW for sale?"
>
>He said, "Yes, it is." I asked, "Can you tell me where I can see
>it?"
>
>He said, "Yes, I live at 34 Oaktree Blvd, in Fairfax. It's a
>yellow rambler, and the car's parked right out in front."
>
>I asked, "What's your name?" He said, "My name is Don Hansen,"
>
>I asked, "When's a good time to catch you, Don?"
>
>He said, "I'm home every evening after five."
>
>I said, "Listen, Don, can I tell you something?"
>
>He said, "Yes?"
>
>I said, "Don, you're an asshole!"
>
>Then I hung up, and added his number to my speed dial, too.
>
>Now, when I had a problem, I had two assholes to call.
>
>Then I came up with an i dea. I called asshole #1.
>
>He said, "Hello."
>
>I said, "You're an asshole!" (But I didn't hang up.)
>
>He asked, "Are you still there?"
>
>I said, "Yeah,"
>
>He screamed, "Stop calling me,"
>
>I said, "Make me,"
>
>He asked, "Who are you?"
>
>I said, "My name is Don Hansen."
>
>He said, "Yeah? Where do you live?"
>
>I said, "Asshole, I live at 34 Oaktree Blvd, in Fairfax, a
>yellow rambler, I have a black Beamer parked in front."
>
>He said, "I'm coming over right now, Don. And you had better start saying
>your prayers."
>
>I said, "Yeah, like I'm really scared, asshole," and hung up.
>
>Then I called Asshole #2.
>
>He said, "Hello?"
>
>I said, "Hello, asshole,"
>
>He yelled, "If I ever find out who you are..."
>
>I said, "You'll what?"
>
>He exclaimed, "I'll kick your ass,"
>
>I answered, "Well, asshole, here's your chance. I'm coming over right now".
>
>Then I hung up and immediately called the police, saying that I
>lived at 34 Oaktree Blvd, in Fairfax, and that I was on my way
>over there to kill my gay lover.
>
>Then I called Channel 9 News about the gang war going down in
>Oaktree Blvd. in Fairfax.
>
>
>
>I quickly got into my car and headed over to Fairfax. I got
>there just in time to watch two assholes beating the crap out of each other
>in front of six cop cars, an overhead news helicopter and surrounded by a
>news crew.
>
>NOW I feel much better.
>
>Anger management really does work!


Nyc Alberts wrote:
You are my guitar hero of the day!

Like your email alias, judging by this post of yours, it probably fits 
you IRL as well..

We should join forces, I get a kick doing stuff like this, and it's 
always more fun if you have a like minded partner to work with.

I usually work off the phone with inbound calls from telemarketers, 
here's a brief description of what I do that I posted elsewhere about a 
week ago:

~~~

I love making phone calls like this.

The week President Nixon died my desk partner and I played merry hell 
out with every building that didn't fly their flags at half mast in San 
Francisco's Financial District, most notably the Pacific Stock Exchange.

They didn't see that one coming.

Also, what's really fun for me is messing with telemarketers, I can keep 
them on the phone for hours until they realize that I'm just fucking 
with them.

Sometimes I pretend that I've got Down's Syndrome, and if it's a woman I 
immediately ask her what she's wearing and move the conversation in that 
direction.

I once got this one girl in New Delhi so upset, (the call immediately 
devolved into a "what are you wearing" from me and went downhill from 
there for 15 minutes), she called me back on her own cell phone just to 
cuss me out, never mind what she must have had to pay to get some 
satisfaction out of me.

heheheh.

I've been faulted for doing this, but it beats screaming "Do Not Call!!" 
at them and gets better results, they tend to never call back after 
dealing with me on the phone.

I should record this bit and put out a CD.

The diff is I don't make the calls, they call me, which gives me mad 
license to go to town.

A phone is a WMD in my hands and I don't know why more people don't do 
this, it's fun to turn tables, y'know.

I once bumped into NYT Select*, (bitches), columnist Paul Krugman* on 
the corner of 17th and K Street, NW, as we were both leaving Farragut 
Park one day, and I asked him to relay the following story of one of 
these calls of mine to his colleague, Mr. Tom "The World Is Flat" 
Friedman, since what I'm about to tell you is his bailiwick more than 
Krugman's.

I pretended to have LaTourette's Syndrome on this one call that came in 
and abused, (believe it or don't, she never once lost her cool and was 
polite throughout), this one female telemarketer, (who was selling a 
*local* landscaping firm's services), for about a half hour until *I* 
the one that was spent, and then I dropped it and started talking with her.

Turns out she was 23, was calling from Romania, had just graduated 
college, spoke 5 languages, and here's the punch line....

Was being paid $200USD a month to put up with my shit on the phone.

Make a decision, if you're a businessman, who would you hire?

A surly US GED holder that you pay $1,200.00 a month that's going to 
drive away your customers, or her?

And yet you people still hold on to the quaint notion that America isn't 
doomed by its own shit and ain't gonna have its lunch eaten by the 
Second World.

~nyc

* Fuck the NYT Select, go here: http://welcome-to-pottersville.blogspot.com/

Her eyes about bugged out of her head. 
>
>I went on and on with the bogus diet story and she was totally buying it. I told her that it was an easy, inexpensive diet and that the way it works is to load your pockets or purse with Purina nuggets and simply eat one or two every time you feel hungry. The package said the food is nutritionally complete so I was going to try it again. 
>
>I have to mention here that practically everyone in the line was by now enthralled with my story, particularly a tall guy behind her. Horrified, she asked if something in the dog food had poisoned me and was that was why I ended up in the hospital.

On 2/14/07, Mallorieknoxx <ina_dream@yahoo.com> wrote:
> again, this is something great i read online, i am not THIS clever....
>
> Mallorieknoxx <ina_dream@yahoo.com> wrote:  Speaking of f*cking with people on the phone.......
>
>
> >Subject: Anger management
> >
> >
> >
> >When you occasionally have a really bad day, and you just need to take it
> >out on someone, don't take it out on someone you know, take it out on someone
> >you don't know.
> >
> >I was sitting at my desk when I remembered a phone call I'd
> >forgotten to make. I found the number and dialed it. A man
> >answered, saying "Hello." I politely said, "This is Chris. Could I
> >please speak with Robyn Carter?"
> >
> >Suddenly a manic voice yelled out in my ear "Get the right f***ing number!"
> >and the phone was slammed down on me. I couldn't believe that anyone could be
> >so rude. When I tracked down Robyn's correct number to call her, I found
> >that I had accidentally transposed the last two digits.
> >
> >After hanging up with her, I decided to call the 'wrong' number
> >again.
> >
> >When the same guy answered the phone, I yelled, "You're an
> >asshole!" and hung up. I wrote his number down with the word
> >'asshole' next to it and put it in my desk drawer.
> >
> >Every couple of weeks, when I was paying bills or had a really bad day, I'd
> >call him up and yell, "You're an asshole!"
> >
> >It always cheered me up.
> >
> >When Caller ID was introduced, I thought my therapeutic 'asshole' calling
> >would have to stop. So, I called his number and said, "Hi, this is John Smith
> >from the telephone company.
> >I'm calling to see if you're familiar with our Caller ID Program?"
> >
> >He yelled "NO!" and slammed down the phone. I quickly called him back and
> >said, "That's because you're an asshole!" and hung up.
> >
> >
> >One day I was at the store, getting ready to pull into a parking
> >Spot. Some guy in a black BMW cut me off and pulled into the spot I had
> >patiently waited for. I hit the horn and yelled that I'd
> >been waiting for that spot, but the idiot ignored me. I noticed a
> >"For Sale" sign in his back window, so I wrote down his number.
> >
> >A couple of days later, right after calling the first asshole (I
> >had his number on speed dial,) I thought that I'd better call the
> >BMW asshole, too.
> >
> >I said, "Is this the man with the black BMW for sale?"
> >
> >He said, "Yes, it is." I asked, "Can you tell me where I can see
> >it?"
> >
> >He said, "Yes, I live at 34 Oaktree Blvd, in Fairfax. It's a
> >yellow rambler, and the car's parked right out in front."
> >
> >I asked, "What's your name?" He said, "My name is Don Hansen,"
> >
> >I asked, "When's a good time to catch you, Don?"
> >
> >He said, "I'm home every evening after five."
> >
> >I said, "Listen, Don, can I tell you something?"
> >
> >He said, "Yes?"
> >
> >I said, "Don, you're an asshole!"
> >
> >Then I hung up, and added his number to my speed dial, too.
> >
> >Now, when I had a problem, I had two assholes to call.
> >
> >Then I came up with an i dea. I called asshole #1.
> >
> >He said, "Hello."
> >
> >I said, "You're an asshole!" (But I didn't hang up.)
> >
> >He asked, "Are you still there?"
> >
> >I said, "Yeah,"
> >
> >He screamed, "Stop calling me,"
> >
> >I said, "Make me,"
> >
> >He asked, "Who are you?"
> >
> >I said, "My name is Don Hansen."
> >
> >He said, "Yeah? Where do you live?"
> >
> >I said, "Asshole, I live at 34 Oaktree Blvd, in Fairfax, a
> >yellow rambler, I have a black Beamer parked in front."
> >
> >He said, "I'm coming over right now, Don. And you had better start saying
> >your prayers."
> >
> >I said, "Yeah, like I'm really scared, asshole," and hung up.
> >
> >Then I called Asshole #2.
> >
> >He said, "Hello?"
> >
> >I said, "Hello, asshole,"
> >
> >He yelled, "If I ever find out who you are..."
> >
> >I said, "You'll what?"
> >
> >He exclaimed, "I'll kick your ass,"
> >
> >I answered, "Well, asshole, here's your chance. I'm coming over right now".
> >
> >Then I hung up and immediately called the police, saying that I
> >lived at 34 Oaktree Blvd, in Fairfax, and that I was on my way
> >over there to kill my gay lover.
> >
> >Then I called Channel 9 News about the gang war going down in
> >Oaktree Blvd. in Fairfax.
> >
> >
> >
> >I quickly got into my car and headed over to Fairfax. I got
> >there just in time to watch two assholes beating the crap out of each other
> >in front of six cop cars, an overhead news helicopter and surrounded by a
> >news crew.
> >
> >NOW I feel much better.
> >
> >Anger management really does work!
>
>
> Nyc Alberts wrote:
> You are my guitar hero of the day!
>
> Like your email alias, judging by this post of yours, it probably fits
> you IRL as well..
>
> We should join forces, I get a kick doing stuff like this, and it's
> always more fun if you have a like minded partner to work with.
>
> I usually work off the phone with inbound calls from telemarketers,
> here's a brief description of what I do that I posted elsewhere about a
> week ago:
>
> ~~~
>
> I love making phone calls like this.
>
> The week President Nixon died my desk partner and I played merry hell
> out with every building that didn't fly their flags at half mast in San
> Francisco's Financial District, most notably the Pacific Stock Exchange.
>
> They didn't see that one coming.
>
> Also, what's really fun for me is messing with telemarketers, I can keep
> them on the phone for hours until they realize that I'm just fucking
> with them.
>
> Sometimes I pretend that I've got Down's Syndrome, and if it's a woman I
> immediately ask her what she's wearing and move the conversation in that
> direction.
>
> I once got this one girl in New Delhi so upset, (the call immediately
> devolved into a "what are you wearing" from me and went downhill from
> there for 15 minutes), she called me back on her own cell phone just to
> cuss me out, never mind what she must have had to pay to get some
> satisfaction out of me.
>
> heheheh.
>
> I've been faulted for doing this, but it beats screaming "Do Not Call!!"
> at them and gets better results, they tend to never call back after
> dealing with me on the phone.
>
> I should record this bit and put out a CD.
>
> The diff is I don't make the calls, they call me, which gives me mad
> license to go to town.
>
> A phone is a WMD in my hands and I don't know why more people don't do
> this, it's fun to turn tables, y'know.
>
> I once bumped into NYT Select*, (bitches), columnist Paul Krugman* on
> the corner of 17th and K Street, NW, as we were both leaving Farragut
> Park one day, and I asked him to relay the following story of one of
> these calls of mine to his colleague, Mr. Tom "The World Is Flat"
> Friedman, since what I'm about to tell you is his bailiwick more than
> Krugman's.
>
> I pretended to have LaTourette's Syndrome on this one call that came in
> and abused, (believe it or don't, she never once lost her cool and was
> polite throughout), this one female telemarketer, (who was selling a
> *local* landscaping firm's services), for about a half hour until *I*
> the one that was spent, and then I dropped it and started talking with her.
>
> Turns out she was 23, was calling from Romania, had just graduated
> college, spoke 5 languages, and here's the punch line....
>
> Was being paid $200USD a month to put up with my shit on the phone.
>
> Make a decision, if you're a businessman, who would you hire?
>
> A surly US GED holder that you pay $1,200.00 a month that's going to
> drive away your customers, or her?
>
> And yet you people still hold on to the quaint notion that America isn't
> doomed by its own shit and ain't gonna have its lunch eaten by the
> Second World.
>
> ~nyc
>
> * Fuck the NYT Select, go here: http://welcome-to-pottersville.blogspot.com/
>
> Mallorieknoxx wrote:
>
> >I was in Wal-Mart buying a large bag of Purina for my dogs and was in line to check out. A woman behind me asked if I had a dog........ Duh!
> >
> >
> >I was feeling a bit crabby so on impulse, I told her no, I was starting The Purina Diet again, although I probably shouldn't because I'd ended up in the hospital last time, but that I'd lost 50 pounds before I awakened in an intensive care unit with tubes coming out of most of my orifices and IVs in both arms. Her eyes about bugged out of her head.
> >
> >I went on and on with the bogus diet story and she was totally buying it. I told her that it was an easy, inexpensive diet and that the way it works is to load your pockets or purse with Purina nuggets and simply eat one or two every time you feel hungry. The package said the food is nutritionally complete so I was going to try it again.
> >
> >I have to mention here that practically everyone in the line was by now enthralled with my story, particularly a tall guy behind her. Horrified, she asked if something in the dog food had poisoned me and was that was why I ended up in the hospital.
> >
> >I said no.....I'd been sitting in the street licking my butt when a car hit me.
> >
> >I thought the tall guy was going to have to be carried out the door.
> >
> >

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Purina Diet... DJ Seven....

After DJ Seven wouldn't take me off his mailing list,
I routinely hunted his ISP down and had his accounts
turned off. This didn't seem to curb his love for
spam.

So, I then tracked down his home phone, fax, and cell.
For months, I set my computer up to ring the three
numbers in succession, randomly at night, early am,
and sometimes just in the middle of the day.

I don't receive his emails anymore.

E

> I usually work off the phone with inbound calls from
> telemarketers, 
> here's a brief description of what I do that I
> posted elsewhere about a 
> week ago:
>

> 
> I love making phone calls like this.
> 
> The week President Nixon died my desk partner and I
> played merry hell 
> out with every building that didn't fly their flags
> at half mast in San 
> Francisco's Financial District, most notably the
> Pacific Stock Exchange.
> 
> They didn't see that one coming.
> 
> Also, what's really fun for me is messing with
> telemarketers, I can keep 
> them on the phone for hours until they realize that
> I'm just fucking 
> with them.
> 
> Sometimes I pretend that I've got Down's Syndrome,
> and if it's a woman I 
> immediately ask her what she's wearing and move the
> conversation in that 
> direction.
> 
> I once got this one girl in New Delhi so upset, (the
> call immediately 
> devolved into a "what are you wearing" from me and
> went downhill from 
> there for 15 minutes), she called me back on her own
> cell phone just to 
> cuss me out, never mind what she must have had to
> pay to get some 
> satisfaction out of me.
> 
> heheheh.
> 
> I've been faulted for doing this, but it beats
> screaming "Do Not Call!!" 
> at them and gets better results, they tend to never
> call back after 
> dealing with me on the phone.
> 
> I should record this bit and put out a CD.
> 
> The diff is I don't make the calls, they call me,
> which gives me mad 
> license to go to town.
> 
> A phone is a WMD in my hands and I don't know why
> more people don't do 
> this, it's fun to turn tables, y'know.
> 
> I once bumped into NYT Select*, (bitches), columnist
> Paul Krugman* on 
> the corner of 17th and K Street, NW, as we were both
> leaving Farragut 
> Park one day, and I asked him to relay the following
> story of one of 
> these calls of mine to his colleague, Mr. Tom "The
> World Is Flat" 
> Friedman, since what I'm about to tell you is his
> bailiwick more than 
> Krugman's.
> 
> I pretended to have LaTourette's Syndrome on this
> one call that came in 
> and abused, (believe it or don't, she never once
> lost her cool and was 
> polite throughout), this one female telemarketer,
> (who was selling a 
> *local* landscaping firm's services), for about a
> half hour until *I* 
> the one that was spent, and then I dropped it and
> started talking with her.
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: More tech geekery

FWIW, I studied neural network technology at USC with Bart Kosko back in th=
e eighties and did work for the government applying the technology as well.=
  My projects in the field included designing a neural computer for ARPA ca=
lled the "demon" which was a dual mode (analog/digital) neural computer bas=
ed on an Intel neural chip, pattern recognition for chemical/biological wea=
pon recognition, and a neural network based algebra tutoring system.=0A=0AT=
he whole neural hardware path sort of died out.  With the continued rapid e=
volution of conventional processors, most neural applications use simulatio=
ns on conventional  machines rather than special purpose hardware.  However=
, neural software is out there doing some interesting things.  Probably the=
 largest non-DoD company doing neural network stuff was Hecht-Neilsen, aka =
HNC, and they were recently sold to Fair Isaac up here in Marin county.  Th=
eir software is used by major credit card networks to detect fraudulent tra=
nsactions.  =0A=0AEverytime you use a credit card there is a very good chan=
ce that a neural network is actually evaluating your transaction.=0A=0AAs f=
ar as self awareness, well, that's another riff entirely.=0A=0ARegards,=0A=

Subject: [sfraves] BP: THIS Friday: PLAZA DE FUNK  @ Mighty  - a SEISMIC event!

This Friday, February 16th - Plaza de Funk!!!!

For a taste of what plaza sounds like: 
http://mightybreaks.com/audio/plazadefunk/PlazaDeFunk-FatSetBounce.mp3

The longest running breaks monthly in San Francisco gets ready to host the 
Cowboys and their arch rivals SEISMIC, to celebrate a new year of Mighty 
monthlies and a first-time SF appearance by breaks newcomer PLAZA de FUNK 
(West Records, FAT!, UK).

profile.myspace.com/plazadefunk

You've heard the Drum Monkey remix dropped by several DJs at BOC, and our 
new Italian friend is ready to rock the party he has heard so much about 
with two of SFs "infamous" crews.

Featuring Cowboy DJs:
8ball
The Geometrist
Mancub
Evinrude

And from SEISMIC:
Murphstar
Trav
Samira
Brett Pinkin

Outside, weather permitting:
Kapt'n Kirk
...and others TBD

Friday, February 16, 2007
10:00 PM  4:00 AM
Mighty, 199 Utah, SF, CA
More Info: 415-626-7001
www.mighty119.com
mightybreaks.com

> --- Mallorieknoxx <ina_dream@yahoo.com> wrote:

>> again, this is something great i read online, i am
>> not THIS clever....

>> Mallorieknoxx <ina_dream@yahoo.com> wrote:  Speaking
>> of f*cking with people on the phone.......
>>
>>
>>> Subject: Anger management
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> When you occasionally have a really bad day, and
>> you just need to take it
>>> out on someone, don't take it out on someone you
>> know, take it out on someone
>>> you don't know.
>>>
>>> I was sitting at my desk when I remembered a phone
>> call I'd
>>> forgotten to make. I found the number and dialed
>> it. A man
>>> answered, saying "Hello." I politely said, "This is
>> Chris. Could I
>>> please speak with Robyn Carter?"
>>>
>>> Suddenly a manic voice yelled out in my ear "Get
>> the right f***ing number!"
>>> and the phone was slammed down on me. I couldn't
>> believe that anyone could be
>>> so rude. When I tracked down Robyn's correct number
>> to call her, I found
>>> that I had accidentally transposed the last two
>> digits.
>>>
>>> After hanging up with her, I decided to call the
>> 'wrong' number
>>> again.
>>>
>>> When the same guy answered the phone, I yelled,
>> "You're an
>>> asshole!" and hung up. I wrote his number down with
>> the word
>>> 'asshole' next to it and put it in my desk drawer.
>>>
>>> Every couple of weeks, when I was paying bills or
>> had a really bad day, I'd
>>> call him up and yell, "You're an asshole!"
>>>
>>> It always cheered me up.
>>>
>>> When Caller ID was introduced, I thought my
>> therapeutic 'asshole' calling
>>> would have to stop. So, I called his number and
>> said, "Hi, this is John Smith
>>> from the telephone company.
>>> I'm calling to see if you're familiar with our
>> Caller ID Program?"
>>>
>>> He yelled "NO!" and slammed down the phone. I
>> quickly called him back and
>>> said, "That's because you're an asshole!" and hung
>> up.
>>>
>>>
>>> One day I was at the store, getting ready to pull
>> into a parking
>>> Spot. Some guy in a black BMW cut me off and pulled
>> into the spot I had
>>> patiently waited for. I hit the horn and yelled
>> that I'd
>>> been waiting for that spot, but the idiot ignored
>> me. I noticed a
>>> "For Sale" sign in his back window, so I wrote down
>> his number.
>>>
>>> A couple of days later, right after calling the
>> first asshole (I
>>> had his number on speed dial,) I thought that I'd
>> better call the
>>> BMW asshole, too.
>>>
>>> I said, "Is this the man with the black BMW for
>> sale?"
>>>
>>> He said, "Yes, it is." I asked, "Can you tell me
>> where I can see
>>> it?"
>>>
>>> He said, "Yes, I live at 34 Oaktree Blvd, in
>> Fairfax. It's a
>>> yellow rambler, and the car's parked right out in
>> front."
>>>
>>> I asked, "What's your name?" He said, "My name is
>> Don Hansen,"
>>>
>>> I asked, "When's a good time to catch you, Don?"
>>>
>>> He said, "I'm home every evening after five."
>>>
>>> I said, "Listen, Don, can I tell you something?"
>>>
>>> He said, "Yes?"
>>>
>>> I said, "Don, you're an asshole!"
>>>
>>> Then I hung up, and added his number to my speed
>> dial, too.
>>>
>>> Now, when I had a problem, I had two assholes to
>> call.
>>>
>>> Then I came up with an i dea. I called asshole #1.
>>>
>>> He said, "Hello."
>>>
>>> I said, "You're an asshole!" (But I didn't hang
>> up.)
>>>
>>> He asked, "Are you still there?"
>>>
>>> I said, "Yeah,"
>>>
>>> He screamed, "Stop calling me,"
>>>
>>> I said, "Make me,"
>>>
>>> He asked, "Who are you?"
>>>
>>> I said, "My name is Don Hansen."
>>>
>>> He said, "Yeah? Where do you live?"
>>>
>>> I said, "Asshole, I live at 34 Oaktree Blvd, in
>> Fairfax, a
>>> yellow rambler, I have a black Beamer parked in
>> front."
>>>
>>> He said, "I'm coming over right now, Don. And you
>> had better start saying
>>> your prayers."
>>>
>>> I said, "Yeah, like I'm really scared, asshole,"
>> and hung up.
>>>
>>> Then I called Asshole #2.
>>>
>>> He said, "Hello?"
>>>
>>> I said, "Hello, asshole,"
>>>
>>> He yelled, "If I ever find out who you are..."
>>>
>>> I said, "You'll what?"
>>>
>>> He exclaimed, "I'll kick your ass,"
>>>
>>> I answered, "Well, asshole, here's your chance. I'm
>> coming over right now".
>>>
>>> Then I hung up and immediately called the police,
>> saying that I
>>> lived at 34 Oaktree Blvd, in Fairfax, and that I
>> was on my way
>>> over there to kill my gay lover.
>>>
>>> Then I called Channel 9 News about the gang war
>> going down in
>>> Oaktree Blvd. in Fairfax.
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> I quickly got into my car and headed over to
>> Fairfax. I got
>>> there just in time to watch two assholes beating
>> the crap out of each other
>>> in front of six cop cars, an overhead news
>> helicopter and surrounded by a
>>> news crew.
>>>
>>> NOW I feel much better.
>>>
>>> Anger management really does work!
>>

>> I usually work off the phone with inbound calls from

>> here's a brief description of what I do that I
>> posted elsewhere about a

>>
>> ~~~
>>
>> I love making phone calls like this.
>>
>> The week President Nixon died my desk partner and I
>> played merry hell
>> out with every building that didn't fly their flags
>> at half mast in San
>> Francisco's Financial District, most notably the
>> Pacific Stock Exchange.
>>
>> They didn't see that one coming.
>>
>> Also, what's really fun for me is messing with
>> telemarketers, I can keep
>> them on the phone for hours until they realize that
>> I'm just fucking
>> with them.
>>
>> Sometimes I pretend that I've got Down's Syndrome,
>> and if it's a woman I
>> immediately ask her what she's wearing and move the
>> conversation in that
>> direction.
>>
>> I once got this one girl in New Delhi so upset, (the
>> call immediately
>> devolved into a "what are you wearing" from me and
>> went downhill from
>> there for 15 minutes), she called me back on her own
>> cell phone just to
>> cuss me out, never mind what she must have had to
>> pay to get some
>> satisfaction out of me.
>>
>> heheheh.
>>
>> I've been faulted for doing this, but it beats
>> screaming "Do Not Call!!"
>> at them and gets better results, they tend to never
>> call back after
>> dealing with me on the phone.
>>
>> I should record this bit and put out a CD.
>>
>> The diff is I don't make the calls, they call me,
>> which gives me mad
>> license to go to town.
>>
>> A phone is a WMD in my hands and I don't know why
>> more people don't do
>> this, it's fun to turn tables, y'know.
>>
>> I once bumped into NYT Select*, (bitches), columnist
>> Paul Krugman* on
>> the corner of 17th and K Street, NW, as we were both
>> leaving Farragut
>> Park one day, and I asked him to relay the following
>> story of one of
>> these calls of mine to his colleague, Mr. Tom "The
>> World Is Flat"
>> Friedman, since what I'm about to tell you is his
>> bailiwick more than
>> Krugman's.
>>
>> I pretended to have LaTourette's Syndrome on this
>> one call that came in
>> and abused, (believe it or don't, she never once
>> lost her cool and was
>> polite throughout), this one female telemarketer,
>> (who was selling a
>> *local* landscaping firm's services), for about a
>> half hour until *I*
>> the one that was spent, and then I dropped it and
>> started talking with her.
>>
>> Turns out she was 23, was calling from Romania, had
>> just graduated
>> college, spoke 5 languages, and here's the punch
>> line....
>>
>> Was being paid $200USD a month to put up with my
>> shit on the phone.
>>
>> Make a decision, if you're a businessman, who would
>> you hire?
>>
>> A surly US GED holder that you pay $1,200.00 a month
>> that's going to
>> drive away your customers, or her?
>>
>> And yet you people still hold on to the quaint
>> notion that America isn't
>> doomed by its own shit and ain't gonna have its
>> lunch eaten by the
>> Second World.
>>
>> ~nyc

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SF Pillow Fight!!!

I once got a group of like 15 friends together with about 100 cans of 
Silly String and then we all rolled over to Borrones outdoor cafe at 
Kepler's Books in Menlo Park and went up to a table of friends that had 
like 7 to 10 people sitting at it, slammed about 15 cans on the table 
and yelled "Let's Go!!!"

They dove for the cans and then we went at it like a pack of mad chihauhas.

It was like being in the middle of a moving, living, breathing Jackson 
Polllock painting in 3D.

By the time the waitstaff caught wind of what we were up to we had 
pretty much emptied the cans and were ready to bounce, which we did 
before they could ID us and like, ban us for life for this egregious 
breach of social etiquette.

Guess we had more of a blast doing that than the grunts are having these 
days using Silly String to spot IED trip wires in Iraq, huh?

~nyc

PS: Silly String is totally RR.

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

"Ha ha!  Ever had the feeling you've been cheated?" ~ J. Lydon, SF, 1978

I heard a second story about a tech who had a "keen sense of justice and 
retribution" who if you pissed him off on a call would remote access 
your box and pull your mouse and keyboard drivers.

machine and then..... nothing.

Dead air.

Whether or not this was just an urban legend, I never found out, because 
that was a pond I didn't wan't to go swimming in.

My life is complicated enough as it is.

>>>
>>>> Subject: Anger management
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> When you occasionally have a really bad day, and
>>>
>>> you just need to take it
>>>
>>>> out on someone, don't take it out on someone you
>>>
>>> know, take it out on someone
>>>
>>>> you don't know.
>>>>
>>>> I was sitting at my desk when I remembered a phone
>>>
>>> call I'd
>>>
>>>> forgotten to make. I found the number and dialed
>>>
>>> it. A man
>>>
>>>> answered, saying "Hello." I politely said, "This is
>>>
>>> Chris. Could I
>>>
>>>> please speak with Robyn Carter?"
>>>>
>>>> Suddenly a manic voice yelled out in my ear "Get
>>>
>>> the right f***ing number!"
>>>
>>>> and the phone was slammed down on me. I couldn't
>>>
>>> believe that anyone could be
>>>
>>>> so rude. When I tracked down Robyn's correct number
>>>
>>> to call her, I found
>>>
>>>> that I had accidentally transposed the last two
>>>
>>> digits.
>>>
>>>>
>>>> After hanging up with her, I decided to call the
>>>
>>> 'wrong' number
>>>
>>>> again.
>>>>
>>>> When the same guy answered the phone, I yelled,
>>>
>>> "You're an
>>>
>>>> asshole!" and hung up. I wrote his number down with
>>>
>>> the word
>>>
>>>> 'asshole' next to it and put it in my desk drawer.
>>>>
>>>> Every couple of weeks, when I was paying bills or
>>>
>>> had a really bad day, I'd
>>>
>>>> call him up and yell, "You're an asshole!"
>>>>
>>>> It always cheered me up.
>>>>
>>>> When Caller ID was introduced, I thought my
>>>
>>> therapeutic 'asshole' calling
>>>
>>>> would have to stop. So, I called his number and
>>>
>>> said, "Hi, this is John Smith
>>>
>>>> from the telephone company.
>>>> I'm calling to see if you're familiar with our
>>>
>>> Caller ID Program?"
>>>
>>>>
>>>> He yelled "NO!" and slammed down the phone. I
>>>
>>> quickly called him back and
>>>
>>>> said, "That's because you're an asshole!" and hung
>>>
>>> up.
>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> One day I was at the store, getting ready to pull
>>>
>>> into a parking
>>>
>>>> Spot. Some guy in a black BMW cut me off and pulled
>>>
>>> into the spot I had
>>>
>>>> patiently waited for. I hit the horn and yelled
>>>
>>> that I'd
>>>
>>>> been waiting for that spot, but the idiot ignored
>>>
>>> me. I noticed a
>>>
>>>> "For Sale" sign in his back window, so I wrote down
>>>
>>> his number.
>>>
>>>>
>>>> A couple of days later, right after calling the
>>>
>>> first asshole (I
>>>
>>>> had his number on speed dial,) I thought that I'd
>>>
>>> better call the
>>>
>>>> BMW asshole, too.
>>>>
>>>> I said, "Is this the man with the black BMW for
>>>
>>> sale?"
>>>
>>>>
>>>> He said, "Yes, it is." I asked, "Can you tell me
>>>
>>> where I can see
>>>
>>>> it?"
>>>>
>>>> He said, "Yes, I live at 34 Oaktree Blvd, in
>>>
>>> Fairfax. It's a
>>>
>>>> yellow rambler, and the car's parked right out in
>>>
>>> front."
>>>
>>>>
>>>> I asked, "What's your name?" He said, "My name is
>>>
>>> Don Hansen,"
>>>
>>>>
>>>> I asked, "When's a good time to catch you, Don?"
>>>>
>>>> He said, "I'm home every evening after five."
>>>>
>>>> I said, "Listen, Don, can I tell you something?"
>>>>
>>>> He said, "Yes?"
>>>>
>>>> I said, "Don, you're an asshole!"
>>>>
>>>> Then I hung up, and added his number to my speed
>>>
>>> dial, too.
>>>
>>>>
>>>> Now, when I had a problem, I had two assholes to
>>>
>>> call.
>>>
>>>>
>>>> Then I came up with an i dea. I called asshole #1.
>>>>
>>>> He said, "Hello."
>>>>
>>>> I said, "You're an asshole!" (But I didn't hang
>>>
>>> up.)
>>>
>>>>
>>>> He asked, "Are you still there?"
>>>>
>>>> I said, "Yeah,"
>>>>
>>>> He screamed, "Stop calling me,"
>>>>
>>>> I said, "Make me,"
>>>>
>>>> He asked, "Who are you?"
>>>>
>>>> I said, "My name is Don Hansen."
>>>>
>>>> He said, "Yeah? Where do you live?"
>>>>
>>>> I said, "Asshole, I live at 34 Oaktree Blvd, in
>>>
>>> Fairfax, a
>>>
>>>> yellow rambler, I have a black Beamer parked in
>>>
>>> front."
>>>
>>>>
>>>> He said, "I'm coming over right now, Don. And you
>>>
>>> had better start saying
>>>
>>>> your prayers."
>>>>
>>>> I said, "Yeah, like I'm really scared, asshole,"
>>>
>>> and hung up.
>>>
>>>>
>>>> Then I called Asshole #2.
>>>>
>>>> He said, "Hello?"
>>>>
>>>> I said, "Hello, asshole,"
>>>>
>>>> He yelled, "If I ever find out who you are..."
>>>>
>>>> I said, "You'll what?"
>>>>
>>>> He exclaimed, "I'll kick your ass,"
>>>>
>>>> I answered, "Well, asshole, here's your chance. I'm
>>>
>>> coming over right now".
>>>
>>>>
>>>> Then I hung up and immediately called the police,
>>>
>>> saying that I
>>>
>>>> lived at 34 Oaktree Blvd, in Fairfax, and that I
>>>
>>> was on my way
>>>
>>>> over there to kill my gay lover.
>>>>
>>>> Then I called Channel 9 News about the gang war
>>>
>>> going down in
>>>
>>>> Oaktree Blvd. in Fairfax.
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> I quickly got into my car and headed over to
>>>
>>> Fairfax. I got
>>>
>>>> there just in time to watch two assholes beating
>>>
>>> the crap out of each other
>>>
>>>> in front of six cop cars, an overhead news
>>>
>>> helicopter and surrounded by a
>>>
>>>> news crew.
>>>>
>>>> NOW I feel much better.
>>>>
>>>> Anger management really does work!
