>>> I usually work off the phone with inbound calls from
>>> telemarketers,
>>> here's a brief description of what I do that I
>>> posted elsewhere about a
>>> week ago:
>>>
>>> ~~~
>>>
>>> I love making phone calls like this.
>>>
>>> The week President Nixon died my desk partner and I
>>> played merry hell
>>> out with every building that didn't fly their flags
>>> at half mast in San
>>> Francisco's Financial District, most notably the
>>> Pacific Stock Exchange.
>>>
>>> They didn't see that one coming.
>>>
>>> Also, what's really fun for me is messing with
>>> telemarketers, I can keep
>>> them on the phone for hours until they realize that
>>> I'm just fucking
>>> with them.
>>>
>>> Sometimes I pretend that I've got Down's Syndrome,
>>> and if it's a woman I
>>> immediately ask her what she's wearing and move the
>>> conversation in that
>>> direction.
>>>
>>> I once got this one girl in New Delhi so upset, (the
>>> call immediately
>>> devolved into a "what are you wearing" from me and
>>> went downhill from
>>> there for 15 minutes), she called me back on her own
>>> cell phone just to
>>> cuss me out, never mind what she must have had to
>>> pay to get some
>>> satisfaction out of me.
>>>
>>> heheheh.
>>>
>>> I've been faulted for doing this, but it beats
>>> screaming "Do Not Call!!"
>>> at them and gets better results, they tend to never
>>> call back after
>>> dealing with me on the phone.
>>>
>>> I should record this bit and put out a CD.
>>>
>>> The diff is I don't make the calls, they call me,
>>> which gives me mad
>>> license to go to town.
>>>
>>> A phone is a WMD in my hands and I don't know why
>>> more people don't do
>>> this, it's fun to turn tables, y'know.
>>>
>>> I once bumped into NYT Select*, (bitches), columnist
>>> Paul Krugman* on
>>> the corner of 17th and K Street, NW, as we were both
>>> leaving Farragut
>>> Park one day, and I asked him to relay the following
>>> story of one of
>>> these calls of mine to his colleague, Mr. Tom "The
>>> World Is Flat"
>>> Friedman, since what I'm about to tell you is his
>>> bailiwick more than
>>> Krugman's.
>>>
>>> I pretended to have LaTourette's Syndrome on this
>>> one call that came in
>>> and abused, (believe it or don't, she never once
>>> lost her cool and was
>>> polite throughout), this one female telemarketer,
>>> (who was selling a
>>> *local* landscaping firm's services), for about a
>>> half hour until *I*
>>> the one that was spent, and then I dropped it and
>>> started talking with her.
>>>
>>> Turns out she was 23, was calling from Romania, had
>>> just graduated
>>> college, spoke 5 languages, and here's the punch
>>> line....
>>>
>>> Was being paid $200USD a month to put up with my
>>> shit on the phone.
>>>
>>> Make a decision, if you're a businessman, who would
>>> you hire?
>>>
>>> A surly US GED holder that you pay $1,200.00 a month
>>> that's going to
>>> drive away your customers, or her?
>>>
>>> And yet you people still hold on to the quaint
>>> notion that America isn't
>>> doomed by its own shit and ain't gonna have its
>>> lunch eaten by the
>>> Second World.
>>>
>>> ~nyc
>>>
>>> * Fuck the NYT Select, go here:
>>> http://welcome-to-pottersville.blogspot.com/

The Ibogaine Cure For Heroin and Cocaine Addiction 2007
Labor Day March On Washington DC:

http://www.ibogainewalk.com/

http://apenwarmedinhell.blogspot.com/
http://digitalcomponents.blogspot.com/

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d5TU8o6TvNk

I'd Rather Be A Matin' Than A Hatin' ~ Me

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

"Ha ha!  Ever had the feeling you've been cheated?" ~ J. Lydon, SF, 1978

>> >Subject: Anger management

>> >I was sitting at my desk when I remembered a phone

>> >

>> >

>> >asshole!" and hung up. I wrote his number down with
>> the word
>> >'asshole' next to it and put it in my desk drawer.
>> >
>> >Every couple of weeks, when I was paying bills or
>> had a really bad day, I'd
>> >call him up and yell, "You're an asshole!"
>> >
>> >It always cheered me up.
>> >
>> >When Caller ID was introduced, I thought my
>> therapeutic 'asshole' calling
>> >would have to stop. So, I called his number and
>> said, "Hi, this is John Smith
>> >from the telephone company.
>> >I'm calling to see if you're familiar with our
>> Caller ID Program?"
>> >
>> >He yelled "NO!" and slammed down the phone. I
>> quickly called him back and
>> >said, "That's because you're an asshole!" and hung
>> up.
>> >
>> >
>> >One day I was at the store, getting ready to pull
>> into a parking
>> >Spot. Some guy in a black BMW cut me off and pulled
>> into the spot I had
>> >patiently waited for. I hit the horn and yelled
>> that I'd
>> >been waiting for that spot, but the idiot ignored
>> me. I noticed a
>> >"For Sale" sign in his back window, so I wrote down
>> his number.
>> >
>> >A couple of days later, right after calling the

>> >

>> >

>> I love making phone calls like this.

>> The week President Nixon died my desk partner and I
>> played merry hell

>> at half mast in San
>> Francisco's Financial District, most notably the
>> Pacific Stock Exchange.
>>
>> They didn't see that one coming.
>>
>> Also, what's really fun for me is messing with
>> telemarketers, I can keep

>> I'm just fucking

>>
>> Sometimes I pretend that I've got Down's Syndrome,
>> and if it's a woman I
>> immediately ask her what she's wearing and move the
>> conversation in that
>> direction.
>>
>> I once got this one girl in New Delhi so upset, (the
>> call immediately
>> devolved into a "what are you wearing" from me and
>> went downhill from

>> cell phone just to
>> cuss me out, never mind what she must have had to
>> pay to get some
>> satisfaction out of me.
>>
>> heheheh.
>>
>> I've been faulted for doing this, but it beats
>> screaming "Do Not Call!!"
>> at them and gets better results, they tend to never
>> call back after
>> dealing with me on the phone.
>>
>> I should record this bit and put out a CD.
>>
>> The diff is I don't make the calls, they call me,
>> which gives me mad
>> license to go to town.
>>
>> A phone is a WMD in my hands and I don't know why
>> more people don't do
>> this, it's fun to turn tables, y'know.
>>
>> I once bumped into NYT Select*, (bitches), columnist
>> Paul Krugman* on
>> the corner of 17th and K Street, NW, as we were both
>> leaving Farragut
>> Park one day, and I asked him to relay the following
>> story of one of
>> these calls of mine to his colleague, Mr. Tom "The
>> World Is Flat"
>> Friedman, since what I'm about to tell you is his
>> bailiwick more than
>> Krugman's.
>>
>> I pretended to have LaTourette's Syndrome on this
>> one call that came in
>> and abused, (believe it or don't, she never once
>> lost her cool and was
>> polite throughout), this one female telemarketer,
>> (who was selling a
>> *local* landscaping firm's services), for about a
>> half hour until *I*
>> the one that was spent, and then I dropped it and
>> started talking with her.
>>
>> Turns out she was 23, was calling from Romania, had
>> just graduated
>> college, spoke 5 languages, and here's the punch
>> line....
>>
>> Was being paid $200USD a month to put up with my
>> shit on the phone.
>>
>> Make a decision, if you're a businessman, who would
>> you hire?
>>
>> A surly US GED holder that you pay $1,200.00 a month
>> that's going to
>> drive away your customers, or her?
>>
>> And yet you people still hold on to the quaint
>> notion that America isn't
>> doomed by its own shit and ain't gonna have its
>> lunch eaten by the
>> Second World.
>>
>> ~nyc

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Purina Diet... DJ Seven....


Legend.

However what DID work was when you would call teh number, and get the ring, 
send down the isolation tone, which would turn off everything past the 
demarkation point, namely, inside the house.

Dead line, etc etc.  Wouldn't last forever, but great fun to somebody who 
didn't know how to bypass those on their house, which was just about 
everyone.  They're neat little pieces of hardware inside the junction box 
on your house.

>>>>>asshole!" and hung up. I wrote his number down with
>>>>

>>>>
>>>>>'asshole' next to it and put it in my desk drawer.
>>>>>

>>>>

>>>>
>>>>>call him up and yell, "You're an asshole!"
>>>>>
>>>>>It always cheered me up.
>>>>>
>>>>>When Caller ID was introduced, I thought my
>>>>

>>>>

>>>>

>>>>>One day I was at the store, getting ready to pull
>>>>

>>>>
>>>>>Spot. Some guy in a black BMW cut me off and pulled
>>>>

>>>>>patiently waited for. I hit the horn and yelled

>>>>
>>>>>been waiting for that spot, but the idiot ignored

>>>>Nyc Alberts wrote:
>>>>You are my guitar hero of the day!
>>>>
>>>>Like your email alias, judging by this post of
>>>>yours, it probably fits
>>>>you IRL as well..
>>>>
>>>>We should join forces, I get a kick doing stuff like
>>>>this, and it's
>>>>always more fun if you have a like minded partner to
>>>>work with.
>>>>
>>>>I usually work off the phone with inbound calls from
>>>>telemarketers,
>>>>here's a brief description of what I do that I
>>>>posted elsewhere about a
>>>>week ago:
>>>>
>>>>~~~
>>>>
>>>>I love making phone calls like this.
>>>>
>>>>The week President Nixon died my desk partner and I
>>>>played merry hell
>>>>out with every building that didn't fly their flags
>>>>at half mast in San
>>>>Francisco's Financial District, most notably the
>>>>Pacific Stock Exchange.
>>>>
>>>>They didn't see that one coming.
>>>>
>>>>Also, what's really fun for me is messing with
>>>>telemarketers, I can keep
>>>>them on the phone for hours until they realize that
>>>>I'm just fucking
>>>>with them.
>>>>
>>>>Sometimes I pretend that I've got Down's Syndrome,
>>>>and if it's a woman I
>>>>immediately ask her what she's wearing and move the
>>>>conversation in that
>>>>direction.
>>>>
>>>>I once got this one girl in New Delhi so upset, (the
>>>>call immediately
>>>>devolved into a "what are you wearing" from me and
>>>>went downhill from
>>>>there for 15 minutes), she called me back on her own
>>>>cell phone just to
>>>>cuss me out, never mind what she must have had to
>>>>pay to get some
>>>>satisfaction out of me.
>>>>
>>>>heheheh.
>>>>
>>>>I've been faulted for doing this, but it beats
>>>>screaming "Do Not Call!!"
>>>>at them and gets better results, they tend to never
>>>>call back after
>>>>dealing with me on the phone.
>>>>
>>>>I should record this bit and put out a CD.
>>>>
>>>>The diff is I don't make the calls, they call me,
>>>>which gives me mad
>>>>license to go to town.
>>>>
>>>>A phone is a WMD in my hands and I don't know why
>>>>more people don't do
>>>>this, it's fun to turn tables, y'know.
>>>>
>>>>I once bumped into NYT Select*, (bitches), columnist
>>>>Paul Krugman* on
>>>>the corner of 17th and K Street, NW, as we were both
>>>>leaving Farragut
>>>>Park one day, and I asked him to relay the following
>>>>story of one of
>>>>these calls of mine to his colleague, Mr. Tom "The
>>>>World Is Flat"
>>>>Friedman, since what I'm about to tell you is his
>>>>bailiwick more than
>>>>Krugman's.
>>>>
>>>>I pretended to have LaTourette's Syndrome on this
>>>>one call that came in
>>>>and abused, (believe it or don't, she never once
>>>>lost her cool and was
>>>>polite throughout), this one female telemarketer,
>>>>(who was selling a
>>>>*local* landscaping firm's services), for about a
>>>>half hour until *I*
>>>>the one that was spent, and then I dropped it and
>>>>started talking with her.
>>>>
>>>>Turns out she was 23, was calling from Romania, had
>>>>just graduated
>>>>college, spoke 5 languages, and here's the punch
>>>>line....
>>>>
>>>>Was being paid $200USD a month to put up with my
>>>>shit on the phone.
>>>>
>>>>Make a decision, if you're a businessman, who would
>>>>you hire?
>>>>
>>>>A surly US GED holder that you pay $1,200.00 a month
>>>>that's going to
>>>>drive away your customers, or her?
>>>>
>>>>And yet you people still hold on to the quaint
>>>>notion that America isn't
>>>>doomed by its own shit and ain't gonna have its
>>>>lunch eaten by the
>>>>Second World.
>>>>
>>>>~nyc
>>>>
>>>>* Fuck the NYT Select, go here:
>>>>http://welcome-to-pottersville.blogspot.com/

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed)


Hardly.

If we were truely at war with terror, and specifically, ptential terror 
domestically, then we would have locke dup our borders, especially the 
mexican border, and kept track of everyone trying to get into teh country.

We never did that.

The Mexican border is the biggest point of entry for people to get into 
this country illegally.  No, I'm not picking on teh mexicans, in fact, they 
take the brunt of people impersonateing workers trying to slip over 
here.  The other large spot peopel slip in is through Canada across the 
love canal, though anyone crossing there tends to glow in the dark afterwards.

They have already documented and detained quite a few on the wanted 
list.  From a statistical point of view, taking into account the amount of 
land to patrol, it's safe to say that for everyone one that was caught 
easily 100 slipped through without incident.

Instead, we have put our own citizens through the ringer, worried about 
politically correct ideals like "profiling" and gone out of our way not to 
offend.

The point is this:  If you are going to fight a war, then fight a 
war.  Don't do it half asses, don't use bandaids.  Strike hard, fast, and 
with brutal efficientcy.  Wipe out all opposition and make sure there's 
nobody left to retaliate.  Otherwise, don't go to war.

The word war get's tossed around so losely.  War isn't a fist fight.  War 
is the total elimination of an enemy, or beating them until they completely 
submit.

So yes, he's right.  If we were serious about the "War on terror" then we 
would have locked down our borders.  This is how we know that Bush is full 
of shit, because while he lauched a war on two fronts he then was pushing 
for open borders.  Sorry, but as einstein said "you can't simultaniously 
prepare for war and prevent war."  Say thing.  You can't claim to be going 
to war for our securit and safety while taking the front and back door off 
the hinges.

it's harde rto get into a bar in san francisco than it is to get into the 
country.

>What would be the consequences for the economy of actually closing the 
>borders?

When I say close, I don't mean barricade.  Closing means tighter security 
and checks.  Closeing doesn't mean a wall, it means stop the flow of 
unchecked entry and exit, and maybe running our check points as tight as 
the air lines do for domestic flights.

>How much money would it cost and how many soldiers would be required to do it?

Well, I'm sure the guys in Iraq wouldn't mind some domestic duty where they 
aren't dodging IED's and 7.54mm rounds all day.  Plenty of soldiers there.

>Its easy to talk say something like this and make it sound sensible so 
>long as you don't actually consider the real effort required or obvious 
>consequences of doing it.

The effort would have a much great effect of creating "National Security" 
than what we are doing right now.

>Note: I'm not fan of Bush, but his "failure" to close the borders isn't why.


Shatter

shatter@sonic.net
http://www.sonic.net/~shatter
Y!: Shatter707  ICQ: 8953718  MSN & AIM:  TheRealShatter
Soulseek:  Shatter242
http://www.imeem.com/  Shatter

We are getting a bit off subject.  I'm simply saying that if you are going 
to go to war with something, then you close up the borders.  That isn't to 
say you can't have free travel.  You of course immediately cite germany, 
which is a bad example, only because that was part of the whole eastern 
bloc aspect.  They were keping people in, not people out.

It would be very easy to secure (again, not barricade) the souther border. 
It's call a nice tall chain link fence.  It simply runs along our property 
and divides us from mexico.  It stops at roads.  Much if this is in place, 
I'm simply saying lets fix the parts that are broken.  Anyone deciding to 
go cross country wold find their way barred.  Anyoen with bolt cutters 
might find themselves looking down the barrel of a US troop wearing night 
vision.

Is this wrong?  They are breaking a law.  Then again, this is a whole 
nuther issue.

>Sealing the border only makes sense if you actually think "threats" to our 
>"security" are entering the country via that route.  The reality is that 
>the border closing movement is 99% about stopping illegal immigration from 
>Mexico and the "War on Drugs" and not about terrorism.

I'm tired) that were crossing into texas, posing as mexican illeagal 
immigrants.  They had shaved their beards, had new clothing, but when they 
got stopped in San Antonio and ran they matched up with peopel who two 
weeks previous had been attempting to come into teh countr via london and 
were denied.  That's one case I remember, there have been several.  Thus, 
why i said statistically that if we find any, considering how many peopel 
cross in undetected, that it's safe to say there are a LOT that have 
slipped in and not been caught.  Are they terrorists?  Who knows.  I guess 
if something get's bombed, we'll know.

>There just aren't that many terrorists to be stopped.  This is also why, 
>for example, the use of biometric security in airports to stop terrorists 
>probably won't work.  The number of false alarms is thousands of times 
>higher than the number of true reports.  Simple statistics.

True, false positives being what they are.

The whole war on terror isn't my method of fighting btw.  My solution is to 
further impose on the American people that it's the PEOPLE'S problem to do 
something.  Look out in their neighborhoods and take cae of 
yourself.  Learn how to defend, learn to shoot a gun.  Take care of 
yourself and stop waiting for somebody to do it for you.

Again, much of this is just an acedemic argument.  I'm simply supporting 
the original statement about war.  For the record, a "War on Terror" is 
liek a War on Drugs, or a War on Communism.

Common.  You can't fight ideals with bullets.  It's a stalemate.  It's 
something to just perpetuate the war machine and divert funding for 
something that could use the money a whole lot more.



>See also:
>
>http://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2006/07/terrorists_data.html
>http://www.foreignaffairs.org/20060901facomment85501/john-mueller/is-there-still-a-terrorist-threat.html
>
>Peace,

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed)

I was stunned that our borders weren't temporarily sealed after 9/!!, as 
they should have, been for at least a week or two.

That, and the massive over-reaction, (yes the deaths of 3,000+ innocent 
Americans on our own soil *is* a tragedy, I'm not minimizing that, but 
in terms of a percentage of our population of 300 million people, it's 
nothing, (like 0.0001% of the USA's population),  as is the loss of four 
planes, and 4 pieces of real estate on less than 25 acres of land, on 
the all together), to the attacks themselves, brought home just how out 
of touch, both the American people and its leadership were, and still 
are, to how The United States of America is perceived by the outside world.

Heads up, we're not very well liked for the shit that we, 5% of the 
world's population, has been ramming down the throats of the rest of the 
world, just because we can, and it was only a matter of time before an 
attack like this was going to happen.

The fact that we didn't see it coming, and reacted the way we did, 
points out just how much all of us have been blithely living in La-La 
Land about our behavior on the world stage for the last 15+ years prior.

We had some real opportunities in the immediate aftermath to do things 
differently, starting with,

"OK, you got a good shot in, and we're going to grieve for an 
appropriate period, and then since we're the most powerful nation in the 
world, we're going to just shrug it off, because something like this 
cannot, and *will not*, do any long term damage to us, and then we will 
land an equivalent punch on those that committed this atrocity, in 
response, and bring them to justice."

Then we're all going to take a time out and figure out what it is that 
we're doing that inspired this level of hatred that men would give their 
lives to try to hurt us like this, and then we'll sit down at the table 
and try to figure out what we *all* can do to ensure that something like 
this never happens again."

We didn't do any of that, did we?

Nope, we didn't.

Not after the 1st attack on the Towers in 1993, (which comes out of the 
same damned well), and not after this second attack, which our craven 
leadership then exploited for their own ends, by turning it into the 
21st Century version of the Reichstag Fire, (following the original 
playbook practically note for note, see: Patriot Acts I & II),  New 
Millennium Stylee.

See, doing all that would have required some real effort on our part, 
and let's face it, we're a lazy people, (not that there's anything wrong 
with that), and it's just a lot easier to rend cloth, gnash teeth and 
pull our hair out of our heads and act all aggrieved, like a spoliled 
child that's had their NintendoGame Boy or PSP  taken away for the 
night, over a hangnail of a wound, (while the rest of the world is 
hungry, blind in one eye, hard of hearing,  limping around with two 
broken legs and nursing a case of shingles and cancer), than it would 
have been to roll up our sleeves and actually do some work around this.

Instead we opted to follow this insane route we're on.

None of this addresses the question of sealed borders, so let me briefly 
return to that.

They're on their way here in The United States of America, and just as 
others have pointed out they won't be to keep people from getting in, 
but like in East Germany under the Soviet, they will be put up to keep 
people in.

For further discussion of this I yield the floor to Marshall Brain, (as 
close to an unimpeachible source that I can find, good luck digging up 
any discrediting dirt on him), who has written extensively on the 
subject for several years.

To get an overview of his thinking, follow all the links you see in the 
following items:

http://roboticnation.blogspot.com/2004/06/israel-to-build-robotic-borders.html
http://roboticnation.blogspot.com/2004/08/olympic-security.html

While I'm here, Marshall Brain has also got some interesting stuff to 
say about God and modern day religion, have fun with these:

http://whywontgodhealamputees.com/god-challenge.htm
http://whywontgodhealamputees.com/your-delusion.htm
http://whywontgodhealamputees.com/bible.htm
http://whywontgodhealamputees.com/summary.htm
http://godisimaginary.com/

That is all.

~nyc

dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

>Nice rant Deepfog, but I don't support the war in Iraq and I don't think you can fight a "war" on "terror".
>
>My primary point was that closing the border wouldn't stop terrorists
>from entering the country unless you also stopped air and sea travel.  And of course this wouldn't deal with terrorists already in the country if any.
>
>Also it would probably take at least 10%-20% of the force in Iraq to really close the U.S. border with Mexico.  I know there are much lower estimates floating around, but history suggests otherwise. 
>
>East Germany required 48,000 men to seal its border with West Germany despite the deployment of minefields, machine guns, dogs, and nearly 800 miles of steel fencing.  See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GDR_border_system
>
>Also, it is worth noting that this is a very real case where you should be careful what you wish for.  A closed border can keep people in
>as well as out. And the history of nations with sealed borders isn't so happy
>and wonderful.  Look it up. 
>
>Finally, one needs to consider the cost/benefit analysis.  There are plenty of things that kill more Americans every year than terrorism such as automobile accidents and air pollution.  Instead of spending billions on a border fence, we might want to look at automobile safety and cleaning up the environment instead.
>
>Peace,
>
>Peter

laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod

of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any

haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever

Subject: [sfraves] Geri Dahl We Hardly Knew Ye....

This is a continuation of a fictional piece.....

"Ig"

"What?!?"

"Buick Grand Twinkies Le Sabre hydroxide."

"Oh, OK."

Today, February 15th,  is the anniversary of Geri Dahl Last Post To SFR 
and let us all take a moment to contemplate what in the hell she was 
ever talking about.

Where she came from, nobody knows, (though a friend claims to have hung 
out with her), and where she has gone, nobody knows either.

Some say she's in Vegas, hanging with Mr. Cooper, Elvis, and 900 foot Jesus.

Some say she sits in Karl Rove's ear and tells him what to do, which 
would explain a lot, nicht wahr?

Some say she never existed in the first place and is just the mass, 
collective hallucination of SFR.

Some say that she's the Head Writer of the Cartoon Network, which, given 
the preponderence of the evidence, is the most credible theory out there.

Some say she was the one that guided that missile into The Pentagon.

Some say that none of this is true.

Some say all of this is true.

Whatever the case may be, one shining truth stands out, like Reagan's 
shining city on a hill, if Geri Dahl did not exist, it would be 
necessary to invent her.

Don't know about you, but since I haven't heard hide nor hair of her, in 
a dog's age, I'm a gonna go light a candle, pour out a 40 on the curb, 
and debate her place in the Pantheon of the Events of this Day: 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/February_15#Events

I'd also like to move that from This Day Forward February 15th Shall Be 
Forever Known As "Geri Dahl Day."

Discuss amonngst yourselves.

Xin Nian Hao!

~nyc

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Tonight! Alloy Trex live!



Hi all,

Alex and I are performing at our local lounge, the ReTox tonight, as
our live downtempo duo, "Alloy Trex".  We do breaky, dubby, psy tunes
with lots of beat mashing and synth tweaking.  You might remember us 
from the downtempo rooms of past psy parties, mostly Koinonea, but
also a few others.

ReTox is a very mellow bar literally at the edge of the city in the quirky
Dogpatch neighborhood, just below Potrero Hill.  Super-easy parking, no
cover or anything.  We will play at around 9pm.

We have some samples of our most recent tracks here:

http://www.alloytrex.com/

ReTox Lounge:

http://www.retoxsf.com

-troy

From: Nyc Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>

Subject: [sfraves] Re: Geri Dahl We Hardly Knew Ye....

My bad, I forgot to include Geri Dahl's Original Last SFR Post from two 
years ago today.

Well, you never asked for it, but here it is, anyways, in all its 
ever-loving. completely linear thought flow, Glory:

>Date: Tue, 15 Feb 2005 16:29:37 -0800 (PST)
>From: Geri Dahl <eeelips@yahoo.com>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: [sfraves] drip, drip, drool nrr
>
>Hello, this is a continuation of a fictional piece:
> 
>"what are you doing, ig?"
> 
>"what does it look like? i am salivating."
> 
>"did you finish all of your candy yet?"
> 
>"no. i am taking a break." :)
>
>		
>---------------------------------
>Do you Yahoo!?
> Yahoo! Mail - You care about security. So do we.
>
>  
>
And take a break, she did.

"Geri, wait, come back...."

Oh, shit, no, that's "Shane", never mind.

~nyc


Nyc Alberts wrote:

> This is a continuation of a fictional piece.....
>
> "Ig"
>
> "What?!?"
>
> "Buick Grand Twinkies Le Sabre hydroxide."
>
> "Oh, OK."
>
> Today, February 15th,  is the anniversary of Geri Dahl Last Post To 
> SFR and let us all take a moment to contemplate what in the hell she 
> was ever talking about.
>
> Where she came from, nobody knows, (though a friend claims to have 
> hung out with her), and where she has gone, nobody knows either.
>
> Some say she's in Vegas, hanging with Mr. Cooper, Elvis, and 900 foot 
> Jesus.
>
> Some say she sits in Karl Rove's ear and tells him what to do, which 
> would explain a lot, nicht wahr?
>
> Some say she never existed in the first place and is just the mass, 
> collective hallucination of SFR.
>
> Some say that she's the Head Writer of the Cartoon Network, which, 
> given the preponderence of the evidence, is the most credible theory 
> out there.
>
> Some say she was the one that guided that missile into The Pentagon.
>
> Some say that none of this is true.
>
> Some say all of this is true.
>
> Whatever the case may be, one shining truth stands out, like Reagan's 
> shining city on a hill, if Geri Dahl did not exist, it would be 
> necessary to invent her.
>
> Don't know about you, but since I haven't heard hide nor hair of her, 
> in a dog's age, I'm a gonna go light a candle, pour out a 40 on the 
> curb, and debate her place in the Pantheon of the Events of this Day: 
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/February_15#Events
>
> I'd also like to move that from This Day Forward February 15th Shall 
> Be Forever Known As "Geri Dahl Day."
>
> Discuss amonngst yourselves.
>
> Xin Nian Hao!
>
> ~nyc
>


--

Labor Day March On Washington DC:

http://www.ibogainewalk.com/

http://apenwarmedinhell.blogspot.com/
http://digitalcomponents.blogspot.com/

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d5TU8o6TvNk

I'd Rather Be A Matin' Than A Hatin' ~ Me

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

"Ha ha!  Ever had the feeling you've been cheated?" ~ J. Lydon, SF, 1978

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: THEY THOUGHT THEY WERE FREE

My favorite current "Conspiracy Theory" of the moment is the one where 
Star Trek creator, one Gene Rodenberry, reached out from the grave with 
his cold, dead, hand, and sent the world the Borg, "7 of 9",  just so 
The Democratic Junior United States Senator of Illinois, one Mister 
Barack Hussein Obama, could run for the US Senate, and win, and then run 
for the President of The United States of America, just so he, 
Rodenberry could get a capricious kick out of giving Hillary Rodham 
Clinton a severe case of the kittens.

heheheh.

It's a knee slapper, not near as funny as the Mark Foley page scandal 
thing, (nothing can beat that, I've never seen Fox News Anchor Brit Hume 
squirm quite like that before), but, you gotta admit, given the unsavory 
details, pretty hysterical, nonetheless.

And here's the punchline....

Unlike every other conspiracy theory that's floating out there in the 
ether....

"It's all true."

You can look it up:

http://tinyurl.com/352nhm
http://tinyurl.com/avlbu

Who's smiling now?
http://tinyurl.com/yo55ar

My favorite part of all this is, in a case of Poetic Justice being 
totally real, and served up hot, and piping, is that "Jack Ryan" is also 
the name of Tom Clancy's All American Super Duper Wet Dream Hero that 
the whackos on the right circle jerk off to every night, which was 
dude's main, (some say only), selling point in his burgeoning political 
career that Rodenberry destroyed from the great beyond.

Can't make this shit up.

Xin Nian Hao!

I'd Rather Be A Matin' Than A Hatin' ~ Me

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Tonal - Fire Engine Red next Friday w/ Miles Maeda + Brown!

Rock It Science, Prismatic Tracks, Crush Collective, and sfhousemusic.com
present:

Tonal - Fire Engine Red

Friday, February 23rd
11 PM 'til very late

SF Location: call 888-482-9281 or 415-412-0406, or visit prismatictracks.com
or sfhousemusic.com the day of for directions 

$10 before midnight, $15 after
$5 discount for dressing in Fire Engine Red
(at door person's discretion--make some serious effort people!)
 
After the epic party experience of Electric Blue we are very excited to
bring you Tonal: Fire Engine Red!  Get ready for the next throwdown in this
series of sick new color themed parties brought to you by some of the
hottest crews in the underground house scene. We are teaming up to bring you
only the best in funky, floorshaking underground house music to keep you
grooving until the break of dawn. Tonal parties will showcase talent flown
in from out of town as well as some of your favorite local house jocks.
Strap on your dancing shoes and get ready to move it! 
 
DJ's:
 
DJ Miles Maeda (Ouvre, Aroma, Apt Entertainment)--Los Angeles/Chicago
 
Miles Maeda was one of the pioneering members of Chicago's scene in the
early '90s, putting out a slew of now legendary mixtapes that inspired many
a young aspiring dj.  Miles has since grown to be a favorite dj of many,
known for his precise mixing skills and poised presence behind the decks.
Sharing a residency at Chicago's Smartbar alongside Justin Long and DJ
Heather, travelling the world to share his  music with everyone, and
consistently putting out top notch tracks keeps Miles very busy.  We are
very excited to have him out for our 2nd Tonal party and can't wait to hear
him lay it down!  www.milesmaeda.com
 
Brown (Drop Music, Aroma, Mobile Trax)--Nottingham, UK
 
Nottingham based vocalist and producer, Brown is one of the key players in
the new UK sound which has had a huge impact on the record bags of our
favorite dj's. Featured in collaborations with Littlemen, Inland Knights, Da
Sunlounge, Andrew Phelan & Origami, and Bryan Jones, Brown has put tracks
out on many a hot label such as Drop, Mobile Trax, Aroma, Myna, Prismatic,
and many more.  Brown's debut SF appearance at Crush-o-matic last summer had
everybody grooving, and we are happy to welcome him back for Round Two for
another dj set featuring himself on live vocals.
www.myspace.com/brownrecordings
 
Andrew Phelan & Origami (Prismatic, Drop Music, So Sound)
 
One of SF's fastest growing duos in both the DJ and production realms,
Andrew and Origami put down some serious business.  The boys tore it up at
Electric Blue and will surely do so again this time.  A Chicago native, Mr.
Phelan brings the funk just how we like it with Origami backing him up on
live bass keeping the speakers booming and your bodies moving!
www.myspace.com/apo 
 
Eric Sharp (Rock It Science)
 
Founder of the Rock It Science crew, Eric Sharp has quickly built a name for
himself with his infectious energy behind the decks and the versatility to
rock any party. Eric's opening set at Electric Blue got everybody going just
right.  This time Eric will throw down a Fire Engine Red closing set,
leaving everybody begging for more and heading for the Endup.
www.myspace.com/ericsharp
 
Rob Crush (Crush Collective)
 
Buckle up San Francisco!  Rob Crush seems to be everywhere at once,
spreading the good word about some of our city's favorite parties.  What you
may not know about Rob is that he has secretly been honing his craft, mixing
records deep within the bowels of a dj research laboratory covered by a
biotechnology front.  You are going to wonder why you haven't heard from Rob
sooner, and we look forward to seeing him get a lot more action on the
decks!

> >> >Today, February 15th,  is the anniversary of Geri Dahl Last Post To
> >> >SFR and let us all take a moment to contemplate what in the hell she
> >> >was ever talking about.
> >> >
> >> >Where she came from, nobody knows, (though a friend claims to have
> >> >hung out with her), and where she has gone, nobody knows either.
> >> >
> >> >Some say she's in Vegas, hanging with Mr. Cooper, Elvis, and 900 foot
> >> >Jesus.
> >> >
> >> >Some say she sits in Karl Rove's ear and tells him what to do, which
> >> >would explain a lot, nicht wahr?
> >> >
> >> >Some say she never existed in the first place and is just the mass,
> >> >collective hallucination of SFR.
> >> >
> >> >Some say that she's the Head Writer of the Cartoon Network, which,
> >> >given the preponderence of the evidence, is the most credible theory
> >> >out there.
> >> >
> >> >Some say she was the one that guided that missile into The Pentagon.
> >> >
> >> >Some say that none of this is true.
> >> >
> >> >Some say all of this is true.
> >> >
> >> >Whatever the case may be, one shining truth stands out, like Reagan's
> >> >shining city on a hill, if Geri Dahl did not exist, it would be
> >> >necessary to invent her.
> >> >
> >> >Don't know about you, but since I haven't heard hide nor hair of her,
> >> >in a dog's age, I'm a gonna go light a candle, pour out a 40 on the
> >> >curb, and debate her place in the Pantheon of the Events of this Day:
> >> >http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/February_15#Events
> >> >
> >> >I'd also like to move that from This Day Forward February 15th Shall
> >> >Be Forever Known As "Geri Dahl Day."
> >> >
> >> >Discuss amonngst yourselves.
> >> >
> >> >Xin Nian Hao!
> >> >
> >> >~nyc
> >> >

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Random Acts of Kindness Week

--0-1331953668-1171584935=:5031
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

 
   
          Random Acts of Kindness Week    By David Price
Mon, February 12, 2007, 12:01 am PST
                    
    (Photo by lifeisajourney)"No act of kindness, however small, is ever wasted." - Aesop

On the drive to work today, traffic was bumper to bumper, the brake lights were playing a sick Morse code with my brain, and coffee had dripped from the cheap paper cup onto my clean white shirt. And I waved to everyone. I was getting into the swing of things for Random Acts of Kindness Week. Yes, it's more than a slogan on a bumper sticker. It doesn't really matter what you do; kindness comes in all shapes and sizes. Maybe you can help an old lady cross the street, bring in your neighbor's trash cans, or help a stranger change a tire. If you have trouble thinking of something, here's a list that may spark some kind ideas. Leave a calling card, or just let it be a mystery. However you spread kindness this week, have fun and smile.

Suggested Sites...     
   The Random Acts of Kindness Foundation - inspiring people to practice kindness.   
   Free Hugs Campaign - sometimes even a hug is enough.   
   Extreme Kindness - join the kindness crew.   
   Staged Kindness - make believe the world is a happier place until it really is.   
   Purple Acts of Kindness - even here at the corporate mothership, we like to do acts of kindness. 


http://dir.yahoo.com/thespark/6457/random-acts-of-kindness-week
 
---------------------------------
Expecting? Get great news right away with email Auto-Check.
Try the Yahoo! Mail Beta.
--0-1331953668-1171584935=:5031--

ooh, there was some guy that got my email address when i was in that  
late night coalition thing and he kept spamming the hell out of me  
with his stupid club mail that i didn't want, well one time he made  
the mistake of doing a cc: instead of a bcc: and i couldn't resist  
doing a reply all with some really rank comments, well probably  
normal stuff if you live in north carolina or something, but you know  
just stupid stuff, then he replied to me actually, took the time to  
reply, and threatened me with all this crap like he knows all these  
people and i should heed warning and all this crap.  i never heard  
from him again.  fortunately i completely forgot the guy's name.  i  
say fortunately for me because that's just useless information i  
don't need in my life.  ju know?


On Feb 14, 2007, at 2:44 PM, Eric Spire wrote:

> After DJ Seven wouldn't take me off his mailing list,
> I routinely hunted his ISP down and had his accounts
> turned off. This didn't seem to curb his love for
> spam.
>
> So, I then tracked down his home phone, fax, and cell.
> For months, I set my computer up to ring the three
> numbers in succession, randomly at night, early am,
> and sometimes just in the middle of the day.
>
> I don't receive his emails anymore.

>>> forgotten to make. I found the number and dialed
>> it. A man
>>> answered, saying "Hello." I politely said, "This is
>> Chris. Could I
>>> please speak with Robyn Carter?"
>>>
>>> Suddenly a manic voice yelled out in my ear "Get
>> the right f***ing number!"
>>> and the phone was slammed down on me. I couldn't
>> believe that anyone could be
>>> so rude. When I tracked down Robyn's correct number
>> to call her, I found
>>> that I had accidentally transposed the last two
>> digits.
>>>
>>> After hanging up with her, I decided to call the
>> 'wrong' number
>>> again.
>>>
>>> When the same guy answered the phone, I yelled,
>> "You're an
>>> asshole!" and hung up. I wrote his number down with
>> the word
>>> 'asshole' next to it and put it in my desk drawer.
>>>
>>> Every couple of weeks, when I was paying bills or
>> had a really bad day, I'd
>>> call him up and yell, "You're an asshole!"
>>>
>>> It always cheered me up.
>>>
>>> When Caller ID was introduced, I thought my
>> therapeutic 'asshole' calling
>>> would have to stop. So, I called his number and
>> said, "Hi, this is John Smith
>>> from the telephone company.
>>> I'm calling to see if you're familiar with our
>> Caller ID Program?"
>>>
>>> He yelled "NO!" and slammed down the phone. I
>> quickly called him back and
>>> said, "That's because you're an asshole!" and hung
>> up.
>>>
>>>
>>> One day I was at the store, getting ready to pull
>> into a parking
>>> Spot. Some guy in a black BMW cut me off and pulled
>> into the spot I had
>>> patiently waited for. I hit the horn and yelled
>> that I'd
>>> been waiting for that spot, but the idiot ignored
>> me. I noticed a
>>> "For Sale" sign in his back window, so I wrote down
>> his number.
>>>
>>> A couple of days later, right after calling the
>> first asshole (I
>>> had his number on speed dial,) I thought that I'd
>> better call the
>>> BMW asshole, too.
>>>
>>> I said, "Is this the man with the black BMW for
>> sale?"
>>>
>>> He said, "Yes, it is." I asked, "Can you tell me
>> where I can see
>>> it?"
>>>
>>> He said, "Yes, I live at 34 Oaktree Blvd, in
>> Fairfax. It's a
>>> yellow rambler, and the car's parked right out in
>> front."
>>>
>>> I asked, "What's your name?" He said, "My name is
>> Don Hansen,"
>>>
>>> I asked, "When's a good time to catch you, Don?"
>>>
>>> He said, "I'm home every evening after five."
>>>
>>> I said, "Listen, Don, can I tell you something?"
>>>
>>> He said, "Yes?"
>>>
>>> I said, "Don, you're an asshole!"
>>>
>>> Then I hung up, and added his number to my speed
>> dial, too.
>>>
>>> Now, when I had a problem, I had two assholes to
>> call.
>>>
>>> Then I came up with an i dea. I called asshole #1.
>>>
>>> He said, "Hello."
>>>
>>> I said, "You're an asshole!" (But I didn't hang
>> up.)
>>>
>>> He asked, "Are you still there?"
>>>
>>> I said, "Yeah,"
>>>
>>> He screamed, "Stop calling me,"
>>>
>>> I said, "Make me,"
>>>
>>> He asked, "Who are you?"
>>>
>>> I said, "My name is Don Hansen."
>>>
>>> He said, "Yeah? Where do you live?"
>>>
>>> I said, "Asshole, I live at 34 Oaktree Blvd, in
>> Fairfax, a
>>> yellow rambler, I have a black Beamer parked in
>> front."
>>>
>>> He said, "I'm coming over right now, Don. And you
>> had better start saying
>>> your prayers."
>>>
>>> I said, "Yeah, like I'm really scared, asshole,"
>> and hung up.
>>>
>>> Then I called Asshole #2.
>>>
>>> He said, "Hello?"
>>>
>>> I said, "Hello, asshole,"
>>>
>>> He yelled, "If I ever find out who you are..."
>>>
>>> I said, "You'll what?"
>>>
>>> He exclaimed, "I'll kick your ass,"
>>>
>>> I answered, "Well, asshole, here's your chance. I'm
>> coming over right now".
>>>
>>> Then I hung up and immediately called the police,
>> saying that I
>>> lived at 34 Oaktree Blvd, in Fairfax, and that I
>> was on my way
>>> over there to kill my gay lover.
>>>
>>> Then I called Channel 9 News about the gang war
>> going down in
>>> Oaktree Blvd. in Fairfax.
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> I quickly got into my car and headed over to
>> Fairfax. I got
>>> there just in time to watch two assholes beating
>> the crap out of each other
>>> in front of six cop cars, an overhead news
>> helicopter and surrounded by a
>>> news crew.
>>>
>>> NOW I feel much better.
>>>
>>> Anger management really does work!
>>
>>
>> Nyc Alberts wrote:
>> You are my guitar hero of the day!
>>
>> Like your email alias, judging by this post of
>> yours, it probably fits
>> you IRL as well..

>> We should join forces, I get a kick doing stuff like

>> always more fun if you have a like minded partner to

>> I usually work off the phone with inbound calls from
>> telemarketers,
>> here's a brief description of what I do that I
>> posted elsewhere about a
>> week ago:
>>
>> ~~~
>>
>> I love making phone calls like this.
>>
>> The week President Nixon died my desk partner and I
>> played merry hell
>> out with every building that didn't fly their flags
>> at half mast in San
>> Francisco's Financial District, most notably the
>> Pacific Stock Exchange.
>>
>> They didn't see that one coming.
>>
>> Also, what's really fun for me is messing with
>> telemarketers, I can keep
>> them on the phone for hours until they realize that
>> I'm just fucking
>> with them.
>>
>> Sometimes I pretend that I've got Down's Syndrome,
>> and if it's a woman I
>> immediately ask her what she's wearing and move the
>> conversation in that
>> direction.
>>
>> I once got this one girl in New Delhi so upset, (the
>> call immediately
>> devolved into a "what are you wearing" from me and
>> went downhill from
>> there for 15 minutes), she called me back on her own
>> cell phone just to
>> cuss me out, never mind what she must have had to
>> pay to get some
>> satisfaction out of me.
>>
>> heheheh.
>>
>> I've been faulted for doing this, but it beats
>> screaming "Do Not Call!!"
>> at them and gets better results, they tend to never
>> call back after
>> dealing with me on the phone.
>>
>> I should record this bit and put out a CD.
>>
>> The diff is I don't make the calls, they call me,
>> which gives me mad
>> license to go to town.
>>
>> A phone is a WMD in my hands and I don't know why
>> more people don't do
>> this, it's fun to turn tables, y'know.
>>
>> I once bumped into NYT Select*, (bitches), columnist
>> Paul Krugman* on
>> the corner of 17th and K Street, NW, as we were both
>> leaving Farragut
>> Park one day, and I asked him to relay the following
>> story of one of
>> these calls of mine to his colleague, Mr. Tom "The
>> World Is Flat"
>> Friedman, since what I'm about to tell you is his
>> bailiwick more than
>> Krugman's.
>>
>> I pretended to have LaTourette's Syndrome on this
>> one call that came in
>> and abused, (believe it or don't, she never once
>> lost her cool and was
>> polite throughout), this one female telemarketer,
>> (who was selling a
>> *local* landscaping firm's services), for about a
>> half hour until *I*
>> the one that was spent, and then I dropped it and
>> started talking with her.
>>
>> Turns out she was 23, was calling from Romania, had
>> just graduated
>> college, spoke 5 languages, and here's the punch
>> line....
>>
>> Was being paid $200USD a month to put up with my
>> shit on the phone.
>>
>> Make a decision, if you're a businessman, who would
>> you hire?
>>
>> A surly US GED holder that you pay $1,200.00 a month
>> that's going to
>> drive away your customers, or her?
>>
>> And yet you people still hold on to the quaint
>> notion that America isn't
>> doomed by its own shit and ain't gonna have its
>> lunch eaten by the
>> Second World.
>>
>> ~nyc

>> http://welcome-to-pottersville.blogspot.com/

I'd Rather Be A Matin' Than A Hatin' ~ Me

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

"No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path  
toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and  
enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras,  
sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and  
Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can  
find in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and  
economic regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond  
what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative  
pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and work in  
squalor."
-Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of  
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will  
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

>
> Anyone trying to detect anything now is a complete fucking idiot.  The 
> place wasn't nuked FFS.
>
I said that there were teams of self-styled Lone Gunmen types there *on 
the day of* within 15 minutes of the second building collapsing, and in 
the days immediately thereafter, and they didn't find anyfuckingthing, 
not a gaddamned thing, or else we'd have never have fucking heard the 
end of it, given how much noise they're making out of nothing.

job.

second that I'd give half a squirt of piss about what some conspiracy 
theorist had to say about it?

Neither do I.

End of.

I'd Rather Be A Matin' Than A Hatin' ~ Me

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

"Ha ha!  Ever had the feeling you've been cheated?" ~ J. Lydon, SF, 1978

Yup, there's that.

Why would they be allowed to live if they were truly onto something?

If I did it, and if  anyone got anywhere close to "the truth", they'd be 
a grease stain, quicker than you can say "doe-ray-mi", bitch

But that's just me.

And on a personal level, all this 9/!! shit really gets under my skin, 
especially this week, and especially today, because it just so happens 
to be the 62nd Anniversary Week of The Valentine's Day Allied 
Firebombing of Dresden, http://tinyurl.com/2zuev9 which might not mean 
jack shit to anyone else on this list, but 100+ members of my family on 
my Mother's side were melted there, and by that I mean their bodies were 
turned into a *sheet of motherfucking glass* in the conflagration of the 
British and Yank's Valentine's Day present to Adolph.

So I don't have a lot of patience for the 9/!! crowd, on either side of 
the aisle.

Also, you revisionists can fucking bite me.

Dresden, by any measure, be it property, (which seems to be the bigger 
concern here in the good old US of A), or loss of life, is a *thousand* 
times worse than what happened on 9/!!.

So I'm not just flapping my gums when I say the USA madly over-reacted 
with our national response to 9/!!, and don't even try to lump me in 
with that asshole, Ward Churchill, either, tyvm.

I've been there to Dresden and I've seen it, we totally fucked that 
place up, yo.

We made it look like New York's South Bronx in the 1970's under Mayor's 
Lindsay and Beame.

So pardon the fuck out of me if I just want the 9/!! Conspiracy Brigade 
to just up and STFU and find something else that's real that they can 
throw their energy into, like making sure we get the hell out of Iraq, 
or better yet......

Katrina.

We shut this motherfucking country down for two solid weeks after 9/!! 
but the biggest issue after Katrina, (which instead of taking out just 
25 acres of land, devasted an area the size of Great Britain),  seemed 
to be where The New Orleans Saints were a gonna play them some football 
that week.

Ugh.

Hello, is this thing on?

What's the hell is wrong with this picture?

Yeah, how about giving New Orleans and environs some of that 9/!! love, 
and money and support, because trust me the rebuilding in NYC is 
proceeding apace, once the greedhead vultures of the LMDC got their act 
together as to how they were going to divvy up the loot that fell on 
them from the clear blue sky, and, besides, New Orleans could use it a 
lot more than NYC.

Ya think?

Yeah, you got some excess energy to burn off, want to make a change for 
the better?

Habitat For Humanity in Biloxi is always looking for a few good hands to 
help out.

Why not go on down there and quit desecrating the Hallowed Ground of the 
9/!! Memorial Pit and leave the memory of those that died there to their 
family and friends?

You know, like show some respect for the dead?

It's kinda the right thing to do,ya know what I mean, Vern?

Thanks!

That'd be great!

~nyc

Shatter,

You know, I have to say that I only disagree with you on one point in =20=

this thread, and that is your comment about Peter invalidating this =20
thread with his hateful comments about Col. Ron Ray.  I think quite =20
the contrary, I think the only person he's invalidating is himself.  =20
How anyone could spend so many hours provoking straw man arguments =20
with people, and Peter, how many times do I have to tell you about =20
just throwing links as if no one's going to actually read them.  Now =20
I want everyone to read the travel advisory, I'm posting it right =20
from the link Peter was so kind enough to share with us, and tell me =20
what sane person is going to risk driving around the US Mexico border =20=

especially around Nuevo Laredo.

Don't be alarmed, SFRavErs, just if I were you I'd avoid taking any =20
road trips in most parts of Mexico right now.

Are you a paid asset of the New World Order, Peter?

--

CRIME IN BORDER CITIES: Visitors to the U.S. =96 Mexico border region, =20=

including cities such as Tijuana, Ciudad Juarez, Nuevo Laredo, =20
Nogales, Reynosa and Matamoros, should remain alert and be aware of =20
their surroundings at all times.

Some border posts have seen an increase in violence over the past =20
year, some of which has been directed against U.S. citizens.  Local =20
police forces have been ineffective in maintaining security in some =20
regions along the border.  Drug-related violence has increased =20
dramatically in recent months, and shows no sign of abating.  While =20
U.S. citizens not involved in criminal activities are generally not =20
targeted, innocent bystanders are at risk from the increase in =20
violence in the streets of border cities.

In Ciudad Juarez, Nuevo Laredo and Tijuana, shootings have taken =20
place at busy intersections and at popular restaurants during =20
daylight hours.  The wave of violence has been aimed primarily at =20
members of drug trafficking organizations, criminal justice =20
officials, and journalists.  However, foreign visitors and residents, =20=

including Americans, have been among the victims of homicides and =20
kidnappings in the border region.  In recent months, the worst =20
violence has been centered in the city of Nuevo Laredo in the Mexican =20=

state of Tamaulipas, where numerous citizens were kidnapped and/or =20
murdered.  U.S. citizens are urged to be especially aware of safety =20
and security concerns when visiting the border region and exercise =20
common-sense precautions such as visiting only legitimate business =20
and tourist areas of border towns during daylight hours.

Mexican authorities have failed to prosecute numerous crimes =20
committed against American citizens, including murder and =20
kidnapping.  Local police forces suffer from a lack of funds and =20
training, and the judicial system is weak, overworked, and =20
inefficient.  Criminals, armed with an impressive array of weapons, =20
know there is little chance they will be caught and punished.  In =20
some cases, assailants have been wearing full or partial police =20
uniforms and have used vehicles that resemble police vehicles, =20
indicating some elements of the police might be involved.

Visitors are very vulnerable when visiting the local "red light =20
districts," particularly if they are departing alone in the early =20
hours of the morning.  In Ciudad Juarez and Tijuana, there has also =20
been a rise in automobile accidents in which municipal police extort =20
money from U.S. citizen victims.

Since we love links and such...

http://www.washtimes.com/national/20060117-121930-3169r.htm


Mexican military incursions reported

By Jerry Seper
THE WASHINGTON TIMES
January 17, 2006

The U.S. Border Patrol has warned agents in Arizona of incursions into the=
=20
United States by Mexican soldiers "trained to escape, evade and=20
counterambush" if detected -- a scenario Mexico denied yesterday.
     The warning to Border Patrol agents in Tucson, Ariz., comes after=20
increased sightings of what authorities described as heavily armed Mexican=
=20
military units on the U.S. side of the border. The warning asks the agents=
=20
to report the size, activity, location, time and equipment of any units=20
observed.

(follow link for rest of article.  There's quite a bit if this that goes=20
on.  I googled for Mexican Army Arizona)

Now, what bothers me about this, is that (and Deep, this is where the=20
Shatter test comes into play) if you replaced all occurances of Mexican=20
Army with U.S. Army and United States with Mexico, this article would gain=
=20
national attention, protests, Mexicans both legal and Illeagal storming the=
=20
city halls and capital builing, national protests, marches, and calls for=20
further Impeechment against Bush.

Instead, because they are on our soil (operating in a militay fashion, and=
=20
quite probably assisting the drug traffic and illeagal activity on our=20
borders) it's not a big deal and people don't have a problem with this.

http://www.ranchrescue.com/

Now while this won't be considered a reputable news source (and I'm sure=20
somebody will find something offensive somewher eto invalidate everything=20
about the site) it does document some things I've read about over the past=
=20
few years, where the Mexican Army has moved in and openerated on U.S. Soil,=
=20
on private property and harassed our citizens.

However, they do have video evidence to back up the claims.

This is some of what I'm talking about when I say to lock down the=20
boarder.  It's not that people can't travel, however how about travel=20
through areas so we can at least monitor what's going on.

The only example I can give, is to ask if you (subjective to who's reading=
=20
this) is if you have a fence around your property?  I always have, every=20
where I've lived.  Can people come over?  Sure, they use the front=20
door.  Anyone living in the house is free to come and go as they=20
please.  Guests must enter and exit through the front door.  You do not hop=
=20
the fence.  You come over at what is deemed appropriate times (4am is not=20
appropriate unless invited).

If there is a breakin, the solution isn't to remove the fences, as well at=
=20
the front and back door, and leave the windows open.  Quite the=20
opposite.  Find out how the break in happened, take steps to make sure it=20
doesn't happen again.  Perhaps better locks on the doors, better door=20
jams.  Maybe a taller fence or a top barrier to discourage hopping over=20
it.  An Alarm system?  Maybe.  In a bad neighborhood bars may be required=20
on windows, as well as a security gate for the doors leading into the house.

Do any of the security measure take away form teh freedom and quality of=20
life of those that live there?  Possible, if they go too far.  However,=20
minimal steps taken shoudn't interfere with your day to day=20
life.  Personally, I don't have problems with fences, that are on teh=20
property line.  It's orderly, and makes things very cut and dry with your=20
neighbors.  This is mine, that is yours.

> they please.  Guests must enter and exit through the front door.  You
> do not hop the fence.  You come over at what is deemed appropriate
> times (4am is not appropriate unless invited).
>
> If there is a breakin, the solution isn't to remove the fences, as well
> at the front and back door, and leave the windows open.  Quite the
> opposite.  Find out how the break in happened, take steps to make sure
> it doesn't happen again.  Perhaps better locks on the doors, better
> door jams.  Maybe a taller fence or a top barrier to discourage hopping
> over it.  An Alarm system?  Maybe.  In a bad neighborhood bars may be
> required on windows, as well as a security gate for the doors leading
> into the house.
>
> Do any of the security measure take away form teh freedom and quality
> of life of those that live there?  Possible, if they go too far.
> However, minimal steps taken shoudn't interfere with your day to day
> life.  Personally, I don't have problems with fences, that are on teh
> property line.  It's orderly, and makes things very cut and dry with
> your neighbors.  This is mine, that is yours.
>

>> CRIME IN BORDER CITIES: Visitors to the U.S. =AD Mexico border region,
>> including cities such as Tijuana, Ciudad Juarez, Nuevo Laredo,
>> Nogales, Reynosa and Matamoros, should remain alert and be aware of
>> their surroundings at all times.
>>
>> Some border posts have seen an increase in violence over the past
>> year, some of which has been directed against U.S. citizens.  Local
>> police forces have been ineffective in maintaining security in some
>> regions along the border.  Drug-related violence has increased
>> dramatically in recent months, and shows no sign of abating.  While
>> U.S. citizens not involved in criminal activities are generally not
>> targeted, innocent bystanders are at risk from the increase in
>> violence in the streets of border cities.
>>
>> In Ciudad Juarez, Nuevo Laredo and Tijuana, shootings have taken
>> place at busy intersections and at popular restaurants during
>> daylight hours.  The wave of violence has been aimed primarily at
>> members of drug trafficking organizations, criminal justice
>> officials, and journalists.  However, foreign visitors and residents,
>> including Americans, have been among the victims of homicides and
>> kidnappings in the border region.  In recent months, the worst
>> violence has been centered in the city of Nuevo Laredo in the Mexican
>> state of Tamaulipas, where numerous citizens were kidnapped and/or
>> murdered.  U.S. citizens are urged to be especially aware of safety
>> and security concerns when visiting the border region and exercise
>> common-sense precautions such as visiting only legitimate business
>> and tourist areas of border towns during daylight hours.
>>
>> Mexican authorities have failed to prosecute numerous crimes
>> committed against American citizens, including murder and
>> kidnapping.  Local police forces suffer from a lack of funds and
>> training, and the judicial system is weak, overworked, and
>> inefficient.  Criminals, armed with an impressive array of weapons,
>> know there is little chance they will be caught and punished.  In
>> some cases, assailants have been wearing full or partial police
>> uniforms and have used vehicles that resemble police vehicles,
>> indicating some elements of the police might be involved.
>>
>> Visitors are very vulnerable when visiting the local "red light
>> districts," particularly if they are departing alone in the early
>> hours of the morning.  In Ciudad Juarez and Tijuana, there has also
>> been a rise in automobile accidents in which municipal police extort
>> money from U.S. citizen victims.
>>
>>

Subject: [sfraves] custom DJ console

after much fruitless searching for a decent DJ console - not a skeezy  
carpet-covered coffin, but REAL furniture - I decided to make my own.  
I've done some furniture design/construction in the past, and I  
thought it was time to get back into it, since there's no way we can  
afford the kind of furniture we want in our new house.

I've been documenting the project, taking photos along the way:
   http://www.flickr.com/photos/44124395037@N01/sets/72157594504962030/

It should be stained and finished by the end of this weekend.

I thought I'd put the word out in case anyone here is looking for  
some custom-made DJ furniture. Send me a private message if you're  
interested.  I already have a couple people who have asked me to  
design/construct custom DJ consoles for them after seeing this one in  
progress.

-philip-

-----Original Message-----
From: Philip.X.Diaz [mailto:st_indigo@earthlink.net] 
Sent: Friday, February 16, 2007 12:43 PM
To: The Twilight Laser Outpost
Subject: [sfraves] custom DJ console

after much fruitless searching for a decent DJ console - not a skeezy  
carpet-covered coffin, but REAL furniture - I decided to make my own.  
I've done some furniture design/construction in the past, and I  
thought it was time to get back into it, since there's no way we can  
afford the kind of furniture we want in our new house.

I've been documenting the project, taking photos along the way:
   http://www.flickr.com/photos/44124395037@N01/sets/72157594504962030/

It should be stained and finished by the end of this weekend.

I thought I'd put the word out in case anyone here is looking for  
some custom-made DJ furniture. Send me a private message if you're  
interested.  I already have a couple people who have asked me to  
design/construct custom DJ consoles for them after seeing this one in  
progress.

-philip-

On Feb 16, 2007, at 1:31 PM, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

> And what about the condom dispenser?  That should be right under  
> the mixer.

if i make one for brandon, it will have a condom dispenser for sure -  
and a lube pump.


> Seriously though it looks pretty sweet.  What is the record  
> capacity underneath?

thanks!  there are speakers inside behind the grill cloth, but the  
top flips up to expose a smallish storage area, lots of room for CDs  
- this was designed for CDJs only, so there is NO record storage  
capacity.

and for drinks (yes, i actually did consider this), there's enough  
flat space above the mixer to set your drink.

-philip-

MIGHTY BREAKS

This Friday, February 16th - Plaza de Funk!!!!

for a taste of what plaza sounds like:

The longest running breaks monthly in San Francisco gets ready to host the 
Cowboys and their arch rivals SEISMIC, to celebrate a new year of Mighty 
monthlies and a first-time SF appearance by breaks newcomer PLAZA de FUNK 
(West Records, FAT!, UK). profile.myspace.com/plazadefunk You've heard the 
Drum Monkey remix dropped by several DJs at BOC, and our new Italian friend 
is ready to rock the party he has heard so much about with two of SFs 
"infamous" crews.

Featuring Cowboy DJs:
8ball
The Geometrist
Mancub
Evinrude

And from SEISMIC:
Murphstar
Trav
Samira
Brett Pinkin

And newly added to the lineup - THE MARIO BROS! (Marc(O) & daniella downs)


Friday, February 16, 2007
10:00 PM  4:00 AM
Mighty, 199 Utah, SF, CA

At 12:42 PM 2/16/2007, Philip.X.Diaz wrote:
>after much fruitless searching for a decent DJ console - not a skeezy
>carpet-covered coffin, but REAL furniture - I decided to make my own.
>I've done some furniture design/construction in the past, and I
>thought it was time to get back into it, since there's no way we can
>afford the kind of furniture we want in our new house.
>
>I've been documenting the project, taking photos along the way:

MIME-Version: 1.0

	format=flowed;
	charset="iso-8859-1";

X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2900.3028
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2900.3028
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 17 Feb 2007 04:27:59.0049 (UTC) FILETIME=[00F66B90:01C7524C]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: More tech geekery - future computing

if you read about the new intel processor architecture, you'll realize that 
the specific claim you state, that "the future won't be these multi core 
chips" with the reason "we're already seeing diminishing returns on them" 
don't jive since the question of how to get cores to swap information 
faster, is the area of development, that hasn't had much development outside 
of the 2-core range.  because of this the 4-core variants available to day 
from intel only get a 2.5 increase in computation power over the single-core 
(those are their numbers - from their website); this new multi-core 
low-power architecture is intels ploy to change all that.

what the new "farm" array of cores, along with the as-yet-fully-developed 
on-chip "network" get you is a miniparadigm of today's high-performance 
computer clusters: a bunch of processing units and a network for them to be 
managed and share their information with each other.

that being said, i don't think anybody is claiming this architecture to be 
"the future of computing" so stating so is a rather dubious feather in your 
cap ;)

but from a shear numbers-crunching standpoint, this area of development is 
what will make computationally-intense processing as affordable as the 
integer processing we have today.  it is technology like this that will cut 
the lifespan of our beloved 1024-bit cypher suites exponentially shorter 
than designed.

as for your postulating that all processing will be modularized with 
separate complete subsystems to take the main processing off the 
central-processor model, i cannot agree at all.  that is what happens today, 
and has always happened, and will likely continue in the future; where 
performing some process-intense task takes an undue amount of effort within 
a central-processor-modelled  computer, a subsystem to address the specific 
need is enlisted.  this was typical in the first computers since they lacked 
the cpu power to perform even basic ancilliary tasks themselves.

One of the first offload components to die off were the modem.  Does anyone 
remember the Mac AV models with a built in DSPs that could be used to power 
stuff like the Apple GeoModem, which had inside of it only the phone-line 
interface components and instead relied on the DSP to do the work D2A and 
A2D for the modem ? When the PPC 604 came out, it had enough power to do the 
job of the DSP and they ditched the DSP in the AV models and included 
software-only solution in the 8600AV.  a need was original met with a system 
external to the cpu and when the cpu became capable, the external system was 
removed.

It is nothing new and continues to this day in every piece of electronic 
equipment made from ASIC codecs in cell phones and mp3 players to usb video 
and audio capture equipment.   All but the absolute cheapest network card 
today contains a TCP/IP checksum offload engine and high-end ones designed 
for iSCSI server applications (especially popular in blades to reduce the 
need for an expensive full Fibrechannel fabric) use a complete tcp/ip 
offload engine (TOE) card that performs the task in ASIC hardware (not the 
barnyard-built complete linux-computer-controlled subsystem like the 
gamer-targetted "KillerNIC").

Where tasks tax the cpu too much to make the user experience satisfactory, a 
solution will be found to offload that task, whether an ASIC, co-processor, 
or a completely separate subsystem, in an effort to maintain 
user-experience, whatever that is.  it's not driven by "coolness" but by 
profit margins as they relate to the laws of supply and demand in a 
capitalistic economic system.

-=dave

computers are g r a t e !

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Shatter" <shatter@sonic.net>
To: <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, February 14, 2007 4:16 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: More tech geekery


>
> Smart sources are speculating (and I'm in total agreement) that the future 
> won't be these multi core chips.  We're already seeing diminishing returns 
> on them.  Quad will be the end for a bit while they push them harder and 
> faster, and then we'll see a break toward distributed processing systems 
> of varying bit size.  A return to 16bit, 24 bit etc that we're already 
> seeing, but at a much larger level.
>
> Already we have GPU's, and NPU's are stating to emerge.  If you geeks 
> havn't looked at KillerNIC do look at it.  I'm really thinking of going 
> that route.  There's also the Physics sub processor that's on many 
> motherboards now, that's increasing game performance by unloading all 
> physics calculations to a dedicated processor.  Befor ethe days of the 
> Floating point processing will remember when all system had a math 
> co-processor to operate.
>
> Essentially instead of a standard NIC you have a NPU card running a 400MHz 
> chip with it's own ram and non volitale storage.  It's running Linus and 
> acts as it's own sub computer handling all network traffic.  Your computer 
> simply send data and the NIC does the rest.  All TCP/IP functions happen 
> on the card, freeing up you CPU to do other things.  You can also have on 
> card Firewall, Applications (Teamspeak, Vent, etc) all running on card, 
> and not on computer.
>
> Control is done from a simple terminal, like you would with any *nix 
> system.
>
> Consider other aspect that could be done via a distributed system and you 
> can see where this can go.  We already have sound moving off the main bus 
> and onto dedicated sub processing systems.  Music peopel have been doing 
> thsi for years to some extent, but now it's becoming defacto.
>
> Essentially, in another 5-8 years we shoudl start seeing what amounts to a 
> distributed cluster into the box.
>
> Then of course, many years after that they'll being it all back into the 
> next interation of super chip, most likely something in the Quantum realm, 
> or photonics.
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: More tech geekery - future computing
