-----Original Message-----

From:  "SE/30" <grindingbassline@hotmail.com>
Subj:  Re: [sfraves] NRR: More tech geekery - future computing
Date:  Fri Feb 16, 2007 8:28 pm
Size:  4K
To:  <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

if you read about the new intel processor architecture, you'll realize that 
the specific claim you state, that "the future won't be these multi core 
chips" with the reason "we're already seeing diminishing returns on them" 
don't jive since the question of how to get cores to swap information 
faster, is the area of development, that hasn't had much development outside 
of the 2-core range.  because of this the 4-core variants available to day 
from intel only get a 2.5 increase in computation power over the single-core 
(those are their numbers - from their website); this new multi-core 
low-power architecture is intels ploy to change all that.

what the new "farm" array of cores, along with the as-yet-fully-developed 
on-chip "network" get you is a miniparadigm of today's high-performance 
computer clusters: a bunch of processing units and a network for them to be 
managed and share their information with each other.

that being said, i don't think anybody is claiming this architecture to be 
"the future of computing" so stating so is a rather dubious feather in your 
cap ;)

but from a shear numbers-crunching standpoint, this area of development is 
what will make computationally-intense processing as affordable as the 
integer processing we have today.  it is technology like this that will cut 
the lifespan of our beloved 1024-bit cypher suites exponentially shorter 
than designed.

as for your postulating that all processing will be modularized with 
separate complete subsystems to take the main processing off the 
central-processor model, i cannot agree at all.  that is what happens today, 
and has always happened, and will likely continue in the future; where 
performing some process-intense task takes an undue amount of effort within 
a central-processor-modelled  computer, a subsystem to address the specific 
need is enlisted.  this was typical in the first computers since they lacked 
the cpu power to perform even basic ancilliary tasks themselves.

One of the first offload components to die off were the modem.  Does anyone 
remember the Mac AV models with a built in DSPs that could be used to power 
stuff like the Apple GeoModem, which had inside of it only the phone-line 
interface components and instead relied on the DSP to do the work D2A and 
A2D for the modem ? When the PPC 604 came out, it had enough power to do the 
job of the DSP and they ditched the DSP in the AV models and included 
software-only solution in the 8600AV.  a need was original met with a system 
external to the cpu and when the cpu became capable, the external system was 
removed.

It is nothing new and continues to this day in every piece of electronic 
equipment made from ASIC codecs in cell phones and mp3 players to usb video 
and audio capture equipment.   All but the absolute cheapest network card 
today contains a TCP/IP checksum offload engine and high-end ones designed 
for iSCSI server applications (especially popular in blades to reduce the 
need for an expensive full Fibrechannel fabric) use a complete tcp/ip 
offload engine (TOE) card that performs the task in ASIC hardware (not the 
barnyard-built complete linux-computer-controlled subsystem like the 
gamer-targetted "KillerNIC").

Where tasks tax the cpu too much to make the user experience satisfactory, a 
solution will be found to offload that task, whether an ASIC, co-processor, 
or a completely separate subsystem, in an effort to maintain 
user-experience, whatever that is.  it's not driven by "coolness" but by 
profit margins as they relate to the laws of supply and demand in a 
capitalistic economic system.

-=dave

computers are g r a t e !

----- Original Message -----

>
> Smart sources are speculating (and I'm in total agreement) that the future 
> won't be these multi core chips.  We're already seeing diminishing returns 
> on them.  Quad will be the end for a bit while they push them harder and 
> faster, and then we'll see a break toward distributed processing systems 
> of varying bit size.  A return to 16bit, 24 bit etc that we're already 
> seeing, but at a much larger level.
>
> Already we have GPU's, and NPU's are stating to emerge.  If you geeks 
> havn't looked at KillerNIC do look at it.  I'm really thinking of going 
> that route.  There's also the Physics sub processor that's on many 
> motherboards now, that's increasing game performance by unloading all 
> physics calculations to a dedicated processor.  Befor ethe days of the

> 
> >
> > Smart sources are speculating (and I'm in total agreement) that the
> future
> > won't be these multi core chips.  We're already seeing diminishing
> returns
> > on them.  Quad will be the end for a bit while they push them harder and
> > faster, and then we'll see a break toward distributed processing systems
> > of varying bit size.  A return to 16bit, 24 bit etc that we're already
> > seeing, but at a much larger level.
> >
> > Already we have GPU's, and NPU's are stating to emerge.  If you geeks
> > havn't looked at KillerNIC do look at it.  I'm really thinking of going
> > that route.  There's also the Physics sub processor that's on many
> > motherboards now, that's increasing game performance by unloading all
> > physics calculations to a dedicated processor.  Befor ethe days of the
> > Floating point processing will remember when all system had a math
> > co-processor to operate.
> >
> > Essentially instead of a standard NIC you have a NPU card running a
> 400MHz
> > chip with it's own ram and non volitale storage.  It's running Linus and
> > acts as it's own sub computer handling all network traffic.  Your
> computer
> > simply send data and the NIC does the rest.  All TCP/IP functions happen
> > on the card, freeing up you CPU to do other things.  You can also have
> on
> > card Firewall, Applications (Teamspeak, Vent, etc) all running on card,
> > and not on computer.
> >
> > Control is done from a simple terminal, like you would with any *nix
> > system.
> >
> > Consider other aspect that could be done via a distributed system and
> you
> > can see where this can go.  We already have sound moving off the main
> bus
> > and onto dedicated sub processing systems.  Music peopel have been doing
> > thsi for years to some extent, but now it's becoming defacto.
> >
> > Essentially, in another 5-8 years we shoudl start seeing what amounts to
> a
> > distributed cluster into the box.
> >
> > Then of course, many years after that they'll being it all back into the
> > next interation of super chip, most likely something in the Quantum
> realm,
> > or photonics.

MAKERS! CRAFTERS! SCIENTISTS! ARTISTS! ENGINEERS!

Come one, Come all to The TechShop in Menlo Park on February 24th!
Make Magazine is hosting an audition for Maker Faire 2007 and every  
free-thinking, out of the box, DIY experimenter is welcome to attend  
and present projects, display performances and demonstrate, operate,  
create anything you want!

TechShop
http://www.techshop.ws
120 Independence Drive
Menlo Park, Ca 94025

We are doing auditions to make it easy for makers to show us their  
work. Make and Craft editors Dale Dougherty, David Pescovitz and  
Natalie Zee Drieu will be there.

You can think of these auditions as more like Dorkbot meetings.  
Anyone is welcome to come watch. We ask Makers to go up in front of  
the audience and present their project in under 10 minutes. This will  
be a fun, friendly and supportive event.

If you are planning to come audition, please contact Natalie at  
natalie@oreilly.com. Come show us what you love to make.

For more information please check out http://www.makerfaire.com

Maker Faire 2007:

Organized by the staff of Make and Craft magazines, Maker Faire is a  
newfangled fair that brings together science, art, craft and  
engineering in a fun, energized, and exciting public forum. The aim  
is to inspire people of all ages to roll up their sleeves and become  
makers. This family-friendly event showcases the amazing work of all  
kinds of makers--anyone who is embracing DIY and wants to share their  
accomplishments with an appreciative audience. Last year, we had  
20,000 people at Maker Faire.

Maker Faire Bay Area will take place May 19-20, 2007 at the San Mateo  
Fairgrounds. We are also adding Maker Faire Austin for October 20 &  
21, 2007 at the Travis County Fairgrounds. This call is primarily for  
Maker Faire Bay Area but you can indicate if you are interested in  
participating in Maker Faire Austin.

We encourage you to join the fun and propose a maker exhibit,  
performance or workshop. http://www.makerfaire.com

Natalie Villalobos
Community Manager
Maker Media Inc.
707.827.7067




--Apple-Mail-53-171007871--

Message-Id: <6.1.2.0.2.20070217184036.02c9eec0@pop.sonic.net>

 <6.1.2.0.2.20070214040753.04ddfa48@pop.sonic.net>
 <BAY124-DAV52BFD02710C753238BFBED4940@phx.gbl>
 <003101c752d4$40be34a0$6401a8c0@apo>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: More tech geekery - future computing


Check your keyboard

http://www.beastlair.com/postcards/images/other/anykey.jpg

At 12:43 PM 2/17/2007, Andrew Phelan wrote:
>hey dave how do I find the any key?
>
>A
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: SE/30 [mailto:grindingbassline@hotmail.com]
> > Sent: Wednesday, February 14, 2007 8:21 AM
> > To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> > Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: More tech geekery - future computing
> >
> > if you read about the new intel processor architecture, you'll realize
> > that
> > the specific claim you state, that "the future won't be these multi core
> > chips" with the reason "we're already seeing diminishing returns on them"
> > don't jive since the question of how to get cores to swap information
> > faster, is the area of development, that hasn't had much development
> > outside
> > of the 2-core range.  because of this the 4-core variants available to day
> > from intel only get a 2.5 increase in computation power over the single-
> > core
> > (those are their numbers - from their website); this new multi-core
> > low-power architecture is intels ploy to change all that.
> >
> > what the new "farm" array of cores, along with the as-yet-fully-developed
> > on-chip "network" get you is a miniparadigm of today's high-performance
> > computer clusters: a bunch of processing units and a network for them to
> > be
> > managed and share their information with each other.
> >
> > that being said, i don't think anybody is claiming this architecture to be
> > "the future of computing" so stating so is a rather dubious feather in
> > your
> > cap ;)
> >
> > but from a shear numbers-crunching standpoint, this area of development is
> > what will make computationally-intense processing as affordable as the
> > integer processing we have today.  it is technology like this that will
> > cut
> > the lifespan of our beloved 1024-bit cypher suites exponentially shorter
> > than designed.
> >
> > as for your postulating that all processing will be modularized with
> > separate complete subsystems to take the main processing off the
> > central-processor model, i cannot agree at all.  that is what happens
> > today,
> > and has always happened, and will likely continue in the future; where
> > performing some process-intense task takes an undue amount of effort
> > within
> > a central-processor-modelled  computer, a subsystem to address the
> > specific
> > need is enlisted.  this was typical in the first computers since they
> > lacked
> > the cpu power to perform even basic ancilliary tasks themselves.
> >
> > One of the first offload components to die off were the modem.  Does
> > anyone
> > remember the Mac AV models with a built in DSPs that could be used to
> > power
> > stuff like the Apple GeoModem, which had inside of it only the phone-line
> > interface components and instead relied on the DSP to do the work D2A and
> > A2D for the modem ? When the PPC 604 came out, it had enough power to do
> > the
> > job of the DSP and they ditched the DSP in the AV models and included
> > software-only solution in the 8600AV.  a need was original met with a
> > system
> > external to the cpu and when the cpu became capable, the external system
> > was
> > removed.
> >
> > It is nothing new and continues to this day in every piece of electronic
> > equipment made from ASIC codecs in cell phones and mp3 players to usb
> > video
> > and audio capture equipment.   All but the absolute cheapest network card
> > today contains a TCP/IP checksum offload engine and high-end ones designed
> > for iSCSI server applications (especially popular in blades to reduce the
> > need for an expensive full Fibrechannel fabric) use a complete tcp/ip
> > offload engine (TOE) card that performs the task in ASIC hardware (not the
> > barnyard-built complete linux-computer-controlled subsystem like the
> > gamer-targetted "KillerNIC").
> >
> > Where tasks tax the cpu too much to make the user experience satisfactory,
> > a
> > solution will be found to offload that task, whether an ASIC, co-
> > processor,
> > or a completely separate subsystem, in an effort to maintain
> > user-experience, whatever that is.  it's not driven by "coolness" but by
> > profit margins as they relate to the laws of supply and demand in a
> > capitalistic economic system.
> >
> > -=dave
> >
> > computers are g r a t e !
> >
> > ----- Original Message -----
> > From: "Shatter" <shatter@sonic.net>
> > To: <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> > Sent: Wednesday, February 14, 2007 4:16 AM
> > Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: More tech geekery
> >
> >
> > >
> > > Smart sources are speculating (and I'm in total agreement) that the
> > future
> > > won't be these multi core chips.  We're already seeing diminishing
> > returns
> > > on them.  Quad will be the end for a bit while they push them harder and
> > > faster, and then we'll see a break toward distributed processing systems
> > > of varying bit size.  A return to 16bit, 24 bit etc that we're already
> > > seeing, but at a much larger level.
> > >
> > > Already we have GPU's, and NPU's are stating to emerge.  If you geeks
> > > havn't looked at KillerNIC do look at it.  I'm really thinking of going
> > > that route.  There's also the Physics sub processor that's on many
> > > motherboards now, that's increasing game performance by unloading all
> > > physics calculations to a dedicated processor.  Befor ethe days of the
> > > Floating point processing will remember when all system had a math
> > > co-processor to operate.
> > >
> > > Essentially instead of a standard NIC you have a NPU card running a
> > 400MHz
> > > chip with it's own ram and non volitale storage.  It's running Linus and
> > > acts as it's own sub computer handling all network traffic.  Your
> > computer
> > > simply send data and the NIC does the rest.  All TCP/IP functions happen
> > > on the card, freeing up you CPU to do other things.  You can also have
> > on
> > > card Firewall, Applications (Teamspeak, Vent, etc) all running on card,
> > > and not on computer.
> > >
> > > Control is done from a simple terminal, like you would with any *nix
> > > system.
> > >
> > > Consider other aspect that could be done via a distributed system and
> > you
> > > can see where this can go.  We already have sound moving off the main
> > bus
> > > and onto dedicated sub processing systems.  Music peopel have been doing
> > > thsi for years to some extent, but now it's becoming defacto.
> > >
> > > Essentially, in another 5-8 years we shoudl start seeing what amounts to
> > a
> > > distributed cluster into the box.
> > >
> > > Then of course, many years after that they'll being it all back into the
> > > next interation of super chip, most likely something in the Quantum
> > realm,
> > > or photonics.
> > >
> > > At 12:28 AM 2/14/2007, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> > >>http://www.mercurynews.com/mld/mercurynews/news/local/states/california/
> > northern_california/16677437.htm
> > >>
> > >>Chip with 80 cores!
> > >>
> > >>Regards,
> > >>

I'd Rather Be A Matin' Than A Hatin' ~ Me

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

"Ha ha!  Ever had the feeling you've been cheated?" ~ J. Lydon, SF, 1978

...during the time that the plane coming into the Pentagon, there was
a young man who would come in and say to the Vice President, he would
come in and say "the plane is 50 miles out ... the plane is 30 miles
out," and when he got to "the plane is 10 miles out", the young man
also said to the Vice President, "do the orders still stand?"  And the
Vice President turned, and whipped his neck around and said, "of
course the orders still stand!  Have you heard anything to the
contrary?"

- Norman Mineta, Transportation Secretary, testifying for the National
Commission on the 9/11 attacks

I'd Rather Be A Matin' Than A Hatin' ~ Me

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

"Ha ha!  Ever had the feeling you've been cheated?" ~ J. Lydon, SF, 1978

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Transmission @ Blake's - Thursday!

i'm guessing that for most of you SFR folk, Blake's on Telegraph is a
place where getting down to electronic music on a weeknight is only a
sweet memory.  well, no longer.  Thursday nights have a new weekly
event with rotating genres.

this Thursday is breaks!  i'll be playing from 12-1am.  it's only $2
for you old folks.

although it's not Ascension, i have many fond memories of going to
Blake's.  i believe i first met Michael Stickman there (when he had
long hair).  bought a ticket to a Vibration party from Ryan while
standing outside.

hope to see some of you there!


Transmission@Blakes
2-22-07 Breaks
9pm-2am

21+ $2
18-21 $5
18 and under $10

Lineup:

Adam Ant 1-2
Nocturnalism / LoveAllstars

DJ Bam 12-1
Evil Breaks / Invibe.com

Luke Shedd 10:30-12
F-8 / Uberschall

Tim B 9-10:30


Blakes 2367 telegraph ave
berkeley ca 94704
510-848-0886

Save How Weird!


The How Weird Street Faire needs our help right now, and if we don't =20
act soon, we will be mourning its loss instead of freaking each other =20=

in the streets to all sorts of crazy beats, like we should be on the =20
first Sunday in May. Earlier this month, the Faire organizers were =20
denied a new permit, despite their 100% safety record. Apparently =20
10,000 happy people celebrating SF art, culture, and the great urban =20
outdoors isn't everyone in the area's cup of tea. However, lots of =20
neighbors, ravers, artists, DJs, and groovers love the annual =20
jubilee, and they are all sending letters and emails to the the =20
Department of Parking and Traffic, before the appeal hearing takes =20
place on Thursday.

Visit the How Weird site to sign the petition as well as get the =20
letter template. Send your letters in by email or fax by Tuesday, and =20=

do your part to get How Weird back out on the pavement where it =20
should be this spring! We deserve it.

Date: send in your letter by Tuesday 2/20, public hearing on Thursday =20=

2/22, Time: hearing @ 10am, Place: 1 South Van Ness Avenue, 7th =20
Floor, Cover: no cover, =EF=BF=BCMore Info. (DKD)




apollo@speakeasy.org

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo

Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm



"No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path =20
toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and =20
enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras, =20
sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and =20
Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can =20
find in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and =20
economic regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond =20
what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative =20
pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and work in =20
squalor."
-Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of =20
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will =20
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--Apple-Mail-5-444107378

	type="text/html";
	boundary=Apple-Mail-6-444107378

Day after day
Alone on a hill
The man with the foolish grin is keeping perfectly still
But nobody wants to know him
They can see that he's just a fool
And he never gives an answer but

The fool on the hill
Sees the sun going down
And the eyes in his head
See the world spinning 'round

- The Beatles

of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any

My favorite thing to do in the old days of super tweaking was for several 
of us to get completely fetish'd out in black rubber and go shopping at 
Walmart @ 3am. The staff was not even sneaky. They would be on the 
loudspeaker, telling their friends what isle the girls were in. Nobody 
could take their eyes off us. 3-4 in Fetishwear would be enough to distract 
teh entire warehouse.

That's when the other friend would be robbing them blind - snatch & grab 
like mad. Nota fet things, but loading the backpack and pockets, going to 
the car, unloading, and returning.

Ah the things you do on meth....

>I was in Wal-Mart buying a large bag of Purina for my dogs and was in line 
>to check out. A woman behind me asked if I had a dog........ Duh!
>
>
>I was feeling a bit crabby so on impulse, I told her no, I was 
>starting The Purina Diet again, although I probably shouldn't because I'd 
>ended up in the hospital last time, but that I'd lost 50 pounds before I 
>awakened in an intensive care unit with tubes coming out of most of my 
>orifices and IVs in both arms. Her eyes about bugged out of her head.
>
>I went on and on with the bogus diet story and she was totally buying it. 
>I told her that it was an easy, inexpensive diet and that the way it works 
>is to load your pockets or purse with Purina nuggets and simply eat one or 
>two every time you feel hungry. The package said the food is nutritionally 
>complete so I was going to try it again.
>
>I have to mention here that practically everyone in the line was by now 
>enthralled with my story, particularly a tall guy behind her. Horrified, 
>she asked if something in the dog food had poisoned me and was that was 
>why I ended up in the hospital.
>
>I said no.....I'd been sitting in the street licking my butt when a car 
>hit me.

I'd Rather Be A Matin' Than A Hatin' ~ Me

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

I'm reading Pat Buchanan's State of Emergency right now.  I used to =20
think he was one of those racist Republicans but I heard him being =20
interviewed on both Alex Jones and KQED's Forum, and I have backed =20
away from that point of view quite a bit.  His book contains a lot of =20
factual information about illegal immigration and he has this =20
interesting quote from an unexpected source that backs up his =20
philosophy.

I would also add my own personal opinion that this not only applies to =20
the illegal immigrants, but this might also apply to a lot of us that =20
have been pushed more and more into finding jobs rather than starting =20
businesses.  I strongly feel we need more entrepeneurs right now in =20
this country in order to survive.

--

There is nothing more dangerous than to build a society, with a large =20
segment of the people in that society, who feel that they have no =20
stake in it; who feel that they have nothing to lose.  People who have =20
a stake in their society, protect that society, but when they don't =20
have it, they unconsciously want to destroy it.

- Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.

I'm sure somebody with the drive to google or dig will corect me on this, 
but IIRC, in 1900 2% of all businesses in the United States were 
Corporations.  In 2000 98% of all businesses were corporations.

As such, 98% of the working force are employeed by corporations.  That 
doesn't leave a lot of room for ownership or personal stake in a business 
or the community it's located in.

Everyone takes shots at Walmart, and with good reason.  They're one of the 
largest conglomerates of community destorying parasites operating in teh 
country today.  They claim to help communities by creating jobs, but the 
reality is they treat their employee'd like shit, and the community like 
shit.  They low ball all the existing brick and mortor into bankruptcy, 
then slowly creep the prices back up. They flatly refuse to purchase from 
any distributor that isn't using chinese labor to create dirt cheap 
goods.  They use their market force and distribution channels to censor 
products and medicine they do't agree with.  They won't carry certain 
suthors or CD's in their stores if it's not "approved".  They proport 
capitalism and democracy while pushing an agenda that would have made any 
1960's communist block dictator cum in his pants.

ya...  I'm ranting.

> company and learn how its done.
>
> I'm currently on my seventh start up and I've founded two myself.  I
> intend to start at least one more.  Wal-mart didn't stop me.  Neither did
> other businesses that were bigger and better funded than mine.  I used my
> own money from savings and credit card debt to do it.
>
> Some members of this list own and operate record labels.  Some own
> production companies.  They are entrepreneurs. I have a good friend that
> uses his DJ skills as a mobile DJ.  He works two days a week for 9 months of
> the year and supports himself.  He's a sole proprieter.  It can be done if
> you put some effort into it.
>
> One of my great grandfathers came to America without a penny in his
> pocket.  He sold lamps on street corners and had to run whenever the police
> came by becasue he didn't have a business license.  Later he saved enough
> money to start a legal business: a delicatessen.  His son (my grandfather)
> became a pharmacist and owned and operated a pharmacy in the Bronx for 30
> years.  His sons both became doctors and scientists.  Their sons became
> entrepreneurs and businessmen.
>
> Just do it and quit complaining about Wal-mart.
>
> Peace,
>
> Peter
>
>
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Shatter <shatter@sonic.net>
> To: Deepfog <sfgroove@deepfog.com>; sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Sent: Thursday, February 22, 2007 4:58:46 AM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Thu)

>
> I'm sure somebody with the drive to google or dig will corect me on this,
> but IIRC, in 1900 2% of all businesses in the United States were
> Corporations.  In 2000 98% of all businesses were corporations.
>
> As such, 98% of the working force are employeed by corporations.  That
> doesn't leave a lot of room for ownership or personal stake in a business
> or the community it's located in.
>
> Everyone takes shots at Walmart, and with good reason.  They're one of the
> largest conglomerates of community destorying parasites operating in teh
> country today.  They claim to help communities by creating jobs, but the
> reality is they treat their employee'd like shit, and the community like
> shit.  They low ball all the existing brick and mortor into bankruptcy,
> then slowly creep the prices back up. They flatly refuse to purchase from
> any distributor that isn't using chinese labor to create dirt cheap
> goods.  They use their market force and distribution channels to censor
> products and medicine they do't agree with.  They won't carry certain
> suthors or CD's in their stores if it's not "approved".  They proport
> capitalism and democracy while pushing an agenda that would have made any
> 1960's communist block dictator cum in his pants.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Tonal - Fire Engine Red this Friday w/ Miles Maeda + Brown!

Rock It Science, Prismatic Tracks, Crush Collective, and sfhousemusic.com
present:

Tonal - Fire Engine Red

Friday, February 23rd
11 PM 'til very late

SF Location: call 888-482-9281 or 415-412-0406, or visit prismatictracks.com
or sfhousemusic.com the day of for directions 

$10 before midnight, $15 after
$5 discount for dressing in Fire Engine Red (at door person's
discretion--make some serious effort people!)
 
After the epic party experience of Electric Blue we are very excited to
bring you Tonal: Fire Engine Red!  Get ready for the next throwdown in this
series of sick new color themed parties brought to you by some of the
hottest crews in the underground house scene. We are teaming up to bring you
only the best in funky, floorshaking underground house music to keep you
grooving until the break of dawn. Tonal parties will showcase talent flown
in from out of town as well as some of your favorite local house jocks.
Strap on your dancing shoes and get ready to move it! 
 
DJ's:
 
DJ Miles Maeda (Ouvre, Aroma, Apt Entertainment)--Los Angeles/Chicago
 
Miles Maeda was one of the pioneering members of Chicago's scene in the
early '90s, putting out a slew of now legendary mixtapes that inspired many
a young aspiring dj.  Miles has since grown to be a favorite dj of many,
known for his precise mixing skills and poised presence behind the decks.
Sharing a residency at Chicago's Smartbar alongside Justin Long and DJ
Heather, travelling the world to share his  music with everyone, and
consistently putting out top notch tracks keeps Miles very busy.  We are
very excited to have him out for our 2nd Tonal party and can't wait to hear
him lay it down!  www.milesmaeda.com
 
Brown (Drop Music, Aroma, Mobile Trax)--Nottingham, UK
 
Nottingham based vocalist and producer, Brown is one of the key players in
the new UK sound which has had a huge impact on the record bags of our
favorite dj's. Featured in collaborations with Littlemen, Inland Knights, Da
Sunlounge, Andrew Phelan & Origami, and Bryan Jones, Brown has put tracks
out on many a hot label such as Drop, Mobile Trax, Aroma, Myna, Prismatic,
and many more.  Brown's debut SF appearance at Crush-o-matic last summer had
everybody grooving, and we are happy to welcome him back for Round Two for
another dj set featuring himself on live vocals.
www.myspace.com/brownrecordings
 
Andrew Phelan & Origami (Prismatic, Drop Music, So Sound)
 
One of SF's fastest growing duos in both the DJ and production realms,
Andrew and Origami put down some serious business.  The boys tore it up at
Electric Blue and will surely do so again this time.  A Chicago native, Mr.
Phelan brings the funk just how we like it with Origami backing him up on
live bass keeping the speakers booming and your bodies moving!
www.myspace.com/apo 
 
Eric Sharp (Rock It Science)
 
Founder of the Rock It Science crew, Eric Sharp has quickly built a name for
himself with his infectious energy behind the decks and the versatility to
rock any party. Eric's opening set at Electric Blue got everybody going just
right.  This time Eric will throw down a Fire Engine Red closing set,
leaving everybody begging for more and heading for the Endup.
www.myspace.com/ericsharp
 
Rob Crush (Crush Collective)
 
Buckle up San Francisco!  Rob Crush seems to be everywhere at once,
spreading the good word about some of our city's favorite parties.  What you
may not know about Rob is that he has secretly been honing his craft, mixing
records deep within the bowels of a dj research laboratory covered by a
biotechnology front.  You are going to wonder why you haven't heard from Rob
sooner, and we look forward to seeing him get a lot more action on the
decks!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Thu)

On Feb 22, 2007, at 4:58 AM, Shatter wrote:

> Everyone takes shots at Walmart, and with good reason.

> They low ball all the existing brick and mortor into bankruptcy,  
> then slowly creep the prices back up.

Actually- if you had ever read any business text about why Wal-Mart  
is so profitable while simultaneously offering low prices that are  
tough for others to beat, you would see that it is due to their  
innovation in to-store distribution.  They only accept full  
truckloads of goods to their distribution centers, and trucks full of  
all kinds of different products arrive at the same time.  Then they  
unload all the stuff, mix it up, and put the same load of mixed goods  
right back on every truck- which then goes and delivers it's load to  
a single store.  Not only greatly simplifying inventory and  
warehousing, the primary savings is... wait for it... fuel!  Not only  
does this make Wal-Mart's operating costs lower, it conserves fossil  
fuels and decreases pollution.  How does that taste in your pipe when  
you're smoking it?

> They flatly refuse to purchase from any distributor that isn't  
> using chinese labor to create dirt cheap goods.

That's absurd- I've done no formal research, but I've done a lot of  
shopping at a lot of places in my years.  And in my estimation, Wal- 
Mart is a retailer that has a *very* high percentage of "Made in USA"  
products- far above average.  They don't sell Chinese cast-iron  
cookware, they sell Lodge.  Ever bought a hobo-pie maker?  They sell  
the original, not a foreign knockoff.  Sure they've got their share  
of imported goods (the $1.35 sandals I bought in CO were a bargain,  
wherever they were made), but even in the main area you would expect  
to find them (apparel), they still have a high percentage of stuff  
that's made here.  Go in to any other big store and look at the  
"commodity" stuff- things like clothes hangers, kid's bikes, laundry  
baskets, kitchen utensils etc- and you will find the same thing- some  
things are just simply much cheaper when made overseas.  But witness  
just those couple examples I listed- where Wal-Mart has a realistic  
choice, they seem to choose the items from domestic manufacturers.

> They won't carry certain authors or CD's in their stores if it's  
> not "approved".

Are you saying that Wal-Mart doesn't have the right to choose to sell  
whatever the hell it pleases, and conversely *not* sell things it  
doesn't agree with?
If I'm a bookstore and I refuse to sell Mein Kampf, are you going to  
be upset?

--
"Jupiter accepts your offer..."
AIM:IMFDUP

dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

>The ultimate irony.  Pat Buchanan quoting Martin Luther King to promote a racist agenda of fear and hate.
> 
>Here's a sample "fact" from Mr, Buchanan's book:
> 
>1/12 illegal aliens has a criminal record.
> 
>Actually I don't contest this number.  That's 8.3% of the illegal immigrants entering our country.  Mexican criminals! Wow! How frightening!
> 
>At least until you realize that 13 million Americans had FELONY records in 2003.  That's right about 7% of the total adult population and 12% of the adult male population of the United States have felony records. (http://www.zmag.org/content/showarticle.cfm?SectionID=30&ItemID=4695)  The percentage with "criminal records", i.e. anyone jailed under a bench warrant for unpaid parking tickets, drunk and disorderly conduct, misdemeanor marijuana possession, etc., is much much higher.  How many on this list have a "criminal record" of some sort?  I bet its higher than 8.3%.
>
>And lets not forget that 11.7% of the new recruits to the U.S. Military had criminal records. (http://www.albany.edu/sourcebook/tost.html)
>
>This is how things add up in Pat Buchanan's racist arithmetic.
>
>Peace,
>
>Peter

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

Nathan Seven wrote:

> On Feb 22, 2007, at 4:58 AM, Shatter wrote:
>
>> Everyone takes shots at Walmart, and with good reason.
>
>
>> They low ball all the existing brick and mortor into bankruptcy,  
>> then slowly creep the prices back up.
>
>
> Actually- if you had ever read any business text about why Wal-Mart  
> is so profitable while simultaneously offering low prices that are  
> tough for others to beat, you would see that it is due to their  
> innovation in to-store distribution.  They only accept full  
> truckloads of goods to their distribution centers, and trucks full of  
> all kinds of different products arrive at the same time.  Then they  
> unload all the stuff, mix it up, and put the same load of mixed goods  
> right back on every truck- which then goes and delivers it's load to  
> a single store.  Not only greatly simplifying inventory and  
> warehousing, the primary savings is... wait for it... fuel!  Not only  
> does this make Wal-Mart's operating costs lower, it conserves fossil  
> fuels and decreases pollution.  How does that taste in your pipe when  
> you're smoking it?
>
>> They flatly refuse to purchase from any distributor that isn't  using 
>> chinese labor to create dirt cheap goods.
>
>
> That's absurd- I've done no formal research, but I've done a lot of  
> shopping at a lot of places in my years.  And in my estimation, Wal- 
> Mart is a retailer that has a *very* high percentage of "Made in USA"  
> products- far above average.  They don't sell Chinese cast-iron  
> cookware, they sell Lodge.  Ever bought a hobo-pie maker?  They sell  
> the original, not a foreign knockoff.  Sure they've got their share  
> of imported goods (the $1.35 sandals I bought in CO were a bargain,  
> wherever they were made), but even in the main area you would expect  
> to find them (apparel), they still have a high percentage of stuff  
> that's made here.  Go in to any other big store and look at the  
> "commodity" stuff- things like clothes hangers, kid's bikes, laundry  
> baskets, kitchen utensils etc- and you will find the same thing- some  
> things are just simply much cheaper when made overseas.  But witness  
> just those couple examples I listed- where Wal-Mart has a realistic  
> choice, they seem to choose the items from domestic manufacturers.
>
>> They won't carry certain authors or CD's in their stores if it's  not 
>> "approved".
>
>
> Are you saying that Wal-Mart doesn't have the right to choose to sell  
> whatever the hell it pleases, and conversely *not* sell things it  
> doesn't agree with?
> If I'm a bookstore and I refuse to sell Mein Kampf, are you going to  
> be upset?
>
> -- 
> "Jupiter accepts your offer..."
> AIM:IMFDUP
>
>
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>

I'd Rather Be A Matin' Than A Hatin' ~ Me

"Now, 75 years later in an abundant society where people have
laptops,cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod
along with books." ~ Harper Lee, 2006

"There aren't a lot of things in this world that one can be sure
of, but I do know this; anytime you go by a House of Worship, of any
size, and of any denomination, that's filled to its rafters with
people, you can be certain that the vast majority of those people
haven't actually taken the time out to read The Bible, or whatever
ancient, "Sacred Text" that they subscribe to, because if they had read
it, and comprehended it, then that House of Worship would be nearly
empty." ~Nyc Alberts, NYC, October, 2006

"Ha ha!  Ever had the feeling you've been cheated?" ~ J. Lydon, SF, 1978

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Thu)

Wal-Mart's main goal today, when it comes to its employees, is to 
eliminate them, because they cost too much, and it will happen for most 
of them over the course of the next decade due to advances in automated 
and robotic systems, both in the back and front-end, and wholesale the 
adoption of RFID.

And it won't just be Wal-Mart, but pretty much every business in the 
service sector that does this, if they wish to remain in business,, 
which means millions of "jobs" will evaporate overnight, with no new 
jobs to take their place.

By the time 2020 rolls around, the America you live in today will 
completely unrecognizable.

~nyc

At 08:29 AM 2/22/2007, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>You know I have to say that IMO this whole thing about Wal-mart is 
>somewhat off base.  Not that I love Wal-mart or shop there, but don't 
>blame Wal-Mart for your poor business situation unless you are in retail.
>
>If you don't want to be an employee start a business.  Or join a start up 
>company and learn how its done.
>
>I'm currently on my seventh start up and I've founded two myself.  I 
>intend to start at least one more.  Wal-mart didn't stop me.  Neither did 
>other businesses that were bigger and better funded than mine.  I used my 
>own money from savings and credit card debt to do it.
>
>Some members of this list own and operate record labels.  Some own 
>production companies.  They are entrepreneurs. I have a good friend that 
>uses his DJ skills as a mobile DJ.  He works two days a week for 9 months 
>of the year and supports himself.  He's a sole proprieter.  It can be done 
>if you put some effort into it.
>
>One of my great grandfathers came to America without a penny in his 
>pocket.  He sold lamps on street corners and had to run whenever the 
>police came by becasue he didn't have a business license.  Later he saved 
>enough money to start a legal business: a delicatessen.  His son (my 
>grandfather) became a pharmacist and owned and operated a pharmacy in the 
>Bronx for 30 years.  His sons both became doctors and scientists.  Their 
>sons became entrepreneurs and businessmen.
>
>Just do it and quit complaining about Wal-mart.
>
>Peace,
>
>Peter

You know how hard it is to find US/US made military fatigues?

Many are US material, assembled outside of US, most are all made outside of 
US.  The US/US ones last slightly longer than those made outside, but 
they're usually a better fit.

>Nathan Seven wrote:
>
>>On Feb 22, 2007, at 4:58 AM, Shatter wrote:
>>
>>>Everyone takes shots at Walmart, and with good reason.
>>
>>
>>>They low ball all the existing brick and mortor into bankruptcy,
>>>then slowly creep the prices back up.
>>
>>
>>Actually- if you had ever read any business text about why Wal-Mart
>>is so profitable while simultaneously offering low prices that are
>>tough for others to beat, you would see that it is due to their
>>innovation in to-store distribution.  They only accept full
>>truckloads of goods to their distribution centers, and trucks full of
>>all kinds of different products arrive at the same time.  Then they
>>unload all the stuff, mix it up, and put the same load of mixed goods
>>right back on every truck- which then goes and delivers it's load to
>>a single store.  Not only greatly simplifying inventory and
>>warehousing, the primary savings is... wait for it... fuel!  Not only
>>does this make Wal-Mart's operating costs lower, it conserves fossil
>>fuels and decreases pollution.  How does that taste in your pipe when
>>you're smoking it?
>>
>>>They flatly refuse to purchase from any distributor that isn't  using 
>>>chinese labor to create dirt cheap goods.
>>
>>
>>That's absurd- I've done no formal research, but I've done a lot of
>>shopping at a lot of places in my years.  And in my estimation, Wal- Mart 
>>is a retailer that has a *very* high percentage of "Made in USA"
>>products- far above average.  They don't sell Chinese cast-iron
>>cookware, they sell Lodge.  Ever bought a hobo-pie maker?  They sell
>>the original, not a foreign knockoff.  Sure they've got their share
>>of imported goods (the $1.35 sandals I bought in CO were a bargain,
>>wherever they were made), but even in the main area you would expect
>>to find them (apparel), they still have a high percentage of stuff
>>that's made here.  Go in to any other big store and look at the
>>"commodity" stuff- things like clothes hangers, kid's bikes, laundry
>>baskets, kitchen utensils etc- and you will find the same thing- some
>>things are just simply much cheaper when made overseas.  But witness
>>just those couple examples I listed- where Wal-Mart has a realistic
>>choice, they seem to choose the items from domestic manufacturers.
>>
>>>They won't carry certain authors or CD's in their stores if it's  not 
>>>"approved".
>>
>>
>>Are you saying that Wal-Mart doesn't have the right to choose to sell
>>whatever the hell it pleases, and conversely *not* sell things it
>>doesn't agree with?
>>If I'm a bookstore and I refuse to sell Mein Kampf, are you going to
>>be upset?
>>
>>--
>>"Jupiter accepts your offer..."

come out and demonstrate some cool projects that I know you're

get some publicity for Maker Faire coming in May 19th and 20th at the  
San Mateo County Fairgrounds.

On Saturday, February 24th, Make Magazine will be holding open  
auditions for Maker Faire from 10 am to 2pm at TechShop in Menlo  
Park.   We will also consider the best project for a future issue of  
Make magazine. In addition, a NY-based film crew will be on-hand to  
record this session.

audition, please contact me, Natalie Villalobos by email

I think your demographics of income are way off there shatter!  SF and Marin
county are both Democratic strongholds with larger populations of high wage
earners...   50K ain't really that much anymore....  And according to your
rule, most people I know should be republicans.... and they're definitely
not!     Cuz if this was true, SF and Marin should be republican strongholds
and places like fresno should be true blue democrat.  I think most people
underestimate the complexities of the political landscape, yes income and
education are factors, but there are several places across the country where
such general theories get turned on their head...  Why does connecticut have
a strong presence of republicans, and why is it the opposite in SF or
Boston?  Why is marin county a strong majority democrats, but orange county
the opposite despite a much larger minority population?

All of this reminded me of one of the most absurd things I've heard- This
guy was an evangelical minister from Seattle, and like a good evangelical he
preached that using birth control/condoms was against God's will. The guy
had a family of like 9 and had no intentions of stopping anytime soon, one
of the reasons he and his wife didn't practice birth control was to birth
more children  to counter the democratic voting black in seattle... to me
that just seemed insane.  What baffles me even more is how Jesus' teachings
run counter to so much of what the Republican party stands for.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Thu)

On Feb 22, 2007, at 2:46 PM, Shatter wrote:
>
> Everyone incorporates to avoid personal lawsuit.  Heaven forbid  
> that they put theor own personal integrity on the line.
>
> Much better to incorporate and havve no blame, guilt or liability  
> for your actions.
>
> "It wasn't me, it was the corporation!  Punish the corp!"

Actually- if you had ever read any business text about why Wal-Mart -  
whoa! deja-vu there! I mean- why corporations are formed, you would  
see that it has nothing to do with personal integrity.  Corporations  
provide protection against personal liability for debt and lawsuits,  
as well as tax benefits- but in the case of criminal behavior this  
corporate veil is easily pierced and people are held personally  
responsible. (See Enron)  Nothing to do with personal integrity, and  
everything to do with outrageous awards, frivolous lawsuits, and  
circumstances beyond your control.
See Tort Reform: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tort_reform

>
> What I'm finding funny on this list, is when the hell did a bunch  
> of PLUR loving ravers suddenly become a bunch of republican  
> capitalists?

I think it was when they stopped using PLUR as a naive-to-the-world  
starry-eyed statement of some kind, and instead started thinking  
about how to really achieve what it means.

Also- because I can't resist- the values you promote above-  
"liability for your actions", "personal integrity"- those are  
Republican ideals.  Democrats favor social assistance instead of  
personal responsibility.  PLUR!

"Jupiter accepts your offer..."

On Feb 22, 2007, at 5:13 PM, Nyc Alberts wrote:

> Well, if you truly believe in these Republican ideals, it does beg  
> the question as to why aren't you serving your country in uniform  
> in Iraq right now?

As a matter of fact- I am in Iraq, and in uniform as I type this.
Hoo-ahh!

> I'm sure your local military recruiter will applaud your decision  
> to take some "personal responsibility" and follow through with the  
> words that come out of your mouth and take some real action and  
> support our troops by, y'know being one.

I only jest- I would join the military only if they could guarantee  
me a position as a fighter pilot- but they can't.
And well- I have a strong distaste for authority- so I reserve my  
talents for more pleasurable ventures.

But I'm in full "support of the troops"- because I know it's not  
their fault that a few misguided assholes with some unknown agenda  
sent them over there to participate in a big sand-filled jackoff.   
But while they're forced to be there, I'll send them my old Maxim  
magazines and such, because I'm sure they're not having much fun at all.

> Otherwise, you can say what you want here, and it will carry as  
> much cred as it does.
>
> And, btw, can't help but to ask you, what was the deal with the  
> November 2006 elections?
>
> Has the entire country gone over the wiberal deep-end, or is it  
> that we just got fed-up with the lies of the Republican Party?

Don't confuse Republican ideals with the sorry state that the  
Republican Party has become.
I have as much contempt for them as anyone you could talk do-
The Republican Party has been infiltrated by the Religious Right, and  
have done nothing but increase the size, scope, and intrusiveness of  
government- totally contrary to Republican ideals.

If you're curious where I stand politically, I would call myself a  
small-L libertarian.
The Libertarian Party is a joke, too full of conspiracy wackos to be  
ever taken seriously.
The group I am most aligned with is the Republican Liberty Caucus.
We realize that as long as we remain in a partisan VS parliamentary  
system, third parties do not have a chance of making any difference  
whatsoever, and instead work within the Republican Party to advance  
those with Libertarian, and genuine Republican ideals.

You might like what you read: http://ca.rlc.org/index.php/RLCCA/SP1/ 
Principles

Main Room:
*Freq Nasty, Rennie Pilgrem with MC Chickaboo, JDS,
Will Saul, Precision Cuts
*Special Live Guests  The Teamplayers featuring
Aquasky, UK Apache, Spyda, The Ragga Twins & Ban Jyang
and Spiltloop

Room 2  Bassline Breaks:

with MC Ivory, Deep Impact with Screwface

Room 3  International Breaks:
Danny Mac, Klaus Heavyweight Hill, Simon Paul vs Sgt
Rock, Madox vs Santos, Cedric Benoit

lineup... man what a pipe dream! MAYBE ONE DAY :-)))
or I guess I gots to hitup Miami ;-)

HAVE A WONDERFUL WEEKEND!!!

Um, unless you haven't been paying attention - for SF not being anywhere 
CLOSE to the UK, which is where half these folks are from, next month alone 
we are getting:

Meat Katie & Dylan Rhymes, 30Hz, Krafty Kuts, Soul Of Man, Kraak & Smaak, 
Deekline & Wizard (or maybe just Deekline), etc.

And that's just the last 2 weekends in March. This weekend there's the 
Raindance party w/ Bassbin Twins, The Glitch Mob, Jonah Sharp vs. 
Mr.Projectile, etc.

I think our breaks scene here pretty much kicks fucking ass.

And considering it's not even summer (or even Spring) yet....that's hot as 
shit. You have no idea what yer in for this year as far as breaks, 
tech-funk, dubstep, etc. is concerned.

> Nathan Seven wrote:
>
>> On Feb 22, 2007, at 4:58 AM, Shatter wrote:
>>
>>> Everyone takes shots at Walmart, and with good reason.
>>
>>
>>> They low ball all the existing brick and mortor into bankruptcy,   
>>> then slowly creep the prices back up.
>>
>>
>> Actually- if you had ever read any business text about why Wal- 
>> Mart  is so profitable while simultaneously offering low prices  
>> that are  tough for others to beat, you would see that it is due  
>> to their  innovation in to-store distribution.  They only accept  
>> full  truckloads of goods to their distribution centers, and  
>> trucks full of  all kinds of different products arrive at the same  
>> time.  Then they  unload all the stuff, mix it up, and put the  
>> same load of mixed goods  right back on every truck- which then  
>> goes and delivers it's load to  a single store.  Not only greatly  
>> simplifying inventory and  warehousing, the primary savings is...  
>> wait for it... fuel!  Not only  does this make Wal-Mart's  
>> operating costs lower, it conserves fossil  fuels and decreases  
>> pollution.  How does that taste in your pipe when  you're smoking it?
>>
>>> They flatly refuse to purchase from any distributor that isn't   
>>> using chinese labor to create dirt cheap goods.
>>
>>
>> That's absurd- I've done no formal research, but I've done a lot  
>> of  shopping at a lot of places in my years.  And in my  
>> estimation, Wal- Mart is a retailer that has a *very* high  
>> percentage of "Made in USA"  products- far above average.  They  
>> don't sell Chinese cast-iron  cookware, they sell Lodge.  Ever  
>> bought a hobo-pie maker?  They sell  the original, not a foreign  
>> knockoff.  Sure they've got their share  of imported goods (the  
>> $1.35 sandals I bought in CO were a bargain,  wherever they were  
>> made), but even in the main area you would expect  to find them  
>> (apparel), they still have a high percentage of stuff  that's made  
>> here.  Go in to any other big store and look at the  "commodity"  
>> stuff- things like clothes hangers, kid's bikes, laundry  baskets,  
>> kitchen utensils etc- and you will find the same thing- some   
>> things are just simply much cheaper when made overseas.  But  
>> witness  just those couple examples I listed- where Wal-Mart has a  
>> realistic  choice, they seem to choose the items from domestic  
>> manufacturers.
>>
>>> They won't carry certain authors or CD's in their stores if it's   
>>> not "approved".
>>
>>
>> Are you saying that Wal-Mart doesn't have the right to choose to  
>> sell  whatever the hell it pleases, and conversely *not* sell  
>> things it  doesn't agree with?
>> If I'm a bookstore and I refuse to sell Mein Kampf, are you going  
>> to  be upset?
>>
>> -- 
>> "Jupiter accepts your offer..."
>> AIM:IMFDUP
>>
>>

Subject: [sfraves]  BSP: Beach Party, Sunday March 4th

------=_NextPart_000_0308_01C7594D.63415B90
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="----=_NextPart_001_0309_01C7594D.63415B90"


------=_NextPart_001_0309_01C7594D.63415B90
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

 

 

 

March Forth!

 

A beach cleanup and gathering of your friends & groovy tunes with: 

Donna Matrix (rEvolution, Panda Rejects) 

Alxndr(Downlow)

DJ Goyo (Uptempo Productions)

 

+ a bonfire to keep you toasty as the sun goes down! We're raising awareness
about a sustainable Ocean Beach and having some fun in the process.

 

When: Sunday March 4th, 2:00-7:30 pm

What: Beach Cleanup with good friends + a groovin' afterparty
Where: Ocean Beach, stairway 20
Why: Ocean Beach needs our help! Irresponsible burning and littering leave
OB covered in litter. You and your friends can help by lending a few hours
of your time for a good cause.
Who: All are welcome. Make new friends, clean up the beach. Enroll as many
people as you can to join us!

RSVP here:  <http://tinyurl.com/3bbxno> http://tinyurl.com/3bbxno

 

Schedule

2:00 Meet at stairway 20, just down from the sand dunes at Lincoln Ave. and
Great Highway
     - A member of our team will provide you with garbage bags and gloves
(we'll have a table set up)
4:00 Cleanup complete
4:30 DJ's start spinning records
4:30-7:30 Par-tay (Alxndr, Goyo and Donna Matrix!)
6:00 Sunset 

7:30 Party winds down-- everybody lends a hand to clean up

 

Bonfire-DJ's-drumming-marshmallows-good peeps...a beach party in March!

 

 * Bring warmish clothing for daylight and afterdaylight. Bring your own
food and refreshments to keep hydrated. Bring hot dogs or marshmallows and a
coat hanger to use to roast them! We'll also be taking donations for the
Ocean Beach Foundation which is working to build fire rings at Ocean Beach
to ensure responsible burning.

 

Note: it is the Ocean Beach policy not to have alcoholic beverages on the
beach. If some should happen to appear, they should be in non-descript
plastic containers. For more on responsible beach fire policies please click
<http://www.nps.gov/goga/parkmgmt/upload/firemanagement_oceanbeach_fireregs_
20031204.pdf>  here.

 

For more information on the fire pits project and the Ocean Beach foundation
<http://www.oceanbeachfoundation.org/>  click here.

	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

div.Section1
	{page:Section1;}
-->
</style>

</head>

<body bgcolor=3Dwhite lang=3DEN-US link=3Dblue vlink=3Dpurple>

<div class=3DSection1>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span =
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";
color:#1F497D'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span =
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";
color:#1F497D'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<div>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><strong><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>March
Forth!<o:p></o:p></span></strong></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>A&nbsp;beach
cleanup and gathering of your friends &amp; groovy tunes with: =
</span><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><strong><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Donna
Matrix (rEvolution, Panda Rejects)</span></strong><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'> </span><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><strong><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Alxndr(Downlo=
w)</span></strong><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><strong><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>DJ
Goyo (Uptempo Productions)</span></strong><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>+
a bonfire to keep you toasty as the sun goes down! We're raising =
awareness
about a sustainable Ocean Beach and having some fun in the =
process.</span><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span =
style=3D'font-size:13.5pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>When:
Sunday March 4th, 2:00-7:30 pm<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span =
style=3D'font-size:13.5pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>What:</span><=
span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'> Beach =
Cleanup with
good friends&nbsp;+ a groovin' afterparty<br>
<strong><span =
style=3D'font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Where:</span></strong> Ocean
Beach, stairway 20<br>
<strong><span =
style=3D'font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Why:</span></strong> Ocean
Beach needs our help! Irresponsible burning and littering leave&nbsp;OB =
covered
in litter. You and your friends can help by lending a few hours&nbsp;of =
your
time for a good cause.<br>
<strong><span =
style=3D'font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Who:</span></strong> All
are welcome. Make new friends, clean up the beach. Enroll as many people =
as you
can to join us!</span><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span =
style=3D'font-size:13.5pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>RSVP
here: </span><a href=3D"http://tinyurl.com/3bbxno"><span =
style=3D'font-size:13.5pt;
font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>http://tinyurl.com/3bbxno</span></a><o:=
p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span =
style=3D'font-size:13.5pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>&nbsp;<o:p></=
o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><u><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Schedule</spa=
n></u><u><span
style=3D'font-size:13.5pt'><o:p></o:p></span></u></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span =
style=3D'font-size:13.5pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>2:00</span><s=
pan
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'> =
Meet&nbsp;at
stairway 20, just down from the sand dunes at Lincoln Ave. and Great =
Highway<br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; - A member of our team will provide you with =
garbage bags
and gloves (we'll have a table set up)<br>
4:00 Cleanup complete<br>
4:30 DJ's start spinning records<br>
4:30-7:30 Par-tay (Alxndr, Goyo and Donna Matrix!)<br>
6:00 Sunset&nbsp;</span><span =
style=3D'font-size:13.5pt'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span =
style=3D'font-size:13.5pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>7:30
Party winds down-- everybody lends a hand to clean =
up<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Bonfire-DJ's-=
drumming-marshmallows-good
peeps...a beach party&nbsp;in March!</span><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>&nbsp;*
Bring warmish clothing for daylight and afterdaylight. Bring your own =
food and
refreshments to keep hydrated. Bring hot dogs or marshmallows and a
coat&nbsp;hanger to use to roast them! We'll also be taking donations =
for the
Ocean&nbsp;Beach Foundation which is working to build fire rings at =
Ocean Beach
to&nbsp;ensure responsible burning.</span><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Note:
it is the Ocean Beach policy not to have alcoholic beverages on =
the&nbsp;beach.
If some should happen to appear, they should be in =
non-descript&nbsp;plastic
containers. For more on responsible beach fire policies please <a
href=3D"http://www.nps.gov/goga/parkmgmt/upload/firemanagement_oceanbeach=
_fireregs_20031204.pdf">click
here.</a></span><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>For
more information on the fire pits project and the <a
href=3D"http://www.oceanbeachfoundation.org/">Ocean Beach =
foundation&nbsp;click
here</a>.</span><o:p></o:p></p>

<div>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

</div>

</div>

Here is a forwarded message from the owner of Kink.com, a BDSM porn site. As
many of you may or may not know, Kink.com recently purchased the historic
Armory and are planning to use it for movie productions. There are some
naysayers who are trying to protest this and there will be a hearing about
it soon.

*********************

 Hi Everyone,



As you know, we have come under a certain amount of heat for buying the
Armory to use for movie production.



Despite the fact that the Planning Department agreed to our use prior to the
purchase, the Mayor pressured them into holding a public hearing on March 8
th 10-12:30 in City Hall, room 416.



This is an 'informational meeting' designed to hear community feedback, and
there will be no vote.  However, in order to prevent the city from
attempting to rezone the Armory, It is important that we show up in force
and that we outnumber the protesters, so please save the date! We will send
out more information nearer the time.



Cheers

Peter

------=_Part_51485_27731610.1172539638795--

Wasn't the initial fight from the community because the building was  
going to be used for more housing? I remember the whole community  
fighting the permits for construction, due to the noise, etc.  
Kink.com moved in because the city was slow and Kink wasn't doing any  
new building, thus slipped in not needing permits.

http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/02/01/ 
EDGC7N768I1.DTL&hw=kink&sn=008&sc=314

"For decades, politicians and neighborhood activists have rejected or  
neglected well-laid plans for the massive building. Now the  
neighborhood is getting back some of that hostility in the form of  
Kink.com, the on-line fetish porn Web site, which bought the building  
quickly and quietly last month and plans to start filming as soon as  
possible. Because the new owners won't be making any structural  
changes to the building, they've been able to bypass the Planning  
Department -- and all the requisite delays, obstacles and public  
obstinateness. "

"thus slipped in not needing permits."

Kink.com hasn't slipped in all sneaky like. The Planning Department has
known about all the details of this for awhile and everything has been
permitted and signed. This isn't like people in city government looked on
the desk one day and said "Well dang! Those porno folks sure did trick us!"

The only difference now is that the mass media has gotten wind of the deal
and are having the expected outcry over anything sexual. The hearing they
are having isn't anything decisive, but a forum for people to voice their
opinions. But, there will most likely be protesters there shouting about
"moral decline" and "Family values" and the like. Sex seems to really make
people freak out, even though no one will be able to go in there or even see
what goes on from the outside.

If you're referring to the possible corruption of youth, let me ask: how?
How will any kids in the neighborhood be corrupted? They can't get inside
the building and they can't see anything. The most that will happen is that
they might walk by the brick monolith and point and giggle from across the
street.

i forgot that logical reasoning doesn't play into account here in the sfr 
twilight zone - my bad  :)

your question is a completely separate topic but to answer it, i would agree 
with you that if my child were forced to observe either a) a man getting a 
blowjob, b) a [street] fight, or c) a stabbing, i would slide my #2 pencil 
into the "a" box.

this answer doesn't change my viewpoint regarding your previous experience. 
no counter-speculation will make me agree with your assessment that one 
should be okay with coming home to observe a random stranger giving a 
blowjob in their driveway unless I am the one getting the blowjob !

-=dave

blow jobs are g r a t e !

Which brings me right back to my original comment of the day, that the 
U.S. is too damn puritanical.

And it signals time for a joke (but you better close your eyes SE/30. 
Wouldn't want to offend.)
Little Johnnie walks in on his mom and dad makin love.

Johnnie asks: Mom, what are you doing?

Mom: Umm...uh...Im....um....Daddy gets full of air sometimes and i gotta 
let some out....

Dad: Yeah. Thats what she's doing.

Johnnie: Well mom, thats a waste of time cuz the lady next-door's just 
gonna blow him back up again.....

> with you that if my child were forced to observe either a) a man getting a 
> blowjob, b) a [street] fight, or c) a stabbing, i would slide my #2 pencil 
> into the "a" box.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Help SF Stay Kinky! - sex jokes !

if thinking that young children shouldn't be taught that public display of 
fornication should be as uneventful as a common handshake makes me 
"puritanical" then by your definition, I am... wholeheartedly.

i want to educate my future child (if any) about all things in life at the 
same pace as their capacity to understand them.  i don't want my elementary 
school teacher or transients in my driveway doing it for me cause it 
invariably breeds misinformation.  a child should get the straight skinny 
from their parents!

like so:

-------------
A little girl came home from school excited and told her mom she had learned 
where babies come. Amused, her mother replied, "Really, sweetie? Where?"

The little girl explained, "Well... OK... the mommy and daddy take their 
clothes off, and the daddy's thing sort of stands up, and the mommy puts it 
in her mouth, and then it sort of explodes, and that's where babies come 
from!"

Her mom shook her head, leaned over to meet her daughter eye to eye, and 
said, "Oh, honey, that's sweet, but that's not where babies come from. 
That's where jewelry comes from."
-------------

-=dave

education is g r a t e !

Actually, that is puritanical. When the Puritans settled here and
encountered the Natives they were horrified at the sexual practices they
engaged in. It was very common amongst Natives for young children to
masturbate in the open or teenagers and adults to have sex where people
could see them and it was no big thing. The journals of some later explorers
are pretty funny when they describe native sexual culture, but the sad side
is that they used the differences in sexual practices to legitimize killing
them and stealing their lands, because anyone who lets children see sex is
obviously an incurable savage.

Nice joke though.

I'm also describing people who were syphilis free until the European
settlers came over. Would you rather live in a syphilis free world or a
wheel free world back then? I would pick the syphilis free one, because a
lack of wheels doesn't cause widespread death.

As nice as it is to see this conversation get derailed completely, if you do
care about what's going on with kink.com, please save the date of March 8th.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Help SF Stay Kinky! - sex jokes !

If you feel that way, then I'd suggest staying the fuck out of Europe, 
where full frontal male and female nudity is constantly used in 
advertising, in print, and during "prime time" on the TeeBee, because if 
you saw that, then your head might explode in righteous indignation, 
like then FCC Chairman's Michael Powell's almost did when he almost got 
a peek at Janet Jackson's big bad boobie during the SuperBowl a few 
years back.

That was pretty funny.

I never thought I'd ever agree with anyone that works at AEI, with the 
exception of Stormin' Norman Ornstein, but when this total hottie of a 
guest of Bill Maher's, Ayaan Hirsi Ali, (from Holland, by way of 
Somalia), asked, "When will Americans ever grow up?" on the show last 
Friday night, I couldn't help but to agree with her.

This thread just reinforces that sentiment.

I've been saying for the last few weeks that we Americans have the 
collective emotional maturity of a 14 year old, but now I see that I 
need to revise that downward to about the age of 12, since that's prolly 
more accurate.

~nyc

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Help SF Stay Kinky! - sex jokes !

agreeing with a single Puritan ideal does not a Puritan make :)

however, regarding what is "puritan", what ideals are Puritan, and what 
ideals are normatively accepable to different cultures, i am not living in a 
tribal community of hunter-gatherers.  my normative ideals would be quite 
different if i were... which reminds me of an old (OLD !)  joke that 
everyone has heard a million times !

--------------
A young man in a tribal north american native community had the opportunity 
to speak candidly with the high cheif after a newborn's "naming" ceremony. 
The boy asked the very old cheif, "how do you come up with the names for all 
of us?"  the cheif replied, "when a child is born, that night i meditate in 
my teepee and the first thing i see when i emerge in the morning is what i 
name the newborn.  When your father was born, in the morning i saw an eagle 
gliding high above the desert and so he was named Soaring Eagle.  When your 
mother was born, I saw a dear bounding carelessly through the snow , and so 
she was named Prancing Doe.  Why do you ask, Two Dogs Fucking ?"
--------------


-=dave

normative reasoning is g r a t e !

> you saw that, then your head might explode in righteous indignation, like 
> then FCC Chairman's Michael Powell's almost did when he almost got a peek

> asked, "When will Americans ever grow up?" on the show last Friday night,

my brother's cock- is due to the fact that in every instance that  
said cocks were present, neither were in a "raging erection" state.

erect size based on flaccid size- sure when I was 4yo I looked up and  
thought "gee mine's much smaller"- but uh- that's about it.

Do you really not see a difference between full frontal nudity and  
copulation?

The fucking kid sees himself in the mirror every day, can see the  
front of his own body, and can touch himself all he wants.
I agree that the US is too uptight about nudity on TV etc, but that's  
a very far cry from sex in public.

A 5yo will understand me if I teach him about violence.
A 5yo will understand me if I teach him about his own body.
A 5yo will FUCKING NOT UNDERSTAND ME AT ALL if I try to teach him  
about sex.

>> their clothes off, and the daddy's thing sort of stands up, and

>> that's where babies come from!"
>>

>> babies come from. That's where jewelry comes from."

>>>>>> i would agree with you that if my child were forced to observe

>>>>>> previous experience. no counter-speculation will make me agree

>>>>>> driveway unless I am the one getting the blowjob !

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Help SF Stay Kinky!

How about this...

Children should be the problem of the people who... you know...  
choose to have children.  And those people should keep them to  
themselves.  Or.... it doesn't take a village, it takes a fucking  
PARENT.

Likewise, those of us who choose NOT to have children (Which I  
personally believe is the more responsible choice; but that's another  
topic.) should not have to have other peoples' children imposed on  
us.  If I choose to watch porn... if I choose to watch kinky porn  
produced in an armory.... you can bet your damn ass there will be no  
children in the room.  And I see no reason whatsoever to, in any way,  
change my behavior, either by myself, with a partner, or a with group  
of consenting adults, on account of someone else's lifestyle choice.

Self-righteous, busybody, "think of the children" types can mind  
their own fucking business.

You seem to have been on a fairly hardcore libertarian-esque binge  
recently.  I'd have thought that you'd have had a similar sentiment.


cya,
john

"Shortbus"

From: Nyc Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Help SF Stay Kinky!

I've noticed that starting somewhere in the mid-late 90s that the gen 
coming up behind me has a rising level of prudishness that seems to be 
in inverse proportion to all the "open-mindedness" "hip slick & 
cooleality" and "freedom" they purport to have. It's an odd phenomenon 
and I can't be the only one that's noticed this.

Not that I'm immune to societal indoctrination myself.

I learned at an early age just how quick and deep the indoctrination 
runs here in the good old US of A. When I was around nine years old I 
spent the summer visiting relatives that lived in a formerly communist 
country. Well, there, in the then glorious worker's paradise, all people 
were equal, which meant that their beaches were all clothing optional. 
One of the greatest freak-outs in my life came when we hit the sand one 
weekend and everyone, my aunt, uncle and cousins all went au natural on 
me, on the spot. I was so mortified that I spent the day, not only fully 
clothed but also wrapped in a towel, completely averting my eyes. This 
was at the age of nine.

Once I grew up I saw how brainwashed I had been at such an early age and 
have gone out of my way to break myself of it. Part of that means not 
paying attention to our arbiters of sexual morality, like the good folks 
over at the Catholic Church, they had 1,500 years to get it right, and 
at the end of it the best they could come up with was Paul Shanley and 
John Geoghan, so I don't listen to what they have to say about anything 
on this particular subject, and I wonder why anyone still takes them 
seriously about anything.

~nyc

Two nuns are walking through the Mission to the grocery store when they're

    But we were only raped once.

    [fanning her flushed face] Yeah, but we're going to have to go back the 
same way we came !

Subject: [sfraves] (sorta bsp) Alex Under & Sammy Dee at KONTROL on Saturday!

(this is only sorta bsp cuz I ain't the promoter, just
a big techno fan...)

Ok, I've been looking forward to this event for
months.  I saw Alex Under play live at Mutek and he
was so good - psychedlic tripped-out vocals, crazy
rocking dance floor... anyway, you'll miss out if you
miss this.  

Saturday, March 3rd

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant house
every first Saturday at the Endup


featuring from Berlin, Germany:

SAMMY DEE  ( perlon . poker flat . kanzleramt)
 
Sammy Dee is one half of Pantytec alongside production
partner
and Perlon label founder Zip.  His incredible
forward-thinking DJ
sets have helped shape the sound of minimal house and
techno
worldwide for over a decade, and have made their
legendary
monthly party, "Get Perlonized", the toast of Berlin.
 
 
and from Madrid, Spain:
 
ALEX UNDER -  Live PA  ( plus 8 . trapez . cmyk musik
. apnea )
 
Spain's scorching hot Alex Under has gained
international acclaim in
the last few years for his fresh, cerebral, and
energetic take on live
techno. Add to that his superb production work and a
top-notch
record label, and you've got one of the hottest
tickets on the planet
right now.
 

plus special guest from Seattle:

KRISTINA CHILDS  ( decibel festival . plasmodium radio
. krakt! )
 

with resident DJs:
 
CRAIG KUNA   ( concept sf . esdjco )
NIKOLA BAYTALA   ( robsoul . junior boys own .
s.w.a.t. )
ALLAND BYALLO   ( liebe detail . floppy funk )
SAMMY D   ( classic . dirtybird . utensil )
